PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Census
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the current practice of destroying the Census is denying future generations an invaluable and irreplaceable resource of data on medical, historical, social, scientific, and demographic factors.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

Request the Government to review its current policy of destroying the Census; and support a proposal to retain the census forms for release for specific research purposes in either 70 or 100 years time.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.

PARA.TAB: Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self-determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PARA.TAB: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and Other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PETITION.PARA: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PARA.TAB: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values

PETITION.PARA: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We request the Senate to call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned:
1. Condemns the President of France, Jacques Chirac, and the French Government for deciding to resume nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll;
2. Joins in the world-wide anger over France's decision, which calls into question France's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty;
3. Urges the Federal Government to urgently inform France in the strongest possible terms of the anger felt by the people of Australia at the decision;
4. Calls on the Federal Government to consider all available diplomatic; economic and cultural measures which may force the French Government to cancel nuclear testing.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we citizens of Australia support a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support our call for a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines, give high priority to support efforts to clear land mines in affected countries and use its influence to encourage other countries to financially support the clearance of land mines in poor countries.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned urges the Government to press for a total ban internationally on the production, stockpiling, trade and use of anti-personnel devices;
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate urge the Government to provide financial aid for the de-mining of countries such as Cambodia.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that many Australians are concerned that the Federal Government is not supporting efforts to introduce a timetable for the elimination of nuclear weapons at the April extension conference of the NPT:
Your Petitioners ask/request that the Senate should call on the Government to do everything in its power to support such a timetable and help to rid the world of nuclear weapons.

PETITION.TITLE: Veterans' Entitlement Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectively showeth:

PARA.TAB: That while the Australian Government has supported the commemorating of the events of World War II with the Australia Remembers 1945-95 program—there are those within the War Veterans' community who served in the Chemical Warfare Unit (1944) and the British, Commonwealth Occupational Forces (Japan) still fighting for compensation and recognition of their valuable service.

That 1995-96 marks 10 years since the Hawke Labor Government repealed all Repatriation laws dating back to 1920 and replaced them with the Veterans Entitlement Act 1986 which has caused hardship and in some cases discrimination;
Now therefore your petitions request that the Senate look at the hardship that is being imposed by the Veterans Entitlement Act of 1986 on those within this community.

The staff at the Grampians Community Health Centre support the recent expression of concern and disapproval on the part of Australians over proposed French nuclear testing at Mururoa.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

TAB.TAB: (i)with great regret, the death of Dame Pattie Menzies, wife of Australia's longest serving Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, and

(b)notes that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) has grudgingly acknowledged, in a statement reported in the Australian of 29 August 1995, that the youth unemployment national figure of 28.2 per cent is intolerable and could lead to the creation of a youth underclass;

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances I give notice that 15 sitting days after today I shall move that the Formulation of Guidelines made under subsection 51AL(7) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, and Determination HS/1/1995 made under subsection 3C(1) of the Health Insurance Act 1973, be disallowed. I seek leave to make a short statement about the committee's concerns with this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee's concerns with these instruments relate to possible prejudicial retrospectivity. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the matters raised by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The summary read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Formulation of Guidelines made under subsection 51AL(7) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936

SPEECH.PARA: These Guidelines revoke existing Guidelines and formulate new Guidelines relating to deductions for approved occupational clothing.

Clause 3 of the explanatory material which accompanied the Guidelines provides as follows: "These guidelines supersede those of 1 September 1993 and are effective as of 7 June 1995. The changes in these Guidelines are not retrospective." The Committee understands that the Guidelines were not notified in the Gazette until 21 June 1995. Under s.48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 the Guidelines would therefore be of no effect if rights are affected or liabilities imposed on any person other than the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth authority before that date. The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice on the retrospectivity.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Determination HS/1/1995 made under subsection 3C(1) of the Health Insurance Act 1973

SPEECH.PARA: This Determination provides for the payment of medicare benefits for a specified medical procedure.
The Determination was made retrospective to 1 November 1994.

The Committee wrote to the Minister seeking advice confirming that the retrospectivity of the Determination did not prejudicially affect any individual other than the Commonwealth. The Minister subsequently advised that no financial liability is imposed on any person or organisation other than the Commonwealth.

The Committee has again written to the Minister seeking advice on effect of the Determination on people who are members of health funds. The Committee asked whether people who would otherwise have been entitled to "gap" benefits were deprived of them retrospectively by the Determination.

I refer to Determination No.2 of 1995 made under section 356 of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 which was before the Committee at its meeting on 1 June 1995.

Dear Mal
Thank you for your letter of 1 June 1995 concerning Determination No 2 of 1995 made under section 356 of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 which was considered by the Committee on that day.

On 9 January 1995 Determination No 1 of 1995 was notified in the Gazette. It took effect from that day. My Department has informed me that, regrettably, no action taken between 31 January and 9 March 1995 (the next fifteen sitting days after the signing of that Determination) to table that Determination in both Houses of the Parliament in accordance with paragraph 48(1)(c) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

As a consequence of that breakdown in procedures within my Department that Determination was not scrutinised by the Committee, and it ceased to have effect, under subsection 48(3) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, on 10 March 1995. I regret that this has happened. I have been informed that procedures are now in place that should ensure that such a situation will not happen again.

My Department has informed me that information has been released between 10 March and 12 May 1995 (when Determination No 2 of 1995 took effect) in conformity with the Guidelines set under Determination No 1 of 1995.

My Department has been advised that the absence of Ministerial guidelines under section 356 of the Act does not mean that there is no legal authority for the exercise of powers under section 355 of the Act during that absence. The provisions, in section 355 that refer to `guidelines from time to time in force' mean, according to that advice, that, if there are Ministerial guidelines, they must be observed but, if there happen to be no Ministerial guidelines, then the statutory power may continue to be exercised. In any event my Department acted as though the Ministerial guidelines were in force.
My Department has confirmed that both sets of guidelines were prepared in consultation with and cleared by staff of the Privacy Commissioner.
Yours sincerely

Dear Sir/Madam

Thank you for your letter of 1 June 1995 about Instrument No 126 of 1995 made under section 196B(2) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and Instrument No 125 of 1995 made under section 196B(3) of that Act.

As you point out, Instrument No 126 amended Instrument 99 which was about `chronic myeloid leukaemia'. The inclusion of the word `acute' was inappropriate since both the Statement and the factor were talking of the `chronic' form, a different medical condition. There was already a Statement of Principles for `acute myeloid leukaemia', Instrument 35 of 1994. No disadvantage occurs to the sufferers of that condition since the same factor appears in that Instrument.
I therefore give the Committee the assurance that no person has been prejudiced by the making of the amendment.

The second part of your letter deals with acknowledgment of the discovery of the error in Instrument No 125 of 1995 and I can give the same assurance that no person has been disadvantaged by that change. I will pass your letter on to the Repatriation Medical Authority for future reference.

Dear Senator Colston

I refer to your letter of 8 June 1995 concerning the Sales Tax Assessment Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1995 No. 86, and the Sales Tax Procedure (Old Law) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1995 No. 87. These statutory rules amend the regulations which specify the information which must be shown on evidentiary certificates for use by the Commissioner of Taxation in proceedings to recover unpaid sales tax.

The statutory rules under consideration make identical changes to the Sales Tax Assessment Regulations and the Sales Tax Procedure (Old Law) Regulations. In each case the amendments remove the need for specifying the year in respect of which tax has been assessed in evidentiary certificates used by the Commissioner of Taxation in sales tax recovery proceedings.

You seek advice on the need for the amendments. You also seek advice as to whether any evidentiary certificates issued after 16 June 1994 (the date on which the requirement to include a reference to the year of assessment was included in the regulations) did not mention the year and, if so, whether such certificates were used in actions to recover unpaid sales tax.

The first point to note is that the amendments operate retrospectively to correct an error made by amendments to the regulations which took effect on 16 June 1994. The two offending amendments were part of a package of changes which included the standardisation of evidentiary certificates for recovery of several kinds of taxes including sales tax. Part of the standardisation of certificates was a requirement that the evidentiary certificate should include the year in respect of which the assessment of tax was made against the person.

The Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992 and Sales Tax Assessment Act (No.1) 1930 (and other sales tax assessment Acts affecting dealings with goods before 1 January 1993) do not impose a liability to taxation in respect of a year or any other period. Accordingly, a regulation containing the requirement to specify, on sales tax evidentiary certificates, the year in respect of which an assessment was made is inconsistent with the principal Acts.

Given this inconsistency, the reference to `year' in sales tax regulations on evidentiary certificates could cause confusion amongst taxpayers, and the courts and tribunals that deal with sales tax matters. The amendments effected by SR86 and SR87 of 1995 are therefore necessary to remove the possibility of such confusion.

Since 16 June 1994 the Commissioner has issued 6 evidentiary certificates in court proceedings to recover unpaid sales tax. Generally, the certificates are used in court in contested actions against individuals for recovery of unpaid sales tax. None of the 6 certificates specified a year in respect of which unpaid sales tax had accrued. The requirement to specify the year was disregarded because of uncertainty about the meaning of the requirement and because there is no power under the principal legislation to issue assessments for sales tax in respect of a particular year.
I trust the above is of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
GEORGE GEAR

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the first report of 1995 of the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee on the examination of annual reports.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No. 338 entitled Accrual accounting—a cultural change and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: It gives me pleasure today to table on behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts the results of the committee's 338th report entitled Accrual accounting—a cultural change. This is the result of the committee's review of two reports presented to the parliament by the Auditor-General in 1994. Those reports were Auditor-General's report No. 32 of 1993-94 entitled Efficiency audit, accrual reporting—are agencies ready? and Auditor-General's report No. 16 of 1994-95 entitled Follow-up audit, accrual reporting—are agencies ready?. These audit reports contained an assessment of whether Commonwealth agencies were adequately prepared to meet their obligations to report on an accruals basis for the 1994-95 financial year. Prior to this, the majority of Commonwealth agencies had been reporting on a cash accounting basis.

PARA.TAB: Accrual accounting has been with us for a long time and is the basis for accounting in the private sector and in government business enterprises. Accrual accounting recognises revenue and expenses in the accounting period in which they occur. This contrasts with cash accounting which records transactions when cash is exchanged. Accrual accounting therefore aims to match the costs incurred during a particular reporting period with the benefits earned in that same period. It also segregates capital transactions from operating transactions. It is a commonsense approach.

The committee's interest in promoting accrual concepts has a long history. In Report 34, The Trust Fund, which was tabled in 1957, the committee argued that Commonwealth bodies operating on a trust account, rather than from the consolidated revenue fund, should keep a profit and loss account and a balance sheet which should be certified by the Auditor-General. Later, in 1982, the committee recommended that cash based accounting should be eliminated as the primary basis for financial reporting by Commonwealth authorities and, instead, that accrual accounting should be adopted.

It also became clear in the committee's recent inquiry into the commercialisation of public sector operations that many Commonwealth agencies, particularly those which had moved to adopt a more commercial approach to program and service delivery, had found accrual reporting and accounting to be a valuable management tool. For this reason, the committee broadened its inquiry beyond the assessment of the readiness of Commonwealth agencies to produce reports on an accrual basis for this last financial year to the uses of accrual information—by the government, by agency managers and by external reviewers—to facilitate better judgments about operating performance, economic impact and the stewardship of public resources.

During the review, the committee received evidence at public hearings in Canberra, Melbourne and Sydney, at which the experiences of agencies within the Commonwealth, Victorian and New South Wales jurisdictions were canvassed. As well, information was sought from other states and territories and from New Zealand, which has been at the forefront of introducing accrual accounting for government agencies in the world.

Report No. 338 considers at some length the uses to which the information in accrual reports can be put. In particular, information can be used to make comparisons between reporting periods and between agencies. Such information has the potential to be of great benefit to the parliament, to which agencies are held accountable, and to the public through media commentators.

To assist those interpreting accrual based financial statements, the committee has recommended that the Department of Finance should develop a professional marketing strategy directed at the potential users of agency financial statements and also that the Department of the Senate and Department of the House of Representatives develop information and training packages on the new financial reports for members of parliament and parliamentary staff. For its part, the committee intends to write to all parliamentarians and party whips informing them of the type of accountability and performance information that can be derived from such reports.

The committee believes that accrual information is an essential tool for modern public sector day-to-day management. Without regular access to accrual information, it is not possible to make accurate assessments of the cost of service provision and thereby the efficiency of program performance. It is of concern to the committee that, as yet, only a few agencies have recognised the value of accrual information, and even fewer have taken the initiative to explore the full potential of accrual information. The committee believes that, at agency level, accrual based financial management systems should be introduced and more should be done to educate managers in how to make best use of accrual information. There should also be incentives to encourage agencies to adopt the reform.

The committee makes a specific recommendation in the report that the government should make a statement stressing the value of accrual information as an aid to effective management of public resources and supporting the move towards full accrual accounting for government agencies. Recommendation No. 11 states:

SPEECH.PARA: All agency heads should:
(a) commit themselves and their agencies to the implementation of accrual management systems and practices . . .
The recommendation further states:

PARA.TAB: The Committee intends to review, 12 months after the tabling of this report, a sample of agencies to test their performance in implementing accrual accounting systems and accrual management practices.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee notes that there is a basic incoherence in the Commonwealth's financial management system—funds are appropriated on a cash basis, but end of year reports are now made on an accrual basis. In the committee's opinion, this is not only inelegant but also sends mixed messages to managers. Managers are inclined to focus on cash—it is cash they have been appropriated—but the end of year accrual reports mean that they are held accountable for more than just managing cash. Such a system is likely to undermine the potential of the reforms undertaken to date. The committee has recommended, therefore, that there should be a major review of the Commonwealth's system of budget appropriations to consider the merits of requiring that budgets be prepared and appropriations made on an accrual basis.

PARA.TAB: Report 338 concludes with a discussion of the next major accounting reform for the Commonwealth—whole of government reporting. The committee believes that preparing such reports on an annual basis would provide information of great value to cabinet, to the government's key economic advisers, to parliamentarians and to many other external users. Whole of government reports would help inform strategic decisions about government priorities and policies and would enable the government to better account for its use of public resources.

Much work needs do be done in teasing out the issues surrounding the preparation of whole of government reports, and the committee has decided to maintain its involvement in this area by conducting a separate and more detailed review of the issues involved. The committee intends to report on these matters during the course of the current parliament.

I would like to emphasise that the recent introduction of accrual reporting across the Commonwealth public sector should be seen as only one step in the reform process. The committee has found that the core sector area still retains a cultural attachment to cash accounting, and the committee believes there is a danger that the reform process will stall unless the government sets new targets beyond just accrual reporting.

The government should articulate a clear vision for the future of financial reporting in the Commonwealth, incorporating whole of government reporting, accrual management and, possibly, accrual based budgeting. A statement of direction from the government would give great impetus to the tentative steps now being taken by agencies toward accrual accounting and accrual management.

Finally, and on behalf of the committee, I would like to express our thanks to the people who contributed to the review by preparing submissions and by giving evidence at public hearings. I would also like to thank the staff of the secretariat for assisting the committee in preparing the report, in particular Laura Gillies, Donna Christophers, Jennifer Hughson, John Carter and Grant Harrison. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT AND REPEAL BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Faulkner) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill amends the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act 1990, the Veterans' Entitlements (Rewrite) Transition Act 1991, the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1992, the Veterans' Affairs (1994-95 Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Act 1994, and the Military Compensation Act 1994. The bill will also repeal two obsolete War Service Homes Acts.

The bill contains a number of minor policy and technical changes to Veterans' Affairs legislation. The amendments improve readability, correct imperfections in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 rewrite, and correct typographical errors.

The bill rectifies anomalies in certain assessments of service pension and income support supplement. These include the calculation of child-related payments and of rent assistance for certain blind pensioners, and also for certain war widows and war widowers who receive a "frozen rate" of service pension.
Some of the changes to the provisions for service pensions have been made to bring consistency with the Social Security Act 1991.

The bill will allow people participating in local exchange trading systems to do so without their non-cash credits being taken as income in the assessment of their service pension or income support supplement.
Carers of service pensioners who accompany the veteran overseas will be able to continue to receive their carer service pension for up to three months of their temporary absence from Australia.

The bill also extends eligibility for a remote area allowance to service pensioners and income support supplement recipients who are residents of Norfolk Island and Lord Howe Island. A remote area allowance is to help compensate residents for the higher than normal costs associated with living in a remote area of Australia. Norfolk Island and Lord Howe Island are acknowledged as remote areas for taxation purposes, and the extension of eligibility for a remote area allowance under the Veterans' Entitlements Act to residents of those islands will remove an anomaly.

Mr President, the period for which Somalia is an operational area for the purposes of the Veterans' Entitlements Act is to be closed as from 30 November 1994. Somalia has been an operational area under the Veterans' Entitlements Act since 20 October 1992. All Australian personnel serving in Somalia were withdrawn by 30 November 1994.
The two acts to be repealed are the:
War Service Homes Agreement Act 1932; and the
War Service Homes (South Australia) Agreement Act 1934.

These acts approved agreements between the Commonwealth of Australia and the Commissioners of the then State Savings Bank of Victoria, and between the Commonwealth of Australia and the State of South Australia, to arrange the transfer back to the "War Service Homes Commissioner" of the Bank's or the State's interest in certain war service homes. If there was any continuing Commonwealth interest in the properties covered by those agreements it was transferred to the Westpac Banking Corporation when it took over the Defence Service Homes mortgage portfolio in 1988.
The War Service Homes Agreement Act 1932 and the War Service Homes (South Australia) Agreement Act 1934 serve no further purpose, and their repeal is appropriate.

In conclusion, Mr President, this is a bill without financial impact that will put into place a number of minor changes. An outcome of the changes is improvement in the administration of benefits for veterans and their dependants.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matters be referred to the Legal and Constitutional References Committee for inquiry and report on or before 23 November 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether an independent inquiry is justified into the conduct of the Commonwealth's actions in relation to Ryker (Faulkner) v the Commonwealth and Flint (9527/1982) and in particular into:

TAB.TAB: (a)the reasons for severe limitations which were imposed on the management of Mrs Faulkner's case; and
(b)the evidence at the trial.

SPEECH.PARA: Notice of motion No. 1 has been on the Notice paper for a while. It has been there because it has been of importance to listen to the various arguments that have been put to us in relation to this matter. I was offered and received a briefing from the government on this matter. I understand the matter has been looked at on several occasions. However, recent freedom of information data has revealed that there are matters that have not been dealt with, and it would seem that there is sufficient prima facie evidence for the matter to be looked into by an inquiry. No matter how much the matter has been dealt with in the past, there has not actually been an inquiry.

PARA.TAB: I would like to make it clear to the Senate that the wording in my motion is conservative. It is conservative in relation to the fact that it asks for matters to be referred to the Legal and Constitutional References Committee for inquiry as to whether an independent inquiry is justified into the conduct of the Commonwealth's actions in relation to Ryker (Faulkner) v. the Commonwealth and Flint, in particular into the reasons for severe limitations being imposed on the management of Mrs Faulkner's case and the evidence at the trial. That means looking into whether or not the Commonwealth is suggesting that Mrs Faulkner's case was weak because it was unsubstantiated, whether or not the right thing was done in not allowing witnesses to substantiate the case, or whether or not there was any interference with evidence. It is important to establish whether there are issues that remain unresolved.

No matter what the history of the case may be from years and years ago, if there are relatively recent events which appear to require investigation, that is what the committee is being asked to do. The committee is not being asked to sit as judge and jury, it is not being asked to sit as lawyers, but it is being asked to look at the evidence presented, especially in light of recent freedom of information-obtained data to find out whether, on the face of it, there seems to be the need for an independent inquiry. As this has never actually happened, that is why the motion is before the Senate today, to make sure—no matter what we think about what has happened over time—that the Commonwealth acted in a correct and proper way in its dealings in all ways in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter has been ongoing for some time. Without pre-judging the matter, I will acquaint the Senate with some of the details. Reg and Sylvia Faulkner ran an engineering company back in the 1960s called Trisal Engineering. There was a period of negotiation of some four years with the Department of Army, as it then was. As a result of those negotiations the Faulkners thought they had a contract, that the Army would be taking on their Trisal clip. The Army thought otherwise. As a result of representations the Faulkners say that Army made to it, they then acted to their detriment, and subsequently Mrs Sylvia Faulkner went bankrupt.

PARA.TAB: There was a writ issued against the Commonwealth in the High Court jurisdiction, I think it was in 1974. That was subsequently transferred to the Supreme Court of New South Wales. The matter was not resolved until 1987. In other words, the proceedings had been ongoing for some 13 years.

During the course of those proceedings it became apparent that a key witness to both sides, a Brigadier Flint, was a main player in the evidence in the case. This reference seeks to look at the Commonwealth's conduct during those proceedings and, in particular, in relation to the evidence produced at trial. The Faulkners say that Brigadier Flint in a letter to the Defence Ombudsman, I think it was, had said that he had acted with authority in the representations he made to the Faulkners, that is, that when he spoke to the Faulkners about whether their clip would be purchased by the army he had authority.

At trial Brigadier Flint said that he did not have authority. So there was a change in the evidence. The question is: how did that come about? Through freedom of information applications it became apparent that there were various notes of conversations made by Commonwealth officers whereby certain statements were made and Brigadier Flint's evidence was discussed. It is in relation to this aspect of the Commonwealth's approach to that matter that part of this reference relates. Among other things, there is a notation that Brigadier Flint should be required to say that he acted without authority, which was contrary to his previous statement. That is an aspect which needs looking at.

There are comments about Brigadier Flint's pension—that he should be told that he does not have to worry about his pension. Brigadier Flint had retired. It is alleged that he was worried about his pension and that the Commonwealth had raised this as an aspect of relevance and that it should be brought to his attention that he did not have to worry about his pension, the presumption there being that if Brigadier Flint was worried about his pension his actions or evidence might be flavoured in some way. I do not make any judgment either way in this regard. It is simply a question of whether this merits further investigation.

As well as this, the Faulkners did have legal aid to conduct their case. However, this was limited before trial and they were denied legal aid for the purposes of obtaining witnesses who they say were essential to their case. These witnesses were overseas. There was the question of the cost involved and the question of relevance. Nonetheless, they say that they could not conduct their case in a proper fashion without a full grant of legal aid. That is another limb, if you like, of the reference—the Commonwealth's actions regarding the limiting of legal aid to the Faulkners.

These are questions of vital importance not just to the Faulkners but generally in regard to how the Attorney-General's Department conducts itself in litigation. We know that in past years the courts have said from time to time that the Attorney-General's Department should act as a role model litigant. I think that would go without saying and the people of Australia would expect that to be so. That aspect needs the general attention of the committee in this reference.

The committee might well make some observations one way or the other about this. Nonetheless, after looking at the aspects of this case, the coalition and I believe that it does merit the attention of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee. Some of the terms of reference have been altered so that the issues have been distilled. Other issues were raised in relation to this matter, but the mover of the motion, and I support it, has seen that it is best to concentrate on the nub of the question.

This is not prejudging anything. It is merely bringing to the Senate's attention a situation which has cause for concern. I am not saying that it is a case which has been made out. We are certainly not at that stage. That is a case for the committee to decide. But, in the first instance, after having met with the officials from the department, who have been most helpful, I believe, and the coalition believes, that there are questions which remain unanswered and which should be answered in the interests of justice and to ensure that we, as protectors of the law in this country and as legislators, question the system of justice and question how the government involves itself in litigation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the referral of this matter to the Legal and Constitutional References Committee. I will make a few explanations as to why we do oppose it. Having looked at the matter overnight, I cannot remember a matter which had been dealt with so comprehensively so long ago being brought to the attention of this parliament. I cannot think of a matter which least deserves the amount of time that has been planned for it to receive through this process than this one. I hope Senator Spindler, Senator Ellison and senators from the Greens listen to some of what I am about to say, because I think it needs to be placed in the context of the history of how this matter has been dealt with to explain why the government opposes it.

PARA.TAB: We are talking about a matter which arose in the 1960s. I am advised that Mrs Faulkner's company invented the Trisal clip, which, I understand, is a haulage clip for securing tow ropes. Mr and Mrs Faulkner sought to sell the clip to the Australian Army. In attempting to do so, they had many dealings with the then engineer-in-chief of the Australian Army, Brigadier Flint. Over a period of years, the relationship between Flint and the Faulkners turned sour.

In 1974, therefore, proceedings were instituted against the Commonwealth and former Brigadier Flint. In those proceedings it was alleged that: Brigadier Flint made negligent or fraudulent statements in relation to the army's intentions to buy a large volume of Trisal clips from Mrs Faulkner's company, and to promote use of those clips by the armed forces of other countries; Mrs Faulkner invested in her company in reliance on these statements; orders of the size foreshadowed did not eventuate and the company failed; and Mrs Faulkner lost her investment in the company and also lost the financial benefits she would have derived from exploitation of her patent rights in the clips.

So in this case we are talking about conduct from the 1960s and proceedings instituted in the 1970s—matters from 20 to 30 years ago. The matter went to the supreme court. It was dismissed by Mr Justice Allen of the New South Wales Supreme Court in 1987. It is a 71-page judgment. The judgment, I am informed, was a comprehensive rejection of the allegations made by Mrs Faulkner, based on what was clearly a very thorough examination of the documentary and other evidence.

It is important to look at the judgment of the judge in 1987. As I say, we are talking about actions that happened in the 1960s and 1970s and a comprehensive court appraisal in 1987. From the judgment it appears that Mr and Mrs Faulkner set up Brigadier Flint to make the representations of which they complained and that, to the extent that any representations were false, the Faulkners were not misled—and this teems out of the judgment of the supreme court. Rather, the representations were made for the purpose of the Faulkners passing them on to others such as financiers, potential purchasers. One only has to look at page 26 of the judgment to get that.

It is important that Senator Ellison understand that the judge found that Brigadier Flint had engaged in unacceptable behaviour, and that is acknowledged. The judge was satisfied that it suited the Faulkners very well that Brigadier Flint had compromised himself—and that is in the judgment at page 44.

In determining whether we take this matter on it is important to note the comments by the judge, having rejected the Faulkners' evidence, and findings as to credibility. They are in the judgment and they are worth placing on the record in this place so that we can appraise the people who are producing this information and the information they are producing. A judge that I have no knowledge of, but in court in 1987, an eminent judge in New South Wales, Mr Justice Allen, had this to say about credibility:

SPEECH.PARA: Analysis of Mr Faulkner's conduct, however, reveals that not only was he grandiloquent but that he was one who deceitfully manipulated others to his own selfish ends, who played upon their own weaknesses of character, who lied when he thought that it was to his advantage to do so and who lashed out in a frenzy to get even with those whom he had considered had let him down.
That is telling in itself. But he goes on to say:
Underneath the veneer was a ruthless and amoral man. . . the basic personality remains—and the basic attitudes remain.

This is page 7 of the Supreme Court judgment. It is neither I nor the government saying it. This is what the judge who heard the case said about the credibility of those who are now seeking this inquiry.

PARA.TAB: I do not come to this issue with any degree of background other than having read a brief overnight. But it is important to keep in mind the judge's assessment of the proponents in this matter. At page 63 of the judgment he goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: I forebear from going into detail as to the conduct of the Faulkners after they found themselves to be financially destitute. The wildness and the vindictiveness of the accusations contained in the written material which is in evidence speaks for itself. It reflects no credit upon them.

It is apparent that in so far as the plaintiff's case must depend upon the reliability of the evidence of Mr Faulkner as to conversations involving the brigadier it is an edifice without foundations. The brigadier emerges with damaged credibility but Mr Faulkner emerges with no credibility.
So this is the judgment of the court, having heard all the matters, having adduced all the evidence.

PARA.TAB: Since that judgment—I think Senator Ellison picked up on this—the Faulkners have made a number of allegations of which two are probably pertinent to this particular motion. One assertion is that limitations were placed on the management of Mrs Faulkner's case. In matters such as this there are two questions to be determined: liability and the quantum of damages.

At the outset it should be made directly clear that the Commonwealth did not directly impose any limitation on the management of the Faulkners' case. Rather, after Mrs Faulkner's bankruptcy—which was another complicating circumstance in this complex tale—the Commonwealth was providing legal funding for her case.

In 1987 some limitations were imposed on the amount of that funding. Attorney-General Duffy and Attorney-General Lavarch, together with the Minister for Justice, Michael Tate, examined these allegations about the limitation. The reasons for the limitation on funding have been given; they have been justified on many occasions to the Faulkners and others who made representations on their behalf. I must also place on record here that, although there have been allegations of impropriety, no evidence has been adduced to support those allegations.

The bottom line is that in relation to the question of the Commonwealth's alleged liability to the Faulkners, which was the first thing that had to be established by the Faulkners, I am advised that legal funding was continued on terms and conditions consistent with the advice of the Faulkners' senior counsel.

So that brings us to another matter. Not only did they lose the case, not only were they slammed in the court but, thereafter, they turned against their senior counsel as well—and that is something which I think people appreciate.

It is true that funding of approximately $550,000 was refused—it is unfortunate that Senator Ellison is not listening to this—in relation to the calling of overseas witnesses. I am advised that the plaintiff's senior counsel had described that part of the plaintiff's claim in respect of which the overseas witnesses were necessary as `somewhat speculative'. The Solicitor-General, who had been instructed by Attorney-General Bowen to consider the plaintiff's claim in the context of a review of legal aid funding, described this part of the claim as `entirely speculative and very close to being bereft of any legal or factual justification'.

It was thus entirely proper, given the advice on the one hand from the plaintiff's counsel that it was somewhat speculative and the advice on the other hand from the Solicitor-General that it was entirely speculative and bereft of any legal or factual justification, for the Commonwealth to decline the funds for the calling of overseas witnesses on the basis that that would have been a waste of public funds. Moreover, it is worth noting that the witnesses related to the amount of damages which they claimed to have suffered rather than the liability. The first question to be tried was the question of whether there was in fact liability.

The Supreme Court of New South Wales ordered that the two questions—that is, the quantitative damages as opposed to whether the Commonwealth could be found to be liable—were to be tried separately. The liability issue was tried first. The witnesses from overseas—which involved $500,000 worth of airfares and whatever—went to the question of quantum.

Having tried the liability question first, the court found that the Faulkners had not established liability and therefore it did not need to consider the issue of damages. Thus, the limitation on funding in relation to overseas witnesses, even if it was unjustified, did not limit the plaintiff's capacity to conduct their case in relation to the Commonwealth's liability, which they lost. I think Senator Ellison will appreciate that the court said that you have to establish liability first and then you can go to the quantum.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is irrelevant to the terms of reference.

—If you had been listening for the last 10 minutes, you might have understood why all this is relevant. Out of a cooperative arrangement, the Commonwealth was asked to foot the bill for an extra $550,000 to bring in overseas witnesses relating to the question of the quantum, not the liability. They got tossed out on liability in a very comprehensive way by the court. That led to what normally happens in these situations where the clients come to the conclusion that their senior counsel did not understand the nature of their case so they turn on the senior counsel. That is essentially the case.

PARA.TAB: In a very compelling judgment the supreme court talks about credibility and tosses out this case. I have gone through the question of Commonwealth funding. I am informed that there was no limitation on the funding for the first case establishing the liability of the Commonwealth that went before the supreme court—the case which was tossed out.

Then there is the other matter which Senator Ellison raised about the Commonwealth's conduct with respect to the evidence. Those allegations have been considered by the Attorney-General and rejected. I am aware that documents have been released under the FOI Act which have been used to support allegations that the Commonwealth, through its senior counsel and officers, took action with a view to having Brigadier Flint give false evidence in the Commonwealth's favour.

My advice is that the material indicates that the Commonwealth had a firm belief that Brigadier Flint had not been telling the truth in relation to his dealings with the Faulkners. It is apparent from my advice that what was being considered—

TALK.START.PARA: —That doesn't justify their getting people to change their evidence.

—My advice is that the Commonwealth's view was that he had not been telling the truth in relation to his dealings with the Faulkners. It is apparent that what was being considered were means by which it might be possible to have Brigadier Flint tell what the Commonwealth regarded as the truth. Moreover, there is no evidence that any approach was made to Flint and officers consulted have denied having done so. Taking up your point, Senator Margetts, the problem you have is that you are trawling up a case which relies on the facts of some 30 years ago—a case which was comprehensively knocked off in the supreme court and a case in which the Commonwealth, particularly on a political level, has acted with total propriety.

PARA.TAB: I cannot think of a matter which has less relevance to current considerations and less substance in terms of arguments about access to justice than this one. You are talking about people who have had their credibility bounced by the supreme court in a comprehensive way. You are talking about people who, like many in this case—we get them day after day in our offices; I used to get them day after day in the legal profession—go from one lawyer to another, not being satisfied that the lawyer they had before, the one before that and the one before that could understand their case. As a consequence, they then turn on their lawyers.

I do not think this case is worthy of any more money being spent on it by the Commonwealth. I do not think it is worthy of getting priority in this place over so many other cases of current relevance to issues such as access to justice. I honestly think this is just a waste of time of this place and a waste of the priorities of senators. The government, having gone back through the evidence on this, would suggest that we have a lot of better things to do with both our time and money.

TALK.START.PARA: —This case has been dragging on for many years. I remember getting the first submissions on it shortly after I entered the Senate in 1990. I appreciate the comprehensive statement that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) has put before the Senate. There is little point served in my repeating the detailed technical aspects of the case as put on record by the minister, Senator Ellison and Senator Margetts.

PARA.TAB: It is always difficult for an individual, in a dispute with a government that does not hesitate to expend whatever resources it needs to make its particular case out, to obtain a fair hearing. In this case, the Australian Democrats support the limited inquiry by the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee to establish whether a further inquiry is necessary.

I would hesitate to commit the resources of the committee to a comprehensive inquiry into this case. The decision to support a limited one is made on balance. But it is incumbent upon us in a case such as this to spend a few hours establishing whether or not the case of the individual vis-a-vis the government has been made out or, on the balance of probability, is likely to be made out and whether it should go further.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say something about this matter because some grey issues are involved here. Senator Spindler, for whom I have a great deal of admiration, particularly in the field of civil liberties, has said it is always difficult for an individual to get a fair hearing. The inference in that is that our court system is loaded against those who do not have as much money as those to whom they are opposed in the court. Whether judges can adjust that is a matter of opinion. In my view, the courts struggle and, in most cases, succeed in seeing that justice is done. Nevertheless, if it is the position of those who want this to go ahead that justice is not done in the courts of Australia, so be it. But it is certainly not an inference that I want to be associated with.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler has said that this will take only a few hours. But what it must be, in effect, is an appeal from the decision that the courts have made. No matter how you try to look at it in any other way, that is it. The Legal and Constitutional References Committee has to inquire into whether an independent inquiry is justified into the conduct of the Commonwealth's actions in relation to Ryker (Faulkner) v. the Commonwealth and Flint and, in particular, the reasons for the severe limitations imposed on the management of Mrs Faulkner's case. I would have thought that a quite nasty reflection upon the counsel appearing for Mrs Faulkner.

I do not know how the counsel conducted that case. I do not know who the counsel was. But it was certainly conducted in a place where privilege is often misused. It is a very interesting suggestion that somehow her case was not conducted properly. I can think of nothing worse than somebody saying about me as counsel that I had placed severe limitations on the way I conducted my client's case.

In any event, if the Senate is so minded as to cast those sorts of aspersions on the very terms of the motion on Mrs Faulkner's counsel, so be it. All I can say is that it might have been at least reasonable to hear what her counsel and her lawyers had to say before we brought this sort of motion into this chamber. I would have thought it would be a matter of fairness that a professional person would have been given some warning, and perhaps he was, before that sort of imputation was put upon him or her—I am not sure of the sex of the counsel or the solicitor instructing the counsel.

I would have thought it to be—to use the most mild word—a most ungenerous approach to the lawyers. Maybe I am not taking that properly. Perhaps that particular section is referring to the severe limitations on the judge. If that is so, again it seems to be a most nasty and unhappy aspersion on the justice who was listening to the cases, Mr Justice Allen. In any event, the Senate seems intent upon pursuing that course. I suppose there is not much that we on this side of the chamber can do about that.

We have to look at the evidence of the trial. I think Senator Bolkus said this trial took some considerable time. So the Legal and Constitutional References Committee has to look to see whether an independent inquiry is justified into the conduct of the Commonwealth's actions in relation to the case, and in particular to the evidence of the trial. That will involve looking at all the evidence that was put before the trial. We will have no assistance, as I take it, from counsel. We will be getting, as I understand, the views of one side and then making a decision which is very properly a decision that should be made in an appeal court.

Again, if the Senate is so disposed to ignoring and setting aside what I call a very good system in Australia of original hearings and a whole series of appeals to the High Court, and if it is so disposed to setting up an inquiry as to whether an inquiry should be held, so be it. I certainly see all sorts of problems with this.

The committee then has to suggest whether an independent inquiry can be set up. At least one of the litigants in this case was unhappy with the independent inquiry that has already been held into this matter by the courts. This is an aspersion on the Supreme Court of New South Wales, as I understand it.

What evidence is there that any independent inquiry we set up is going to satisfy those particular litigants? How long will it take us to look at all the evidence of this trial to see whether or not some part of it was not fair? Are we as senators better placed than the courts themselves to decide what is fair and what is not fair? Unless we have a vigorous inquiry into this matter through adversarial means, inquisitorial means or both, how can we say we are going to be in a better position than the courts?

Another thing I do not like about this procedure is this: many people have difficulties in the courts and feel that they do not receive justice. Is the process going to be established whereby if you lobby people in this chamber you can go behind the judicial system—that is what is happening here—and get an inquiry? What about all the other people who are disappointed and who say they get unfair hearings when further evidence arises later on? Why should they be excluded from this process? Why should these particular people—I do not know who they are—be blessed over everyone else? Why do other people have to go through the judicial system to get results when these people can lobby so successfully? More than half the Senate is now going to vote for a process that other people in the same or a worse position cannot achieve.

What about the people who have been gaoled? What about the people who have received bad results from the perjured and false evidence from the police in New South Wales? Why are we not doing something about them? The instant case is a civil case, but for some strange reason we are going to enter into the field of the judicial system, extrapolate one case, and say, `We are really doing justice.' The only connection that this matter has with the Senate is that one of the litigants was the Commonwealth and the other was Flint.

When the Commonwealth is a litigant does it have to be treated differently in the courts? Does that mean that the courts are not going to administer fair and equal justice? Does it mean that the courts are going to administer one sort of justice for BHP and all the other big companies and some other justice for the Commonwealth? Are we going to say that there is equal justice for all?

I will not persist because clearly the numbers are against us on this side of the chamber. I was pleased to hear Senator Bolkus's contribution in opposition to this proposition. This measure is going to produce the problems I have outlined.

I have great pride in the committee system in this place. Over the years the Clerk has worked quite magnificently for the committee system. This action throws an awful strain on the system. In this situation people's reputations are being put on the line and their credibility is tested. The members of the committee might have quite different views about the evidence put before them. The committee will, in effect, become something of an appellate court.

This action is really asking for leave to appeal to another body outside the judicial system about a case that has already been decided within the judicial system. I do not believe that type of exercise is good for the committee system in this chamber. We should be looking at such issues as drought. Senator Ferguson has conducted inquiries which I believe should be the business of these committees. But in any event, it is no good rabbiting on. I have indicated my attitude to this and, in those circumstances, I will, sadly, take my seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat saddened today, too. We heard a lot yesterday in relation to the fact that justice must not only be done but be seen to be done. I do not think it does Attorney-General's any benefits not to investigate properly any claims that there might have been problems involved with the handling of a case by the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: I am very saddened to hear Senator Bolkus, on behalf of the government, suggesting that the character of a person should be important in deciding whether or not we are careful or particularly careful as to the actions of the Commonwealth in dealing with that person. If we are talking about characters and credibility here, I am horrified to hear a minister getting up and suggesting that the character of a person should determine whether or not we look into whether the Commonwealth has acted correctly. Does that mean somehow that justice is more important for nice people than it is for people who might not be as likeable? I do not know, but I would be horrified if that were the basis upon which we are acting.

They are the reasons we are acting today. It is not necessarily about what happened back in 1964—there are aspects of that, of course; it is about the actions of the Commonwealth and it is about protecting the system. It is about the democratic process as well, because this is the only body which can bring those kinds of issues to public notice if there are no other means to do it.

As Senator Cooney has suggested, if there are instances where there might be prima facie evidence that there has on any other occasion been a case where the Commonwealth has worked or possibly might have worked in an unjust way, then yes, this is the place where those issues ought to be dealt with. That is why we are asking for support—not because we think we would like to spend all our time looking at these issues, but because there is nowhere else for this kind of issue finally to be dealt with.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Margetts's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 24 August, on motion by Senator Spindler:
That the following matters be referred to the Economics References Committee for inquiry and report on or before 30 January 1996—
(1)The extent to which `outworking' or other subcontracting methods are used in the Australian garment industry.

(2)The extent to which garment industry practices or contract provisions related to delivery times, quality standards, piecework rates and related matters, impose working conditions on outworkers and their families which do not meet standards of fairness and equity which the community expects to prevail in the labour market, with particular reference to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the adequacy of piecework rates of pay and, in particular, whether these rates adequately cover:
(i)minimum award rates of pay, and
(ii)holiday and other conditions and entitlements;
(b)the delivery times required for particular orders;
(c)the effect on the work-safety and the well-being generally of outworkers and their families;
(d)the proportion of labour costs contained in the firms' finished articles at wholesale and retail level, compared with on-site manufacturing costs;
(e)the extent to which the current system promotes the employment of children under 15, the conditions under which they are employed, and the effect on their school attendance and general well-being;
(f)the extent to which the current system brings about abuses of social security and taxation laws; and
(g)any other matter which in the opinion of the committee is relevant to the issues listed above.

PARA.TAB: (3)Steps which could be taken to address any deficiencies identified in paragraph (2), in particular, the conditions which prevent outworkers accessing standards of fairness and equity in the labour market and the action which needs to be taken to address contracting policies and procedures between principal companies, retailers and subcontractors.
(4)Implications for government adoption of relevant International Labour Organisation conventions and recommendations on outworking, once these are finalised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend the motion standing in my name.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I amend the motion in the terms circulated in the chamber. The motion now reads:

PARA.TAB: (1)the extent to which `outworking' and other subcontracting methods used in the Australian garment industry impose working conditions on outworkers and their families which do not meet accepted standards of fairness and equity, particularly with regard to:

TAB.TAB: (a)all aspects of remuneration, including piecework rates, hours of work, leave entitlements and training, as well as comparison with conditions that apply to on site garment makers;
(b)all aspects of working conditions and their occupational health and safety implications, including delivery times for orders;
(c)the extent to which children aged under 15 are involved in outworking and the effect this may have on their education, health and general well-being;

(d)the extent to which aspects of outworking may result in a breach of any laws, either by the employer or the outworker and their family, particularly in relation to employment conditions and the proper reporting of payments made or received for work completed;

(e)contract policies and procedures between retailers, subcontractors and outworkers and whether these practices run contrary to any international conventions, for example the International Labour Organisation; and

PARA.TAB: (2)steps which could be taken to address any deficiencies identified in paragraph (1) and any other matter which, in the opinion of the committee, is relevant to the issue of whether outworkers and their families are exploited by existing conditions of employment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government supports this motion, which is to refer the matter of outworkers in the clothing industry to an inquiry of the Senate Economics References Committee. There is notorious exploitation principally of migrant outworkers who often do not have a facility in English, who work under a naked light globe in a back room in suburban Melbourne or Sydney more often that not and who are paid usury wages. The purpose of this motion is to refer an inquiry into that type of exploitation to the committee, and the government supports it.

PARA.TAB: The government supports the referral for a number of reasons. Obviously we are opposed to that type of exploitation which falls outside of the reach of the industrial relations system in this country and, therefore, should be properly addressed. Secondly, there are a number of employers in this industry who are respectable and honest employers. While the issue of outworkers remains ill-defined as to who are the culprits, the honest employers get labelled as bad employers while the bad employers tend to get off scot-free. This inquiry will identify who are the baddies and who are the goodies, exonerate the goodies and condemn the baddies. That is an appropriate thing to be done in the public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was somewhat surprised to hear Minister Cook talk about the outcome of the inquiry before we have had it. Last Thursday, when Senator Spindler raised this matter in the Senate, both Senator Childs as deputy chair and I as chair of the Senate Economics References Committee indicated that we would oppose the motion put forward by Senator Spindler. I want to make it quite clear that our opposition to that motion was purely the procedure that had taken place for the raising of the matter in the Senate. Senator Spindler, as a full member of the economics committee, had not raised the matter at a committee meeting where it could have had proper discussion by all members of the committee. In that way there could have been some input from all members of the committee into the devising of the terms of reference. That consultation has taken place this week with Senator Spindler, Senator Childs and me and then later at a full committee meeting.

PARA.TAB: We were never opposed to the concept of the inquiry because we believe it to be a very important issue. As the minister has said on behalf of the government, and as other coalition members have said, we have always thought it an important issue and, certainly, one worth inquiring into. What we were opposed to at that stage was the procedure that had been followed whereby the matter was raised in the Senate before it had been properly discussed by our committee.

I think you will remember, Mr Acting Deputy President, both Senator Childs and I said at that earlier stage that, if the matter was adjourned, it could then be discussed by the committee. So we have come up with revised terms of reference which I think cover all the aspects Senator Spindler wants to raise in that inquiry, and I think, probably through the input of six or seven people on the committee, we have come up with something that is acceptable to everybody.

The other thing I would like to highlight with regard to the committee, and this also applies to other committees, is that committees themselves at some stage have to have some control over their agenda, the amount of work before the committee and the amount of work put onto the secretariat when there is more than one inquiry proceeding at once. Let me say that the last three references to the economics committee have all been raised in this place before they have gone to the Senate committee for discussion. It just so happens that the last three references have been raised by the Democrats. This has meant that the work the committee wants to do—whether it is work that government members of the committee want to do, references they may want to bring forward, or references coalition members may wish to bring forward—has all been superseded.

I must admit that Senator Spindler did speak to me privately about this at the end of June, but we, both government and coalition members of the committee, have not had an opportunity to discuss it. There are areas that members have an interest in and that they would like to develop references on themselves, but in each case they have not been able to do so because of matters raised in the Senate without consultation with the committee as a whole which have been forced upon the committee.

Let me also say that, in the new terms of reference devised following committee discussion, there is purposely no reporting date in this new, amended motion. That is due to the fact that we have had a reference with regard to telecommunications towards the year 2000—this is the last reference that was generated from within the committee—which we have been hearing for some 18 months. It has had to be pushed aside for other references which have needed urgent inquiry. Although they have been important references, I concede that, unless the committee has some control over its agenda, the good work done by committees in the past will be in danger of losing some significance. I know that applies not only to our committee. It can be said, because of the change in the nature of committees, that some references have been generated in the same way as Senator Spindler has brought this matter forward.

In closing, let me say that I certainly support this reference. I think it is a very important one, and there are lots of matters that we need to look into. I anxiously await the evidence that might come before the committee. I certainly will not pre-judge what might happen at the committee because we may find out lots of things we now do not know about. The committee is unanimous in its decision that this reference should now go forward in its amended form.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly. I cannot refrain from responding to Senator Ferguson's remarks. I am really delighted that agreement has been reached, and I certainly do not oppose the capacity to cooperate between committees and people who raise references. I also acknowledge that committees work very hard, and that they have a great deal of difficulty with their timetables and with addressing references. I must say, though, I was disturbed by the inference that committees are entitled to object to references coming from the Senate—not because of their content or appropriateness, but as a matter of process or procedure—
—When the member is a full member of the committee.

—I agree, but I do not think that means that the Senate should then be used as a place for disciplining a member of the committee who chooses to come to the Senate with a reference rather than addressing the committee as a whole. I do not want to expand on it but we need to remember that the comments Senator Ferguson made about matters raised in this place and forced on the committee, pushed on the committee, imply that committees are meant to be served by the Senate rather than serving the Senate.

PARA.TAB: We should be extremely grateful for the work that committees do to serve the Senate. We must remember that committees have been set up to serve and assist the processes of the Senate. To reject a reference because it has not first been discussed with the committee is a precedent I do not think any of us would want to see brought in because it violates the principle of the democracy of the Senate being able to set its own terms and references. I do not, therefore, object to what has happened here. It is a good example of talking through the problems and working out something with which all members are more pleased.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to express my appreciation in the first instance for the support that the minister has expressed and that Senator Ferguson as the chairman of the committee has expressed on behalf of the opposition for this reference. I also thank Senator Chamarette for her comments. I am glad that the discussions we have been able to have in the last week, both outside and within the committee, have resulted in terms of reference which in substance do not differ from the terms of reference I put forward last Thursday, as Senator Ferguson has said. I must admit that just occasionally I am inclined to pay a little more attention to substance than to technical procedures. So I am gratified that we have finished up with the same substance, the same motion, that I moved last Thursday.

PARA.TAB: This is an important reference. It arises from a report by the TCF union into the practice of outworking in the garment industry both in Melbourne and in Sydney. It is an area of our industrial work that we must pay some attention to. We are rightly critical of the working conditions that obtain in some of the countries which are our trading partners in this region and elsewhere. There is some evidence that in our own backyard—and I use that term advisedly—working conditions are imposed on people that are anything but fair and just. We must ensure that the conditions for which we have fought for so long in this country are protected. In particular, I have an interest in children under 15 who are being exploited in various industrial contexts overseas. In this case there is some evidence that this may happen in Australia as well.

I am aware of the workload of the committee. I am therefore not objecting to the fact that we do not have—in a fairly unprecedented way, although I know there have been some previous occasions—a reporting date but I know the workload of the committee. I have been assured that everything will be done to expedite the work on this reference. We will place advertisements shortly. I understand that we will seek submissions to reach us by the middle of December and hope to have some public inquiry dates available to us in January. So, all in all, I am delighted that the motion we have finished up with is in substance the same as the one I moved last Thursday and that the procedural requirements the committee wishes to have followed have now been complied with. I thank the Senate for its support for this important motion.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1994MIGRATION AGENTS REGISTRATION (APPLICATION) LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1994MIGRATION AGENTS REGISTRATION (RENEWAL) LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1994IMMIGRATION (EDUCATION) CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 30 August, on motion by Senator Schacht:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was adjourned yesterday I had finished dealing with one of the four main elements of the bills before us, namely, the restructuring of the Refugee Review Tribunal. The second main element relates to the provision in the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) for the Remuneration Tribunal to determine the remuneration of all members of the Immigration Review Tribunal and the Refugee Review Tribunal. Currently, only the principal members' remuneration is determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. Other members' remuneration details are prescribed by the Migration Act, at SES band 1 levels for full-time members and amounts determined by the minister in writing for part-time members.

PARA.TAB: The proposal contained in the bill is to bring the IRT and RRT into line with the arrangements applicable to similar tribunals such as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the Veterans Review Board. Giving the Remuneration Tribunal the responsibility to set remuneration because it is in line with other tribunals is, therefore, not objectionable in itself, and the coalition supports that.

The provision in the bill to deny the Remuneration Tribunal the ability to lower the remuneration for members appointed before 1 July 1995 is, however, at odds with the spirit and purpose of the transfer of the determination of the terms and conditions to an independent assessment body. There is no justification, in our view, for prohibiting the Remuneration Tribunal lowering remuneration if it deems that appropriate, especially when most appointments were made last year for a period of five years and many of those appointments, as we have debated on other occasions in the Senate, were obviously political appointments whereby the minister, Senator Bolkus, was favouring his political mates.

With the provision left intact, if the bill goes through unamended, the Remuneration Tribunal effectively only has the power to grant remuneration increases.
