The government's justification for this no-downward provision is that it maintains equity between future members, if they get paid more, and also fulfils employment and remuneration conditions entered into by those people at the time of their employment. But the government's position is inherently inconsistent. On the one hand, it talks about preserving conditions applicable at the commencement of the employment. If it wanted to do this, it would make the new Remuneration Tribunal provisions only applicable to new appointments and exempt old ones, who would continue under their existing arrangements.

On the other hand, it talks about equity between all members, new and old, but will not allow the Remuneration Tribunal to properly implement this by reducing remunerations where it is determined to be appropriate. It may be that the Remuneration Tribunal would never want to reduce terms and conditions of employment. Nevertheless, to prevent it doing so in relation to certain of those appointments is, in our view, inconsistent.

The coalition does not believe that the government can have it both ways. We come down on the side of equity, with all members being treated equally under the proposed arrangements. On behalf of the coalition I have had circulated an amendment which seeks to remove clauses 6 and 7 of the bill. They deny the Remuneration Tribunal the ability to lower remuneration for existing IRT or RRT members. I hope the Senate will give serious consideration to supporting that proposed amendment.

The third issue involved in the bills relates to investment-linked visa cancellation provisions. The amendment to provisions for the cancellation of certain business skills visas contained in the bill follows last year's recommendations by the Business Skills Advisory Panel, better known as the Deveson committee. In particular, it incudes special cancellation procedures for the new investment-linked class of visa.

The proposed cancellation provisions, as outlined in the government's explanatory memorandum, allow the minister to cancel an investment-linked visa `where the minister is satisfied that the person who held the designated investment relevant to the grant of the visa has or have ceased, for any reason, to hold that investment within three years of the investment being made'.

The provisions provide for notification and also the cancellation of related family members visas. There is also an amendment to make the established business in Australia visa subject to normal visa cancellation provisions rather than under the business skills provisions, which provide for Administrative Appeals Tribunal appeal.

The proposed visa cancellation arrangements for investment-linked and other special business skills visas, as recommended by the Deveson committee, are, the coalition believes, a balance between the need for migrant investors to have a high degree of visa security and the minister to be able to revoke the visa in the event of a failure to fully comply with its conditions. That approach is consistent with that already applicable to other business skills visas.

I do want to put the government on notice, however, that the coalition will be very closely scrutinising the new investor-linked visa class. We will be watching closely to ensure that this does not become another of those business migration schemes of the late 1980s, which, sadly, were so extensively rorted.

The granting of additional statutory entitlements to applicants engaging the Immigration Review Tribunal has been a controversial aspect of this bill. The measures proposed in the bill include: the right to appear before the IRT where a hearing occurs; the right to assistance while appearing; the right to an interpreter; and the right to material submitted to the IRT. These measures are in accordance with the recommendations made in December 1992 by the Committee for the Review of the System for Review of Migration Decisions—a dreadful name for a committee—otherwise known as the Macphee committee after its Chairman, Ian Macphee.

The new arrangements applying to applicants before the Immigration Review Tribunal are, according to the minister and his department, all intended to give the applicant greater rights and opportunities at hearings. In line with the Macphee committee recommendations, they are intended to enhance the non-adversarial nature of the IRT. They overcome several concerns and shortcomings that have been expressed about the IRT's present operations. Most of the measures simply represent a codification of current arrangements following a Federal Court decision last year—that was in the case that has become known as the Tordo case.

The major exception is the restriction on legal representation. This move has created a great deal of controversy, especially among legal groups, and it was very much the focus of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee's consideration of this bill a few months ago. In that committee hearing, my colleagues Senators Ellison and Abetz, on behalf of the coalition, submitted a dissenting report which, very properly, drew to attention the major concerns the coalition has. The major concern was that we were not convinced that allowing lawyers to address the tribunal would necessarily make it adversarial. As I understand it, that was the essential thrust. But Senator Abetz, who I think is speaking later in this debate, may wish to elaborate on that.

The coalition shares the concerns of Senator Abetz and Senator Ellison, although on balance we will not be opposing the government's provisions in the bill but we will be watching it very closely. It is an on balance decision and we nevertheless put the government and the IRT on notice that we will be closely scrutinising its operations under these new arrangements. If evidence substantiates that applicants are being unfairly dealt with by the IRT due to insufficient recourse to assistance, then we will certainly review our stance on this matter. But, at this stage, overall the coalition will be supporting the bills before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is cognately debating the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1994, together with the Migration Agents Registration (Renewal) Levy Bill, the Migration Agents Registration (Application) Levy Bill and the Immigration (Education) Charge Amendment Bill.

PARA.TAB: The first bill, the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1994: firstly, provides for the Remuneration Tribunal to determine the remuneration of members of the IRT and the Refugee Review Tribunal; secondly, enables the minister to cancel investment linked visas; thirdly, provides that people appearing before the immigration tribunal cannot, unless there are exceptional circumstances, present arguments to or address the tribunal; and, fourthly, provides that certain information must not be disclosed to an applicant to the IRT if the minister has certified in writing that it would be contrary to the public interest to do so.

Let me deal first of all with the question of remuneration of tribunal members. Clauses 7 and 8 of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) ensure that the current remuneration of existing members of the Immigration Review Tribunal and the Refugee Review Tribunal will not be reduced when the Remuneration Tribunal gains authority to determine the remuneration of members of the two tribunals.

We understand, and we have heard from Senator Short, that the opposition is voting against these provisions because it believes that you either allow the Remuneration Tribunal to determine the salary and conditions of members or you do not; there should be no half-measures. In turn, we heard from the government in its second reading speech that it would be akin to a breach of contract to allow a possible reduction in the salary and conditions of members.
The Democrats have considered both arguments and, on balance, believe that the government's reasoning is more convincing. On that basis, we will not be supporting the opposition's amendments.

The next part of the bill allows the minister to cancel an investment linked visa where the minister is satisfied that the person ceased to hold the investment within three years of it being made. This initiative stems from a review process that found people were rorting the system by transferring funds for a short period only—in fact, a period only long enough to, in effect, buy themselves a passport. The Democrats welcome this particular measure.
I now come to what is probably the most contentious aspect of this bill, that advisers of people appearing before the tribunal may not directly address the tribunal or cross-examine witnesses.

The bill provides that, while an applicant before the Immigration Review Tribunal is entitled to have another person present to assist him or her, that assistant however is not entitled to either present arguments to the tribunal, address the tribunal except in exceptional circumstances, or examine or cross-examine any person appearing before the tribunal to give evidence.

Presently, it is up to the discretion of a member of the IRT whether a representative of the person appearing before the tribunal may in fact address the tribunal. We have had Tordo's case where it was stated that the tribunal shall, in carrying out its functions, pursue the objective of providing a mechanism of review that is fair, just, economical, informal and quick. However, Tordo's case could be interpreted as saying that a representative of a person appearing before the IRT has an absolute right to address the tribunal and to cross-examine witnesses.

It is my understanding that the government believes, in view of its interpretation of Tordo's case, that it is necessary to introduce these particular amendments. The amendments attempt to change this situation by removing the members' discretion and by providing that a person is not entitled to address the tribunal unless there are exceptional circumstances—for example, where the applicant is disabled or mentally ill. That seems to me to be a fairly narrow interpretation of exceptional circumstances.

Essentially, the government has introduced a mechanism which allows comments from advisers to be delivered, but insists that these comments will have to be delivered by the applicant rather than by the advisers. Where the concepts are complex, or where the language skills of the applicant are poor, the process could be seriously delayed. The case that is being made out on behalf of the applicant before the tribunal could be seriously disadvantaged.

It seems to the Democrats that the skills of advisers are most useful in casting light on issues. We believe that an applicant or a person without the equivalent experience might not in fact be able to do this. As suggested by the Law Council of Australia, this presently occurs and is of significant assistance to the tribunal. The premise upon which this aspect of the bill appears to be founded is, following Tordo's case, that members of the tribunal will be obliged to allow a representative to address the tribunal even where they consider it to be inappropriate. That is only one interpretation of Tordo's case. Even if that is correct, it could have been achieved with an amendment which has a much more limited effect and which restores the discretion of the tribunal.

I have actually visited the IRT office in Melbourne, examined its operation and discussed the issue at some length with IRT members. I have formed the view that IRT members are perfectly capable of appropriately exercising the discretion they have had so far. Therefore, in the Democrats' view, all the government needed to do to respond to Tordo's case was to simply restore that discretion and clarify that Tordo's case does not throw out the baby with the bath water.

However, the government has chosen to go the whole hog, as it were. I believe that the amendments deny people a fundamental right, particularly when questions of liberty are at issue. The need for people to be granted full access to representation is made all the more important by the fact that the IRT has a role in determining such issues when it assesses whether bridging visas should be granted. They are similar in nature to bail applications, given that they can result in a successful applicant being released from detention. Not allowing such representation in these circumstances is indefensible.

I am rather disappointed that the coalition parties have decided to go along with the government's amendments and not take account of that very basic legal fact. I hope that even at this late stage they have a change of mind. I provided them with a copy of my amendments last night. I apologise for the lateness in providing the formal amendments. But the Democrats' position has always been on record. We have made it very clear that we will be moving amendments that will knock out the government's attempt to virtually exclude the discretion of IRT members to allow representatives to speak on behalf of applicants.

It seems to us that the government's amendments will disadvantage, in particular, an inarticulate or poorly educated applicant. They also present a backward step in the representation of people from such backgrounds, as argued by a witness before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, Mr David Bitel, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: Applicants before the IRT are generally among the least skilled members of the community dealing with bureaucratic and administrative matters. In addition, the legislation dealt with by the IRT is among the most complex and difficult of any affecting the everyday lives of ordinary people. To deny such people professional assistance in dealing with the tribunal is a contradiction of the government's fundamental commitment to the presence of access and equity for all members of society.

It seems to me that the government's fear that allowing such representation will necessarily make the tribunal an adversarial body is ill-founded. I believe that, apart from Tordo's case, there is absolutely no evidence that the discretion of IRT members in the past has been exercised to make it such. They have had that discretion for years, yet the exercise of that discretion has not resulted in making the IRT an adversarial body.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that we are dealing with a massive over-reaction by the government to one particular case. I would be ready to admit that, if we want to treat the tribunal as a non-adversarial forum, there may be some justification for restricting the possible flow-ons from Tordo's case. But I do not think it calls for this sledgehammer approach that we are using here.

There is another reason why these amendments should not proceed. The Administrative Review Council is at present conducting a major review of merit review tribunals, including the IRT. Why do we not wait until we have that review and then decide what measures are necessary? That report is expected to be handed down some time this year. It seems to me that the government could have waited until that report is made available.

Given that the council `considers that many of the issues dealt with in the bill fall within the scope of the council's report', intervention at this time would seem most untimely. As I have indicated, we will be moving amendments to knock out these items in the schedule to the bill.

I will now move to the non-disclosure provisions of the bill. The Democrats will also be opposing those items in the schedule which provide that certain information must not be disclosed to an applicant to the IRT if the minister has certified in writing that it would be contrary to the public interest to do so. The Democrats agree with the comments in the report on this bill by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. There is much to be said in providing the IRT with a discretion to provide the information to the applicant if the interests of justice outweigh the reasons stated by the minister.

It seems to us wrong that the minister should have this unfettered discretion. Accordingly, we believe that the bill should be amended to grant the IRT a discretion to provide the information to the applicant if the interests of justice outweigh the reasons for non-disclosure advanced by the minister. At this stage, we will simply be moving an amendment to take out these provisions which give the minister such unfettered discretion.

Finally, the bill proposes to amend the Immigration Education Act 1971 to provide for the automatic indexation of fees and charges. The amendments replace the current $250 maximum fee that may be charged in relation to English language courses with a fee that is going to be indexed at the beginning of each financial year. Given that the Democrats are opposed in principle to any increase in course fees for English language courses, we will also be voting against these particular provisions and the whole of the Immigration (Education) Charge Amendment Bill.

Once again, it is a question that goes to equity and access. We have seen statistics coming out at regular intervals which show that people of ethnic background have to struggle to keep their end up, as it were, in the job stakes and in education. It seems to us that providing the opportunity for newcomers to this country to receive English tuition should not have additional barriers placed in its way. As I said, I will be moving those amendments. Subject to those, the Democrats will be supporting the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate, I wish to address only the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1994. In addressing only that bill, I will restrict my comments to proposed sections 366A and 366D, which are basically designed to overturn the Tordo decision, or the Tordo case—a decision of His Honour Justice Keely.

PARA.TAB: That decision was brought down in 1993 and confirmed the procedures that had been adopted that the words `not entitled' meant that members of the tribunal had a discretion to allow an applicant's representative to address the tribunal and even to examine or cross-examine witnesses if this was required to produce a decision which was fair, just, economical, informal and quick. So, prior to the tribunal member deciding whether or not to allow cross-examination and representation to take place, the tribunal member had to exercise his or her mind as to whether or not it was fair, just, economical, informal and quick.

Let me say, I am somewhat disappointed that the opposition is not actually opposing this bill. On balance, we have decided to let it go through to the keeper and observe what happens in the future. From my own point of view, as expressed in the dissenting report which I co-signed with Senator Ellison, I am concerned that justice may not necessarily be done because it seems to me that, if a tribunal member comes to a decision that in the circumstances it would be fair, just, economical, informal and quick to allow cross-examination and legal representation to take place, surely justice demands that that be allowed. Unfortunately, this legislation completely denies that, except in very narrow circumstances such as if the person suffers from mental illness or is completely incapable of representing himself or herself.

Justice Keely, in the decision of Tordo, considered how the tribunal was to conduct its inquiries. Section 123 of the Migration Act required that the tribunal shall, in carrying out its functions under the act, pursue the objective of providing a mechanism of review that is fair, just, economical, informal and quick. Section 132 provided that a person appearing before the tribunal to give evidence was not entitled to be represented by any other person or to examine or cross-examine any other person appearing before the tribunal.

So anybody before the tribunal did not have the right to cross-examine. It was only allowed if they were able to get over the threshold of convincing the tribunal member that it was fair, just, economical, informal and quick in the circumstances to allow that to take place.

When somebody's liberty or future is at stake I believe it is vitally important that, if the tribunal member so determines, legal representation be allowed. It seems very strange to me that if I am charged with going through an orange light or exceeding the speed limit by 10 kilometres per hour, as of right in this country I am entitled to legal representation to cross-examine all the police witnesses and to fight the case tooth and nail should I so desire. I would have thought that a person's rights under the Migration Act may well be a lot more important than the question of whether or not I ran foul of an orange light or whether I exceeded the speed limit by a small amount.

The good book in Proverbs 18:17 tells us that the first to present his case seems right until another comes forward and questions him. That is the very basis of the right to cross-examination in our legal system: one side always sounds very, very good until the other side questions the person giving the evidence, questions the procedures adopted and questions the rationale under which a certain decision was taken. There are people in the community who are skilled advocates.

Whilst I can possibly understand why one would not necessarily wish legal representation in each and every case, I would have thought that, if the tribunal member came to a determination that the circumstances of a particular case required legal representation to ensure justice and fairness, surely it ought to be allowed. If the government says that these tribunal members are not fit and proper persons to exercise that discretion—because they do not really know how to exercise it—they should not have been appointed in the first place to make determinations about people's future under this legislation. In a roundabout way the government is passing a vote of no confidence in the tribunal members in saying, `We do not think you are fit and proper to determine whether or not the discretion that is afforded to you ought to be exercised by you, and therefore we will take that discretion away.'—except, as I said, in very restricted circumstances.

I am also very disappointed that when the matter came before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee we were told by the assistant secretary of the Legal Framework Branch that the tribunal would have some discretion in the implementation of the section. The majority report signed by Senator Cooney said on page 11 at paragraph 1.23:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Committee observes that the explanation does not take account of the requirement that the assistant is not entitled—
and I want to stress the words `not entitled'—
. . . to address the Tribunal unless the Tribunal is satisfied that there are exceptional circumstances. . . and the operation of proposed section 363A which apparently removes any discretion.
Senator Spindler, who preceded me in this debate, said:
It removes the discretion of the tribunal.
Ms Read said:
I think so, yes.

I always have great concern when governments—and, unfortunately, governments of all persuasions do this—seek to put in minimum penalties and maximum penalties and do all manner of things to try to restrict those people within the community who have to exercise, for want of a better term, a judicial mind and to try to administer some sort of system of justice.

PARA.TAB: If we remove the discretion of tribunals, really we are limiting the range in which tribunal members can operate and restricting their capacity to deliver justice in each and every individual case. Sure, if you take the broad-brush approach you might say, `Yes, it can be arguable,' but, at the end of the day, justice is not about the broad-brush approach; it is about each and every individual that comes before the tribunal, the court or whatever tribunal or body is to make a determination.

The views of the Law Council of Australia are fairly clear, as was the view of the Bar Association of New South Wales. I do not wish to take any more time of the Senate in this regard, other than to commend the dissenting report of Senator Ellison and myself, and also those parts of Senator Spindler's dissenting report which deal with that one issue I wanted to address today, because it is a matter which is close to my heart. I am genuinely concerned about the way governments—might I add, of all persuasions, in all jurisdictions—seem to be moving in restricting the discretions being given to tribunals and other bodies that are charged with delivering justice and fair outcomes for individual citizens in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1994, as the second reading speech by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) pointed out, seeks to make a number of amendments to the Migration Act and to other legislation. There have already been very good comments on, and explanations of, the bill from my colleagues in the chamber, so I will just mention the response of the Greens in relation to some of those. I will start with that part of the bill which, in my opinion, contains the most fundamental aspect of all the measures before us, and it is the one that Senator Abetz has been referring to.

PARA.TAB: The bill seeks to limit the powers of the Immigration Review Tribunal in its ability to set its own guidelines for the conduct of hearings. It seeks to alter section 363 of the Migration Act by stating that, if a person is not entitled to do something, then the tribunal does not have the power to permit the person to do that thing. It will remove the tribunal's power to grant a person leave to be represented.

This amendment is the result of Justice Keely's ruling that the act, while it does not entitle a person to be represented at a tribunal hearing, does not prevent the tribunal from allowing representation. Justice Keely found that the tribunal has wide powers to decide what form of hearing would provide a fair, just, economical, informal and quick review of a case.

If we look at section 353(1) of the act, we find that the tribunal was set up to provide fair, just, economical, informal and quick review of immigration decisions. If I recall rightly, at the time I was very concerned about some of those terms which may well provide contradictions in terms. We cannot always find justice from the quickest measures; nor can we always find the fairest means through informal means.

Putting that aside, I cannot help but wonder how the government's aim of hampering the tribunal will assist in ensuring fair and just decision making. Perhaps I am taking too negative a view of the government's motives here, but we are becoming too accustomed to dealing with migration or refugee legislation which is drafted in response to court decisions which the government does not like. In almost every case, the legislation is aimed at limiting the rights of people seeking review of decisions made by government departments. I would have felt more easy if we had been making a change to the law to make explicit that the tribunal should be able to give that leave or allow people to have that leave.

In this particular case, the government's motives must be even further questioned when we note that this restrictive change is not mentioned in the outline of the explanatory memorandum to the bill. Indeed, the changes to the Immigration Review Tribunal's functions are said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to provide the applicant with additional entitlements in relation to the presentation of, and access to, material before the Tribunal.
While we cannot argue that such provisions exist, the provision to exclude any possibility of representation before the tribunal is conveniently not mentioned.

PARA.TAB: The Greens will move an amendment to this provision in the committee stage. We just seek to drop the clause from the bill. I express my regret at already hearing in the chamber that, on balance—which is a very useful phrase at the moment—the opposition will not be supporting that amendment. I acknowledge the comments made by Senator Abetz, and also referred to in Senator Short's remarks, that it is not a consensus position of the opposition. I could wish that conscience voting would allow greater support for the amendment that I will put and that I understand is included in a range of amendments which will be put by Senator Spindler for the Democrats.

Other matters in the bill which need to be mentioned at this point include the change whereby the Remuneration Tribunal will be empowered to determine the remuneration of members of the Immigration Review Tribunal and of the Refugee Review Tribunal. I understand that the opposition is opposing two clauses which set certain conditions in this area. I can only regard the opposition's stance on clauses 6 and 7 as part of an economic world view which says that, if a salary can be indexed, it must be able to be indexed downwards as well as upwards. It may well be that certain economic circumstances could arise in which such a course of action could suggest itself. However, these provisions apply only to current members, who will not be members forever.

The government's reasoning here seems simple enough: that if, by chance, the Remuneration Tribunal's first determination should set the salary for members of the IRT and RRT at a level lower than that at which the current members are appointed, then they should not be penalised. After all, they have accepted appointment to important positions within the community on terms and conditions put to them in good faith and they have accepted them in good faith. Why should the government now be able to change the rules in an arbitrary fashion?

Furthermore, if the current members' remuneration is higher than that provided for in the first determination of the Remuneration Tribunal, then their remuneration will simply stand still until that which applies to later members catches up in future years. Perhaps the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) could reassure me on that point when the Senate moves into the committee stage. As a result of that, we will not be supporting the opposition's amendments.

At the end of the bill provision is made for the level of certain fees relating to education services to migrants to be indexed. This is in line with the government's desire to have such fees increased automatically over time, reflecting the increased costs of providing the services as measured by some broad economic indicators. Clearly, this is a government policy decision which covers vast areas of service delivery and is similar to the decision made by this government in the early part of its time in office to index such things as certain excise duties and the like.

A great deal of political heat has been taken out of the government's budget processes as a result. It can be seen as a logical and worthwhile move towards predictability for the community. We had not intended to oppose it in this case, at least in part because of the wider context in which the change is being made. But we will listen to Senator Spindler's comments and arguments in relation to this. The Greens intend, in spite of reservations, to support this bill but we certainly wish that our amendment to the schedule in relation to item 25 will gain some support and some reconsideration from the government, as the opposition seems to have made its stand already.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think most of the points raised in the debate so far go to particular aspects of the bill. In the interests of saving time, it might be best if we do not have a long response from me at this stage. For instance, I think Senator Abetz put forward both sides of the argument with respect to the point that he was pursuing. The government comes down on the one side; he comes down on the other. So there are points like that, but I think they could probably be addressed as we go along in the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall put the first three bills on the Notice Paper together—Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1994, Migration Agents Registration (Application) Levy Amendment Bill 1994 and Migration Agents Registration (Renewal) Levy Amendment Bill 1994. I will put the remaining bill separately. The question is that the bills be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Immigration (Education) Charge Amendment Bill 1994 be read a second time.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a statement in relation to these bills. I draw to the attention of the committee the fact that two of these bills, the Migration Agents Registration (Application) Levy Amendment Bill 1994 and the Migration Agents Registration (Renewal) Levy Amendment Bill 1994, provide for increases in the charges which may be levied under the principal acts. Those acts impose taxes subject to a ceiling, and the bills allow increases in the ceilings. The government is treating the bills as bills not imposing taxation and is moving amendments to them.

PARA.TAB: This treatment of the bills appears to arise from the new interpretation adopted by the government during the consideration of taxation legislation in 1993 that a bill is not a bill imposing taxation within the meaning of the constitution unless it levies some new tax and that a bill which increases the amount of the tax is not a bill imposing taxation. The majority of the Senate, in effect, has taken a different view and would, on that view, treat these bills as bills imposing taxation and as therefore requiring requests rather than amendments. This has been drawn to the attention of the government's advisers, but it has been indicated that the government's amendments are still being moved in the form of amendments.

I make this statement so that the committee will be aware of this and, if it agrees to the amendments, this will not be regarded as setting a precedent. The question of the proper interpretation of the constitutional provision is under consideration by the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette wanted to move separately the amendment that she has described. But, as it hangs together with Democrat amendments 2, 3 and 4 in this area, I wonder whether I can simply acknowledge that the Greens are also moving that same amendment, and seek leave to move my amendments as a group.
—Is leave granted for the Democrat amendments to be moved together? I understood you were opposing item 25, which really is not an amendment—you are just voting against it.

—I was about to say that I think Senator Spindler realises that neither my amendment, nor perhaps his, will gain support in the Senate. I was hopeful that it would be possible to look at omitting item 25, and that that might actually be something which could gain support in the Senate. Having it included in the other items—while I support them—that Senator Spindler's amendment raises might exclude people from the option of simply dropping this new insertion into the act, which effectively deprives people of their legal representation simply by removing the power of the tribunal to grant it to them by leave.

PARA.TAB: I think it is a very serious matter, and I know there is a difference of views within the chamber about that. So I ask the government to explain what its motivation is in this regard, because it comes across as highly restrictive of peoples' civil rights; also, it would set a precedent by restricting a tribunal in the powers and the discretion that it should legitimately exercise so as to ensure that the aims of the act—stated there as fair, just, economical and informal, et cetera—can be carried out properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have stated in my speech during the second reading debate, this is an amazing amendment by the government, saying to members of the tribunal, `You may not make certain decisions except in exceptional circumstances.' I ask the minister to explain. Although the term `exceptional circumstances' is mentioned in the bill a little further down, this is really the point at which, even at this stage, the government could remedy this extraordinary provision that is being imposed which removes the discretion of the tribunal that has been appointed to deal with applicants who in some cases may simply not be able to represent themselves properly. If the government were prepared to give a very wide definition to `exceptional circumstances' that may perhaps go towards ameliorating some of the still negative effects that this amendment will have. As it stands the Democrats will certainly oppose item 25.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler will anticipate that I cannot give him that assurance. Exceptional circumstances have been mentioned, for instance, in my second reading speech—and we are talking about exceptional circumstances. I think the opposition agreed with us in respect of this. I recognise once again that Senator Abetz has a different perspective. Our proposal, our structure, is such that it does not embrace the adversarial approach before the IRT. As a consequence, we limit exceptional circumstances to situations where there are physical or intellectual disabilities or psychiatric conditions, for instance. But we do stick to that approach. It has at its roots the profile that we have of an IRT, which is one that does not work on the adversarial approach. So we do have a difference in starting points in a sense. We have a difference at least on this issue, which I am sorry we cannot resolve.

—I ask the minister why the government is so strongly of the view that just because you involve the right to representation it would necessarily make it adversarial. I am not sure that anything has been put forward by the minister to substantiate that assertion. Secondly, I ask the minister to exercise his mind as to what is the most important thing from the government's point of view. Is it to at all costs ensure that it is non-adversarial or is it more concerned about ensuring those parts of the legislation which require fairness, justice and those sorts of factors?

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that a government that allegedly prides itself on social justice and things of that nature would have more concern about effecting a fair and just outcome as opposed to just saying, `Well, we don't like the adversarial system so we will not have it' even if it means that fairness and justice, which ought to be the top priority, cannot be the result. I would like to hear the minister explain why the government is so concerned that it will turn into an adversarial system, what proof he has of that and, even if it were to, what is more important—the fairness and justice of the situation or for some reason not having any adversarial situation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I could go through this at length and traverse issues which have been traversed a number of times in this place and score political points about Senator Abetz's part in this, but I will not do that. All I will say is that we are of the view that once you allow cross examination the system becomes adversarial. Without traversing the whole raft of issues involved in this, let me say to Senator Abetz that the whole structure was intended to be flexible and non-adversarial; one which would allow access to people without their needing to go to lawyers; and one in which the department would not find itself being represented by lawyers before the tribunal as well. As a consequence, it makes the system much more accessible to people who do not have the means to get legal assistance.

PARA.TAB: It is all part of the philosophy that we had in setting this up in the first place. It is all part of the philosophy which drove the review in this area, CROSROMD, which made recommendations which further strengthened the general, non-adversarial nature of the tribunal. The government has agreed to pick up recommendations 25 to 28 which go down that route. We can discuss this all you like, but let me place on the record the fact that the opposition is also of the view that the flexibility and access, which are the main features of the system as it now stands, are worthy of protection.
Question put:
That item 25 of schedule 1 stand as printed.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Schedule 1, page 7, item 26, proposed section 366A, omit the proposed section.
3.Schedule 1, page 8, item 26, proposed section 366B, omit the proposed section.
4.Schedule 1, page 8, item 26, proposed section 366D, omit the proposed section.

The three amendments taken together confirm that the tribunal has no power to allow representatives of people before the IRT to give evidence—unless there are exceptional circumstances—that people appearing before the tribunal are not entitled to be represented in this way, and that they have no right to examine or cross-examine witnesses before the tribunal. The issue is essentially the same as the one we discussed under item 25—that is, that people who are not capable of representing themselves efficiently and effectively should have the opportunity to ask an adviser or an assistant to address the tribunal to make a point clearly and cogently.

PARA.TAB: There are provisions for interpreters to be used but we are talking about the case where people are simply not well-versed in administrative procedures and require their case to be put. I believe that that is not within the tradition of Australia's administrative or legal systems. I know the government's motivation is to ensure that these proceedings do not become adversarial, but there is a long step between them becoming adversarial and for some arguments to be put by an adviser if the person herself or himself is unable to do so.
I do not propose to seek a division on these three amendments, but I seek leave to have my opposition on behalf of the Democrats recorded. That will save the time of the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Similarly, I do not want to take up time, but the Greens (WA) support the Democrats' amendments and would like that to be on the public record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Items 30, 32 and 33 are consequential on items 27 and 28. The amendments are intended to ensure that the minister does not have unfettered discretion to stop disclosure of information to people appearing before the IRT. We believe that, once again, this power of the minister should be balanced by a discretion of the tribunal, and these amendments are intended to achieve that. I understand that there is no significant support in the chamber.
—That's nice!

—There is no support for this from the two major parties in the chamber. In anticipation of the result, I seek again to have my dissent on behalf of the Democrats recorded in lieu of calling for a division.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Wednesday, 30 August 1995, of Dame Pattie Maie Menzies GBE, wife of Australia's longest-serving Prime Minister, the late Right Honourable Sir Robert Menzies, and herself a figure held in great affection by many in the Australian community for many decades and tenders its profound sympathy to her family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: Dame Pattie Menzies was a magnificent Australian and indeed a warm and joyous human being. She managed to combine often potentially conflicting roles—on the one hand as a politician's spouse and a loving parent of three children and, on the other, to maintain an active involvement in a variety of forms of public life and community service.

PARA.TAB: Throughout her long life she never shied away from responsibility—she was always prepared to put her resources and energy back into the community and the country which had given her so much. She came from a deeply political background. Indeed, her father, like her husband, was a member of both the Victorian and federal parliaments and a minister of the Crown.

She was enormously supportive of her husband's political career. The expression `behind every great man stands a great woman' is no longer particularly apposite in the current age, but the spirit that lies behind that proposition was never more apt than in her case. Everything that her husband did was discussed with her. She was there when the momentous decisions were made, such as his decision to transfer from state to federal politics.

She was not only his constant political companion but on many occasions his chauffeur and his political weathervane. At the same time, she not only managed to bringing up her family—and each of her children has gone on to great successes in life—but also maintained a very active and continuous involvement with a range of community institutions, particularly the Royal Children's Hospital in Melbourne, the Royal Women's Hospital in Melbourne and the Royal Melbourne Hospital.

Dame Pattie saw both family and community good as very worthwhile aspirations. Her life was devoted to the service of those close to her and those she believed had not been as fortunate as she had. She was therefore prepared on every occasion to make the necessary sacrifices. Those of us who were fortunate enough to see her in action at political functions can always remember the twinkle in her eye and the way in which she was able to make the strategic pause and capture the spirit of the audience. She was not a consummate orator, as undoubtedly was her husband, but nonetheless she was able to read the mood of a meeting. She was able to relate to people both publicly and privately. She was prepared to remain active throughout her long life.
Australia will be much the poorer for her passing. But I think we are all very grateful for the magnificent contribution that she made to this country.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is very pleased to join with the opposition in supporting this very appropriate condolence motion. Dame Pattie was a role model to a very great many Australian women over a long period of extremely distinguished public service. It is absolutely fair to say that she was held by the Australian people generally in great affection and esteem.

PARA.TAB: It is recognised that she did play a tremendously supportive role for all those years of marriage to her husband and was a significant influence on him in all sorts of ways. One of the best documented of those influences was the remarks she evidently made by chance to Robert Menzies in 1954. She is recorded as saying, `One hears a lot of talk about rates of pension and so on. But I believe that the greatest social need for old people is that they should have a place of their own to live in. Couldn't you think up some scheme under which the government could subsidise the building of proper accommodation.'

The immediate and positive outcome of that was the Aged Persons Homes Act, under which a Commonwealth subsidy was provided for institutional accommodation for the aged. Sir Robert Menzies is recorded as saying, I think accurately, that no other of his government's schemes was more widely welcomed by the public or gave that government and the community greater satisfaction. Someone who exercises that kind of very positive and helpful influence is to be much admired and much applauded.
I do not suppose that we could ever do much about her political loyalties, but Dame Pattie was a lady of great charm, great good humour and great grace. We mourn her passing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I add my tribute to the life of Dame Pattie Menzies. I had the privilege of knowing her a little going back to the early 1960s when I worked as a ministerial staff member for Sir Robert Menzies' then deputy, and his subsequent successor, Harold Holt. In those years and subsequently, I had the pleasure and the great privilege of meeting her from time to time.

PARA.TAB: At all times, as Senator Alston and Senator Gareth Evans have said, Dame Pattie Menzies was a lady in every sense of the word. She was a lady of great character and strength. She was a lady of grace, intellect, wit and good humour. She enchanted all those who had the privilege of meeting her.

She was a tower of strength and support to her husband throughout their long lives together, particularly during his long years as the Prime Minister of our nation. She was, quite simply, truly a great Australian. Her passing will be mourned by all Australians regardless of their political allegiances. I also take this opportunity to extend my deep sympathy and that of my wife to Dame Pattie's devoted daughter Heather and her husband Peter, and as well to her 10 grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the National Party in the Senate to associate the National Party with the condolence motion moved today. I extend our sincere sympathy for yesterday's passing away of Dame Pattie Menzies at the great age of 96. For over 50 years, Dame Pattie has been one of the most admired women in our nation. The reverence in which she was held by the Liberal Party is demonstrated by the standing ovation she received when she attended the Liberal Party's 50th anniversary last year. Liberal Party president, Tony Staley, extolled her great contribution to the party and nation, calling her a great woman, one of our great wives and one of our great mothers. That is a heartfelt sentiment with which we here would all concur.

PARA.TAB: Dame Pattie was born to a life of politics. Her father served as both a state and federal member of the parliament, and when she met Sir Robert at the local Presbyterian Church her fate to hold a central role in Australian political life was sealed. Dame Pattie was a source of great strength to Sir Robert when his early political career faulted with his resignation as Prime Minister in 1941. She provided unstinting support, loyalty and hard work when his career made its magnificent resurgence in 1949.

She made a great contribution to Australia, firstly, in her role of supporting Sir Robert Menzies—Australia's longest serving Prime Minister—and later for her community and charity work in helping the underprivileged and disadvantaged. Dame Pattie was awarded a GBE in 1954 in recognition of her tireless and unselfish work, and her tireless nursing of Sir Robert when he had a stroke in the early 1970s. We in the National Party extend our sympathy to her family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am honoured to associate myself with this condolence motion for Dame Pattie Menzies. I had the great privilege to know her. I met her on only two occasions, and was received into her home on one of those. I have very fond memories of those two occasions.

PARA.TAB: Dame Pattie Menzies, I believe, knew not only where power lay but why the power is there and for what purpose the power should be exercised. She realised the absolute fundamental importance of the family to society. She knew the power of a woman in the family. She obviously exercised that power in the gracious way that only women in that situation can. She always exercised the power for good. Her work for the extended family and the community was absolutely marvellous. Her work for the underprivileged and for the community in general will be remembered for a long time to come.

Despite my political differences with the Liberal Party—I think I was a member of the Labor Party when I met Dame Pattie—I do think she was a person who transcended those political differences. When the history of Australia is written, I believe she will loom large, slight though she was, in the honours of persons who have contributed so much to this country. She was indeed a gracious lady. I offer my condolences to her family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join in the condolence motion to Dame Pattie Menzies. In recent years it was remarkable how often one would bump into Dame Pattie at Liberal Party functions. At 94, 95 or 96 years of age Dame Pattie was so often there. You had to be a member of the Liberal Party to feel the buzz which occurred when Dame Pattie came into the room, frail and aged as she was.

PARA.TAB: But she reminded us all, I think, of the link to the past and the great history of our party. We mourn her for many reasons. We mourn her for the reasons mentioned by Senator Alston and Senator Harradine. But we also mourn her because that powerful link has now gone. In 1954 Sir Robert Menzies said that no public man could have ever received more wonderful help from his wife than he had. I believe that in 1995 we can say that no political party could ever have had more support and inspiration than the Liberal Party had from Dame Pattie.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this condolence motion for Dame Pattie Menzies, not because she was known to me personally but because I think many women across Australia admired her and respected the role she played in relation to her husband's political responsibilities, to her family, and to her country. You did not have to be a member of the Liberal Party to sense the buzz that she aroused when she appeared.

PARA.TAB: The only occasion on which I met her was on the occasion of Sir Paul Hasluck's funeral. It was wonderful to see Gough Whitlam and Dame Pattie walking together down the aisle of the church. I think that was a very important way to symbolise and remember that people who serve their country are much more than ciphers of any political party; they are very valuable human beings. The fact that Dame Pattie was regarded—not by people who knew her but by people who did not—as an accompaniment of her much more famous husband is something that I do not want to let pass today. That is why I rise to associate myself with the comments made in this chamber by those who knew her much better than I.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate myself with the condolence motion for Dame Pattie Menzies. Even though at her advanced age it was hardly a surprise that she would pass away, it still saddened me. As a Labor politician in the Northern Territory—one of the more far flung regions of Australia—I never expected to have the privilege of meeting her. But I did!

PARA.TAB: A number of years ago we opened the Menzies School of Health Research in the Northern Territory. This school was named after her husband. I was then Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory parliament. Dame Pattie came to Darwin for the opening of the school. It was a delightful affair and, with the cups of tea and so on that followed, it took most of the afternoon. I had the great privilege—and I will never forget it—of meeting her and spending several hours with her that afternoon.

I agree with the comments of Senator Alston, Senator Short, and Senator Harradine, but could I join Senator Chamarette in slightly disagreeing with the comments made by Senator Kemp. You did not have to be a member of the Liberal Party to recognise the buzz caused by Dame Pattie.

Seriously, I don't think I have ever met anyone who more epitomised—in that slight figure—the words charm, grace and good humour than Dame Pattie Menzies. She was an extraordinary personality. Let me tell honourable senators that that same buzz occurred in the heart of this hard-nosed Labor apparatchik along with all the rest of the people in the audience who had the pleasure and privilege of her company.

Disliking Dame Pattie Menzies would have been like disliking your mother; it was just not possible to do that. She was an icon for many years for Australians of whatever political persuasion. Having met her, I can understand full well why she was.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join with my colleagues and to support them in the condolence motion to Dame Pattie Menzies. As my colleagues have said, she was a person of great commitment to her family, especially to her husband during his time as the leader of this country, and to her community. I think she was also a great example to all of us of how to grow old gracefully and how to grow old with vigour, interest and, as Senator Richard Alston said, with a twinkle in her eyes. As I looked at the newspapers this morning, you could see that twinkle coming out of all the photographs, even right up until last year.

PARA.TAB: I had the pleasure of meeting Dame Pattie Menzies on innumerable occasions, but last year I introduced her to a young friend of mine who was a first-year student at university at the time. Dame Pattie engaged her in a very long conversation and started off by asking, `What are you doing?' And she said, `I'm doing linguistics, Dame Pattie.' Dame Pattie and this young friend had a long conversation about language and the importance of studying language and languages. I am not sure that every 95-year-old would be as able to carry on a conversation with a young person of that age group about linguistics.

They also, I might add, had discussions about cooking. She said somebody had given her a recipe book of old recipes and Dame Pattie said, `I really had to appreciate it, but I do have a lot of old recipes at home.' So she had a sense of humour that stayed with her right until the very end. I think it is a great example to all of us of how somebody in their latter years can still live with great vigour and vitality. I wish to extend my deep sympathy to Heather, her daughter, to her grandchildren and great-grandchildren, and other members of her family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to associate myself with the condolence motion. I had known Dame Pattie for many years since the time when I was a student and a Young Liberal. I saw her on many occasions over those years. I agree with those who have spoken as to her wit, her charm and her ability always to know exactly what was going on in the world, particularly within the Liberal Party, and never to be afraid to tell you exactly what she thought of what we were or were not achieving, or the way we were going about doing it.

PARA.TAB: I just want to mention one occasion in particular. Seventeen months ago, she allowed some of us to organise a birthday party for her 95th birthday. I had raised it with her the year before and she said no. She said no several times, but eventually she was prevailed upon to be the guest of honour at a birthday party which was held here in Canberra. It was a huge luncheon function.

When she arrived, she said to me, `I've been feeling sick in the night. I won't be able to speak.' But, of course, during the luncheon she got up and made an excellent speech. She then said she would need to leave early for the same reason. When I spoke to her about leaving she said, `But I haven't visited the tables,' and she went to every table in the room in the way she had done for so many years of her life. Nobody in the room was left out of feeling that they had been greeted by her and thanked for coming to this occasion.

Her skill in doing that, her skill in being able to meet and take an interest in everybody that she met, was really quite exceptional. It is not surprising that she is held with so much regard and affection in this community. I certainly mourn her passing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to speak for long. I first met Dame Pattie about 35 years ago when I was a bride and she was the wife of the Prime Minister. I was, of course, very impressed with meeting the Prime Minister and his wife, and very overawed, but she had that great gift she had all her life of putting people at ease.

PARA.TAB: I have not known her well over the years, but I have continually met her at Liberal functions. I found her an inspiring lady and great fun to be with. Her vitality came through in her eyes. She gave you the feeling it was a real pleasure to have met you. She sent a lot of people of all ages away feeling good to have met her.
As a woman, I guess I am proud that we have had a Prime Minister's wife who was such an inspiration to the women of the nation. She was an incredible lady, and I mourn her passing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal Land Grant and Management (Jervis Bay Territory) Legislation Amendment Bill is essentially non-controversial legislation. It seeks to allow the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council to play a role in the functioning of the community by transferring the land back to the community so that the Jervis Bay National Park can effectively be operated by the local Aboriginal community but, for all practical purposes, will continue in the way that it operates at the present time. So it will remain a national park.

PARA.TAB: There is power in the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Act, as I recall, for the minister to actually direct that to happen if it does not. Otherwise, it is a 99-year lease which will give the Aboriginal community invaluable experience in the operational aspects of control of the park. We, therefore, regard it as a positive step. Perhaps I could simply say that we will be supporting the amendments that have been circulated in the name of the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly on the Aboriginal Land Grant and Management (Jervis Bay Territory) Legislation Amendment Bill. There were originally some concerns expressed by residents of the area that this may well pose some kind of threat to their traditional rights, if you like, to fishing in the area—this is the non-Aboriginal residents of the region—because there has been a great deal of visitation to the area by those people who recognise its beauty and its potential for recreational fishermen. But I think the way this matter has been handled has resolved any of those problems which have emerged. I understand that the Mayor of Shoalhaven has carried out some investigations in the region and established that there are no problems. This is, of course, an area that comes under the control of the ACT.

PARA.TAB: I do want to raise one little matter that is of concern to some Aboriginal people working in this area, and that is that employees of the National Parks and Wildlife Service are entitled to housing. I think there are about eight Aboriginal families who have an employee member of the family working either for the National Parks and Wildlife Service or for the administration in that area and who are entitled to housing in the area. The problem that emerges is what will happen to those Aboriginal people who are entitled to housing when they cease, by retirement or by some other measure such as redundancy, to be employed.

The reason I ask this question is that there is a shortage of housing in the area. As I understand it, there is something of a waiting list to get into the Wreck Bay housing facility, which is an Aboriginal housing facility. All I am raising with the government is whether the problems facing those Aboriginal employees of the National Parks and Wildlife Service in this area could be examined. I do not know what the right solution is, but I know that some Aboriginal people there that I have spoken to recently have concerns about their future accommodation in the event of their retirement from employment, which carries with it the entitlement to housing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are still on a path towards reconciling ownership of land in this country. It is the right path to take, and that path is leading us to a number of different forms of management of the land. One of those ways is to have joint management in some areas like Uluru and Kakadu. The Aboriginal Land Grant and Management (Jervis Bay Territory) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 that we are debating today provides the mechanism for the next step in joint management of part of Jervis Bay National Park and Jervis Bay Botanic Gardens. I think we should acknowledge that the government is moving this legislation as part of the implementation of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, recommendation No. 315.

PARA.TAB: At this stage, I would like to acknowledge the presence of the Wreck Bay community who are sitting in the gallery watching what is, for them, the culmination of a significant amount of work. I am sure they acknowledge there is a lot more to come. I need to tell them that we may not be proceeding to pass this bill today. I understand that we are going only to the end of the second reading stage.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—That is correct, Senator Kernot.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think they will be very disappointed with that. However, the Australian Democrats are going to take the opportunity presented by government amendments to this bill to present our own series of amendments which deal with the structural processes by which the community operates. The amendments we are moving have been drafted in consultation with members of the Wreck Bay community. I will take just a few seconds to outline their scope.

PARA.TAB: They aim to clarify the processes that have come about as a result of the community's experience in dealing with the principal act. We believe our amendments will assist the community to operate more efficiently and more reasonably. For example, our amendments will allow the community to take action with regard to community needs like housing, education and social welfare. Our amendments will enable the community to undertake capital works, to protect and conserve natural and cultural sites on Aboriginal land, manage their land, conduct business enterprises and plan their land use needs. Our amendments will enable the community to refrain from seeking ministerial approval for amounts under $100,000. We are talking about a community which is organising sewerage, housing and other infrastructure contracts.

Finally, our amendments will deal with defining the number of people required for a quorum and defining a term for the executive. As I said, they deal with procedural matters to enable the community to work, as they see it, more reasonably and efficiently. I think we should commend the passage of this bill. It is very important to the Wreck Bay community to be able to get on with doing the job. I hope we can find time very soon to proceed to the end of the process from the legislative point of view.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also would like to comment on this very important piece of legislation. It is important not only because of the issues that arise for the Jervis Bay territory but also for external territories. My remarks will be principally confined to those relating to Norfolk Island.

PARA.TAB: At the outset, I would like to make the point that I share the concern of Senator Kernot that the residents of Jervis Bay, who have come today to listen to this legislation, are not able to see it taken through to finality. It ought to be realised that the reason for that is, given the amendments which have been proposed, that there is an agreement that amendments will not be processed at this time of day, which is principally set aside for non-controversial legislation. Therefore, unfortunately, by the government choosing to bring it on at this particular point, it is unable to be properly processed. It is through no fault of those of us on this side of the parliament. In fact, it should have been listed at a more appropriate time on the program.

However, I want to specifically address those aspects of the legislation that relate to Norfolk Island. There are clauses within this bill that set out to extend new and certain provisions to enable inquiries into the provision of reports to the minister on application made by Norfolk Island to the commission for a grant of special assistance, and any matter relating to a grant, or the making of a grant of financial assistance, by the Commonwealth to Norfolk Island, referred to it by the minister. Secondly, it requires the commission to inquire into and report to the minister on any matter relating to the financing of works and services provided by the Commonwealth, or a Commonwealth authority, to an external territory other than Norfolk Island, referred to it by the minister.

I think it is important to recognise that we have a very special and unique relationship between the Australian parliament and the government of Norfolk Island. This is historical; it is based on a very long and negotiated special arrangement. Anybody who is familiar with the budget appropriations of the federal parliament will know that Norfolk Island makes very little demand and, in fact, operates on special financial arrangements, unique and very different to those that apply at our other external territories of Cocos (Keeling) Island and Christmas Island, where very generous and extensive financing is, in particular, made available. Therefore, the provision of an inquiry in this area must necessarily take into account the needs and the issues of Norfolk Islanders.

Several months ago I wrote to the government of Norfolk Island to ascertain their position with regard to this legislation. I would like to read part of the reply that I received from the Norfolk Island Minister for Health and Education, Nadia Lozzi-Cuthbertson. There is the usual first paragraph, and I will quote the second paragraph:

On the 6th July 1995 the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories passed to the Norfolk Island Government (NIG) (through the Administrator) a copy of the Bill. The extension of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973 was discussed at a recent Inter-Government Meeting between the Parliamentary Secretary for Territories, Mr Snowdon, and the NIG. At that meeting the NIG emphasized that the self governing status of Norfolk Island should be taken into account in any amendments, that the changes should include a clause to permit the Commission to respond to any future application for special assistance initiated by the NIG, and that no reference to Norfolk Island matters will be undertaken without prior consultation with, and agreement by, the NIG.

The NIG was very pleased that the Bill covers the first two matters and we have had assurances at ministerial level about the third. We are particularly pleased that the Bill includes Norfolk Island in the category of "autonomous territories", similar to the Northern Territory and the ACT.

We did note, in the draft explanatory memorandum at point 27, the word "latter" should be deleted and "former" substituted. I note that the draft explanatory memorandum attached to your letter still contains this error. Thank you very much for sending this Bill on to us. Although on this occasion there was indeed extensive consultation, that is regrettably not always the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I want to stress is the need for consultation and agreement of the Norfolk Island government in initiating any inquiries of this nature.

PARA.TAB: I know that, earlier this year, there was a report by the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories entitled Delivering the goods. It is an important report which looks at external territories and it covers a number of issues. I am sure that Senator Reid and, I think, Senator Ian Macdonald are very familiar with the report as they were participants in that particular case. The report contains specific recommendations with regard to inquiries into issues arising in the various external territories of Australia.

Recommendation 21 of the report specifically deals with the need to look at the cost of living of residents of Norfolk Island as a remote community and it recommends that inquiries should be extended to look at a number of issues in this area. Recommendation 22 of the report specifically recommends that the Minister for Finance decline to make any loans for transport infrastructure or shipping pending the outcome of an examination of the financial relationship between the Commonwealth and Norfolk Island. It is important to recognise that there is a need for further inquiry, and this has been accepted by the parliament of Norfolk Island. However, these inquiries must be initiated only after full agreement has been reached with the local representatives of the island.

As I said in my initial comments, Norfolk Island is a unique place, and I refer to the discussions that the Norfolk Island parliamentarians have had with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mr Snowdon). In reading the report, it is very interesting to note that the residents of Norfolk Island are apprehensive and that they hold reservations. When Mr Snowdon visited Norfolk Island, he raised the hackles of many people there when he discussed the issue of how Australia will proceed with the issue of Australia becoming a republic. Following a report by Mr Snowdon, a local Norfolk Island paper, the Norfolk Islander, printed the following:

In conversation with Mr Snowdon the question of the Australian republic was raised. Mr Snowdon is a staunch republican, he even has a watch to prove it, and we asked him where Norfolk island would stand if the question of Australia becoming a Republic were put to the vote.

He said that Australians in Norfolk Island would be involved in the referendums the same as Australians in the mainland and that when Australia became a Republic, which he seems to believe is a foregone conclusion, that Norfolk islanders `would just have to cop it sweet'.

SPEECH.PARA: Naturally, this is the type of attitude that raises the hackles of parliamentarians and residents anywhere. It reveals the arrogance of this government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was it again who said it?

—The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories said that in his dealing with this very important constituency. As I am sure many senators will recognise, given the Pitcairn heritage that applies to Norfolk Islanders, an attitude such as that portrayed by Mr Snowdon, if it is the attitude of the Australian government, would give the Norfolk Islanders many reasons for concern. Whilst we support the legislation, we specifically put on the record the reservations that must apply.

I rise to speak on the Aboriginal Land Grant and Management (Jervis Bay Territory) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 which is before the Senate. As the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) has mentioned, we support this bill. Mrs Gallus has consulted widely with community groups and business groups in the Nowra area. One group wrote to her to say that it sees this bill as a step which will help in the reconciliation process and will provide employment opportunities for the most disadvantaged group in the local labour market.

PARA.TAB: The bill touches on three of my portfolio responsibilities: firstly, as shadow minister for the environment; secondly, as shadow minister for the ACT; and, thirdly, as shadow minister for administrative services. The bill amends the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Act 1986 and the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973. The National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act is, of course, administered within the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, while the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act is administered within the Department of Administrative Services.

It will surprise some senators to learn that the Jervis Bay territory is, in effect, part of the Australian Capital Territory and that the laws enforced in the ACT operate in the Jervis Bay territory so far as they are applicable. A description of the Jervis Bay Territory and the legal regime which applies was outlined in the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report, Islands in the sun, which I think was referred to by my colleague Senator Tambling. As mentioned, this legislation enables title to the Jervis Bay National Park and Jervis Bay Botanic Gardens to be granted to the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council. It will then be leased back to the Commonwealth to be jointly managed as a national park.

The proposal on the land grant and lease-back follows the model established for Uluru National Park. This model includes legislative compulsory lease-back whereby the council is obliged to give a lease for continued management of the granted land as a national park. A board of management with a majority of representatives of the traditional Aboriginal owners will be established to oversee management of the park and gardens. Overseeing development of a plan of management to the area will be, of course, a major task of the board. Extensive public involvement in the development of the plan is required under the legislation. The legislation amends the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act to enable the minister to establish a board for the national park and botanic gardens if they are declared to be Aboriginal land under the Aboriginal land grant act, and if agreement is reached with the council, of course.

The Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973 is amended to extend the functions of the Grants Commission to inquire into the territory, as well as all external territories, and my colleague Senator Tambling dealt with some of the issues in relation to Norfolk Island. The proposed amendments will place Norfolk Island in the same position as the states and territories in respect of the Grants Commission survey. In that sense, the Grants Commission can be said to be an auditor and a determinator of the level of Commonwealth assistance. As mentioned, the coalition will be supporting this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to make only a short speech on this Aboriginal Land Grant and Management (Jervis Bay Territory) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, states that this bill reflects the continuing commitment of this government to securing legitimate title to traditional lands on behalf of the Aboriginal people throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that this bill is yet another sham perpetrated by this government on Aboriginal people.
