The bill grants title of the Jervis Bay National Park and Botanic Gardens to the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council who are then required, under the legislation, to lease their land back to the Commonwealth for the purpose of a national park. Existing legal rights of land-holders and public rights for use are preserved. A management plan is to be prepared under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. As it did over Mabo, the government is paying lip service to Aboriginal self-determination, while entrenching existing land title and placing paternalistic limits on the ability of Aboriginal people to manage their own land and affairs.

The Greens (WA) are appalled that the government finds itself incapable of coming to terms with the true nature of self-determination. This bill shows that it is utterly unwilling to return land back to its original owners, full stop. Instead, the land is returned but must then be leased back. Existing titles are maintained and a management regime is established under yet another act. Why is it that the government cannot grant land to Aboriginal people without the spectre of mistrust and suspicion hanging in the background? Reconciliation will never advance beyond its infant stage without non-indigenous people making unequivocal acts of trust in Aboriginal people.

This bill not only fails to give the members of the Aboriginal community control over their land and activities; it also fails to affirm their enormous wisdom and skill in the management of the land up till now. Thus the bill requires a management regime to be established under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. On top of this, the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council's operation continues to be controlled by the act, including the insulting requirement that spending decisions over $1,000 must be approved by the minister. I might add here that this is not money that is given by the government; this is the money they have earned in their own right. They require approval by the minister for any spending decisions over $1,000. Is this what the government means by self-determination? I will be moving an amendment later, in the committee stage, to eliminate this requirement.

The Greens have listened to the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community and understand that they want to see this bill passed. Because of this, we will not be opposing the legislation. However, if the government wants the community to believe that it is committed to reconciliation, it must show in the future a much greater level of trust and understanding of Aboriginal people than is contained in this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, let me express my thanks for the number of positive contributions in this second reading debate on the very important and historic legislation before this chamber. I am disappointed at the very ungenerous and inaccurate comments that have been made in Senator Chamarette's contribution, and I will deal with the substance of those when we go to the committee stage of the Aboriginal Land Grant and Management (Jervis Bay Territory) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the fact that we are able to have this second reading debate while representatives of the Wreck Bay community are able to be present in the public gallery. I do know what this bill means for the future of the Wreck Bay community, and I am delighted that I have been able, as the minister for the environment, to be involved with its development.

I would also like to place on record my sincere appreciation of the cooperative and constructive spirit that has enabled us to achieve this outcome. There is no doubt that such a spirit has characterised the negotiations that we have had on this issue, and I appreciate the role that the Wreck Bay community has played in that regard.

I have said on a number of occasions, and I would like to say on the record again today in the Senate chamber, that I regard this as one of the most important pieces of legislation that I have been associated with. Not only am I absolutely confident that the joint management arrangements which can flow from this legislation will be of great benefit to the Wreck Bay community but I really believe that they are going to be very important for the conservation of Jervis Bay National Park. I can also say that the Australian Nature Conservation Agency—which is responsible for the management of the park—is very much looking forward to working jointly with the Wreck Bay community to protect the natural values of this area, one which is very important to all Australians.

The reason we are having this second reading debate during this period of non-controversial legislation is the pressure of business this morning and our routine of business this afternoon. It would have been impossible for us to get to the bill this morning but we do have an opportunity at this time of the day to finalise the second reading of this bill. It would be my intention to move a motion at the conclusion of this second reading debate, which is not usually done at this period of the day, to allow this matter to become an order of the day for a later hour this day and, if it is at all possible, for us to return to this after the other business we have before us is finalised. I hope that we will be able to return to the committee stage of this bill later in the day. That will, I think, depend on the pressure of other business that we have before us, but I think that in relatively short order, whether it be later on this afternoon or whether it be in a fortnight's time, we will see this very important bill pass the Senate.

I believe this legislation will mean a great deal in terms of the protection of this sensitive environment and, as I have said, has very great significance for the future of the Wreck Bay community. I am delighted, as the environment minister, to be able to be associated with this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a personal explanation in relation to some comments made about me by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner).

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—You may claim misrepresentation, having spoken before the minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to do that. I would just state very briefly that I hope that the minister did not imply by his remarks that I do not support the plea by this community, members of which are here witnessing the debate and the speeches today, that this bill be passed and that they gain the amount of self-determination which they believe the government has offered to them. That is where I believe that there may have been some misrepresentation in Senator Faulkner's remarks and I would want to distance myself from that. My criticisms were for the government and I have indicated that I will be supporting the legislation in an effort to give the people of Wreck Bay what they have requested and what they manifestly deserve.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the bill in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for a later hour of the day.

DEBATE.TITLE: BANKING (QUEENSLAND INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 June, on motion by Senator Schacht:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill 1995 seeks to bring the Queensland Industry Development Corporation—the QIDC, as it is known—under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia by listing it under the definition of a bank in section 5 of the Banking Act 1959. The Queensland government has sought this measure to improve the accountability of the QIDC. The bill includes provisions complementary to Queensland legislation under which the Queensland government transferred its constitutional banking power as it relates to the state financial institutions, in this case the QIDC, to the Commonwealth. This will ensure that the QIDC is required to follow the provisions of and is subject to the supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia in relation to prudential matters.

PARA.TAB: The coalition will not be opposing this bill but I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the bill is not without some controversy in Queensland itself. The reason is that the Goss Labor government in Queensland, when it passed complementary legislation last year for the QIDC to be brought under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank, gave assurances that the QIDC would not become a bank. However, declaring the QIDC a bank under section 5 of the Commonwealth Banking Act will give it a complete range of banking powers. So what we have got is the fact that the Goss government gave quite misleading assurances last year that the QIDC would not become a bank.

When one looks at the absolutely disastrous records of some other state Labor governments in managing state banks, one can only have cause for some concern that the consequence of all of this is that the Queensland Industry Development Corporation will, in fact, become a full state bank. In my own state, Victoria, we saw a Labor government, in the 1980s and early 1990s, absolutely wreck the State Bank of Victoria through gross incompetence and, in some instances, worse. We saw the same situation in South Australia with the State Bank of South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're good at it.

—My friend, Senator Abetz, says that they are good at it. They sure are. They turned the mismanagement of state banks into an absolute art form, and one can only hope that the same does not happen in the case of the QIDC, now that it has the full range of banking powers. Having said that, I repeat that the coalition does support this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the contribution that Senator Short has made on this occasion, and commend the Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill 1995 to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 30 March, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Marks Bill 1995 repeals and replaces the Trade Marks Act 1995 and the Trade Marks Act 1994. The bill derives from an exposure draft of the Trade Marks Bill 1994 which the government released, and on which it invited public comment, in February 1994. The 1994 bill sought to implement the government's response to the July 1992 report of the working party to review trade marks legislation, entitled Recommended changes to the Australian trade marks legislation.

PARA.TAB: Before the results of public consultation could be included, the government decided to introduce the Trade Marks Bill 1994 as part of the package of legislation enacted last December to ensure that Australia met its obligations under the agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation. However, in so doing, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) indicated that the government would amend the new act at the earliest opportunity to incorporate the results of that process of consultation. Due to the extensive nature of the changes that would be necessary to amend the Trade Marks Act 1994, the government has decided that it is now simpler and more convenient to repeal the 1994 act and replace it with a new consolidated bill which we now have before us. The Trade Marks Act 1994 has not yet come into effect.

The bill proposes a new and wider definition of a trade mark. As a result, it will now be possible to register sounds, smells and aspects of packaging as trade marks provided that all other requirements are met. The bill also streamlines existing procedures under the trade marks system. In particular, it is proposed to introduce a system of multi-class applications which will eliminate the need for separate applications for each class of goods or services for which registration is sought. In addition, the bill includes simplified provisions for recording the assignment of trade marks and a more streamlined method of removing unused trade marks from the register.

In line with the 1994 act, the bill proposes that the distinction between part A and part B of the trade marks register be removed. Under the existing system the register is divided with trade marks registered under part B accorded more limited rights than those in part A. There were a number of members of the 1992 working party who recommended retention of a divided register and, according to the minister's second reading speech, a minority of submissions to the working party also supported that view. Nevertheless, the government has opted to pursue a unified register with all trade marks accorded the same level of protection currently afforded by part A registration.

Whilst the bill differs from the 1994 act, mainly in matters of clarity and technical detail, there are two key areas of more substantive difference which are worthy of comment. Firstly, whilst the 1994 act sought to streamline existing provisions dealing with associated trade marks, the new bill proposes to do away with the concept of associated trade marks altogether. According to the minister's second reading speech, this measure is in line with submissions received during the public consultation process and is consistent with the situation in most other industrialised nations.

The other area of more substantive difference from the 1994 act is that the new bill does not include provisions relating to the registration of the use of the trade mark by a person other than the trade mark owner. Instead, the bill provides for use of trade marks by persons other than the registered owner provided that the owner retains control over the use of the trade mark. According to the government, the World Trade Organisation agreement does not require use under control of the owner to be registered and, consequently, it is said there is little benefit in retaining additional provisions for the registration of users. The change also simplifies existing legislation by eliminating part 11 of the 1994 act.

The coalition supports the bill. It is, for the reasons I have outlined, one that we think improves the situation. It clarifies the situation in relation to trade marks and therefore is to be supported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some very brief comments, not in relation to the technical detail but to the processes involved in arriving at the point we have reached today. In essence, the Trade Marks Bill 1995 is an update of the Trade Marks Bill 1994 which was passed into law by the Senate last December. The bill we dealt with then was part of a very large package of trade bills which were introduced in order to enable Australia to accept the agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation, which was an agreement to which the government was very keen to be a founding signatory. The Democrats did not agree with the rush to sign the World Trade Organisation agreement because of the blind faith it puts in free trade ahead of fair trade. But that is now a past debate; that is past history. We are in there, although I believe the consequences have not yet been fully felt.

PARA.TAB: The 1994 Trade Marks Bill was drafted so as to be consistent with standards and principles prescribed for trade marks contained in the WTO agreement. It replaced the Trade Marks Act 1995 and was due to come into effect on 1 January 1996. However, in the rush to enable us to sign the WTO agreement, the government was actually forced to table and have the parliament pass an exposure draft of the bill, with which we are currently dealing. The exposure draft became the Trade Marks Bill 1994.

The bill we now have, the Trade Marks Bill 1995, is the final, completed version of the bill. It has been updated to reflect the outcome of consultation with the trade marks community, and it will repeal and replace last year's bill. This final bill represents the culmination of a process which began as long ago as March 1989 when the then Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Mr Barry Jones, authorised a working party comprising representatives of the Trade Marks Office, the Institute of Patent Attorneys of Australia and the Law Council of Australia to review and streamline the trade marks legislation. That working party released a discussion paper for public comment in July 1991 and its final paper, glamorously called, `Recommended changes to the Australian trade mark legislation', in July 1992.

From that point, there came the draft legislation. It was widely circulated and an extensive process of consultation occurred under the auspices of the Trade Marks Office. The bill does reflect that consultation. I believe that the government is to be congratulated for the considerable amount of work and discussion and participation that has gone into developing the bill to this stage—if only it happened all the time. In particular, I would like to congratulate the Trade Marks Office, which made sure that it did happen.

We do not have 100 per cent agreement on the final bill, but it certainly is very widely accepted. The major problem, as we see it, is the inclusion of aspects of packaging, shape, colour, sound or scent in the definition of a trade-markable sign. We understand this is included to make the legislation consistent with what is described to us as international practice. It seems, however, to the Democrats that adding aspects of packaging, shape, colour, sound or scent to the definition of a trade-markable sign only adds to a marketer's capacity to capture market share by gaining control over forms of sensory manipulation, rather than forcing them to provide anything more concrete by way of producing something really new or valuable. Manufacturers and marketeers will have their products protected by labelling and other definitions in this bill. We do not believe that they need any more.

We have arrived at this position because, despite receiving assurances from the Trade Marks Office that they do not intend this bill to be adventurous with new definition—assurances which we do accept—the fact is that the final decisions on these matters will be made in the courts and that is a process that we do not particularly want to trigger off.

That issue aside, we support the bill. People within the trade mark community are ready to proceed under the new system. We do believe that adequate processes and safeguards are in place to protect both consumers and traders and that, as I said before, the consultation process has been comprehensive. We therefore recommend this bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The introduction of this bill is not opposed by the opposition. It will modernise the trade mark regime. The current regime was enacted in 1955, some 40 years ago. It would be noted by even the most casual observer of trade and technology that there have been significant developments in the intervening 40 years. This bill has its genesis in the research undertaken by the working party to review trade marks legislation. The working party reported in 1992. The government, in response, produced a draft exposure bill two years later which, in effect, implemented the government's response.

PARA.TAB: Whilst the public consultation was still in progress, the government decided to introduce the Trade Marks Bill 1994. It undoubtedly did this because of its self-perceived need to fulfil its obligations to the World Trade Organisation. However, the public consultation process resulted in so many amendments that the government, quite properly, decided to, in effect, withdraw the 1994 bill and proceed with this particular bill.

Some of the welcome features of this bill include: a wider definition of trade marks, to include sounds, smells and aspects of packaging as trade marks; and the streamlining of existing procedures, including a system of multi-class applications. There is other material on the public record about this bill which does not need to be repeated. I note that the bill will eliminate provisions that may have the effect of diluting the level of accountability between owners and other users of trade marks. Time will tell as to how these changes will work in practice.

Whilst discussing the Trade Marks Bill 1995, I wish to express my concern at the way the Trade Marks Office has dealt with a particular constituent of mine in Tasmania, a Mr Roger Coates, who had the name `Tarkine Tours' registered by the Trade Marks Office.

As a result of answers to questions placed on notice at the last Senate estimates committees, we have confirmation that the Trade Marks Office does not register names that are geographic names, and that geographic names do not qualify as trade marks pursuant to paragraph 24(1)(d) of the Trade Marks Act. There is no difficulty with that. That makes sense; it is reasonable and proper that that be the case.

The reason I want to raise this matter is that `Tarkine' is not the recognised name of a geographic area within my home state of Tasmania. It was a name invented by certain elements within the green movement to try to establish some credibility for having the Arthur-Pieman region of my home state listed on the Australian heritage list. It clearly was a propagandistic name and had no geographic basis whatsoever. Indeed, the Tasmanian Nomenclature Board did not recognise it.

The Trade Marks Office itself, of course, did not recognise it, and that is why it initially allowed the registration of that name. Indeed, they say that, during examination, the normal geographic references were searched. So all the normal ones were searched and, of course, `Tarkine' did not come up. No entry was located to indicate that `Tarkine' failed to qualify as a trade mark because of its identity as a geographic name.

But then, undoubtedly, certain pressures were brought to bear, because of the federal government's pursuit of having the Arthur-Pieman region in my home state listed. This region is one where there have been townships of in excess of 2,000 people, and where considerable mining, agriculture and forestry operations have taken place, over many decades. So, to try to beef up the claim to have this listed on the Australian heritage listing, a new name had to be developed.

A name was then developed by picking on a version—not even a proper name but a version of a name—of the name of an Aboriginal band that lived in the area. They were the Tarkinimma band, and theirs was only one of very many bands that traversed the area which is known as the Arthur-Pieman region. Indeed, they were mainly coastal Aboriginals, only went round to about 10 miles inland and, basically, survived on seafood. But, in insisting that they wanted to get some good-sounding name, the name `Tarkine' was used by those supporting the listing of the Arthur-Pieman region, so they tried to call this area `the Tarkine region'.

It seems to me that the Trade Marks Office has unwittingly and quite foolishly embroiled itself in a debate that it need not have involved itself in by saying that, just because certain green elements in the community have renamed an area as Tarkine, that, of itself, has some geographic value all of a sudden. The Trade Marks Office people told me in the answer that they provided that information came to light that Tarkine does have geographic value. It is used to denominate an area of wilderness—once again, they have made a value judgment that it is wilderness; how and why they have done that, I do not know—in north-west Tasmania between the Arthur and Pieman Rivers. Of course, in Tasmania the area between the two rivers which are mentioned is known as the Arthur-Pieman region.

It seems quite astounding that the Trade Marks Office should involve itself in determining that this area is somehow a wilderness when the area has roads, mines, sawmills and townships in it. The area is not the sort of wilderness that the listening community in the gallery might expect to be described as wilderness when there are all these interventions and human activity in it.

The Trade Marks Office made an unfortunate decision to involve itself in a heated political green debate over the use of a name when clearly that name, as yet, has not been gazetted or placed on the Nomenclature Board listing. The name has no basis other than for propagandistic purposes by those who are trying to list another part of my home state on the Australian Heritage Commission list.

I hope and trust that the experience the Trade Marks Office has had in this particular situation will make it less anxious to adopt propagandistic terms as geographical names and that it thereby cancels trade mark names that they have approved. If the normal research that the Trade Marks Office undertakes does not disclose the name, one wonders why they should then undertake further research only to find out that somebody is now calling an area by a different name.

The Trade Marks Office could well find itself in great difficulty. All you would have to do is to get a local shire council or something of that nature to start to refer to an area by a different name than that which is on a map or in the Nomenclature Board and then tell the Trade Marks Office, `Look, sorry. The people in this town refer to this area by a particular name and, therefore, this particular trade mark ought be cancelled.' It sets a very dangerous precedent.

I hope and trust that there was not inappropriate political involvement in the Trade Marks Office when it came to its determination. If there was not inappropriate political intervention, then the officers concerned ought reflect on the way they handled this matter. They ought consider their actions for the future to ensure that genuine people who want to get about their business are not confronted by having their trade marks cancelled simply because certain minority groups within the community wish to rename an area without either the approval of the people of that area or of the state concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —This area of trade marks comes under the heading of intellectual property, which has more importance than most people would realise. The question of trade marks is relevant both to the consumer and to the business involved, particularly small businesses which perhaps use trade marks more often in the course of their daily commercial activities. A trade mark is a word or symbol used to identify the trade source of goods or services. Thereby the consumer relies on that, and the vendor or the retailer relies on that mark as being something which is identified in the marketplace and something upon which that business hangs its hat in order to sell its goods. As I said, it is part of the area of intellectual property where you have such things as designs, patents and trade names. Sometimes it is hard to define the differences between them.

PARA.TAB: The common law recognised the action of passing off, which is a situation where you pass off someone else's goods as your own. There was an action allowed to an individual, based on either deceit or false pretence, in relation to that. It was allowed for very good reasons, because someone had the thought and went to the effort of coming up with a design or a trade mark and, of necessity, had to have protection for having endeavoured to come up with that. Similarly, the consumer needed that protection because the consumer needed to know that what he or she was buying was in fact that article which was for sale and was not the property of another person.

This Trade Marks Bill 1995 repeals and replaces the Trade Marks Act 1955 and the Trade Marks Act 1994. The coalition is aware of the problems being faced by the owners of registered trade marks and the complexity of issues arising from the sale of Australian products in an ever increasing international market and, therefore, does not oppose the bill. As previous speakers have mentioned, this bill came about as a result of Australia's obligations under the agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation and, in particular, the sub-agreement entitled `The agreement on trade related aspects of intellectual property rights'. This is an aspect where perhaps an international instrument is of great value domestically to Australia because, in this sense, it provides a minimum standard for intellectual property protection—thereby protecting Australian products, I believe.

The definition, as has been mentioned previously, has been widened. I understand from the paper done by the parliamentary library that the current definition did have its problems. The present definition which is contained in the Trade Marks Act 1955 has limitations because it does not expressly convey the requirement that the trade mark must be distinctive. Also the definition is ambiguous because it refers to a connection by an infringer with the owner of a registered trade mark.

As I understand it, clause 17 of this bill remedies those defects, and allows for signs which can include a shape, colour, sound or scent provided that the identifier can be represented graphically. Under the new definition, these features of a product will be protected, and I think that is to be applauded. The new definition is simple and easily understandable. In fact, I would compliment the drafters of this bill in the setting out of the explanatory guide at the beginning of the bill, and then the flow chart, done by way of an appendix, which sets out how to obtain the registration of a trade mark. I believe that that is an innovation which the Commonwealth is using more and more these days, and it is one which I applaud.

The bill generally seeks to streamline the process for registration of trade marks, and introduces a system of multi-class applications which will eliminate the need for separate applications for each class of goods or services for which registration is sought. That, too, is a good thing. It removes the distinction between types of trade marks. At present, you have two categories A and B, and the bill removes that distinction and accords all trade marks the same protection at the higher level under the old system. That also is a reform. I understand that the financial impact of this bill will not be great by means of implementation, but the gains that remain to be enjoyed by the business community, and the consumers of Australia in general, are very great indeed. I support wholeheartedly this bill, as does the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of those areas where it is simple for a person to become submerged in the complexities of the legislation and find they have accepted the reasoned and basic view. It is useful, from time to time, to surface and look at what the act does and why. Trade marks have one primary function which is to distinguish the product of one manufacturer from the product of others. There are two reasons to do this. One is because a person may want people to know that the product is yours so that, if they like it, they can buy it again. It is a basic method of ensuring that, when a producer puts the time and effort into a product to make it a good product, consumers can identify that product and buy it again. It protects the interests of producer and consumer.

PARA.TAB: This is a fairly simple and straightforward issue. A label or some other identifying mark can be used that means customers can find that product when they look. Note that this is an interactive definition that assumes the customer is an active agent who pays attention to signs and seeks out products they like.

The second reason for having a trademark is so that a person can take a product which is little different from any other, or of little inherent value, and promote it through advertising using the full range of psychological marketing techniques. This allows those with a lot of money to develop an image which they sell and with which they try to convince customers that they can partake of this image if they buy the product.

In this case, the producer wants to protect their investment in marketing by assuring that no-one with an essentially identical product can cash in on their image creation. The consumer is seen as a passive person to be led and the issue is that the people with big bucks who spend it in marketing do not want other people leading the sheep they have created.

Going back to the first case, the one the moral argument for trade marks rests upon, we would have to say that where a product is functionally superior—whether that means it works better, tastes better, smells better or makes your cat happier—people will look at that product, identify it for themselves and seek it out. If there is a similar product that is not as good, they will remember that as well. As long as there is a label of some sort, the consumer will do the differentiation. All that is needed is that label.

All the marketing tools, specially shaped bottles, scented thread or whatever are irrelevant. The consumer will still look for the label and buy the product they want. All that is required to protect producers from fraud is the establishment of a clear label as a trade mark. The only time consumers will not look for and buy according to quality and price is where they have been convinced that some product is somehow better, cooler or sexier.

Advertising can override good sense. This is where the image issue comes in. Coca-Cola is often used as the classic example of packaging or shape being used as a trade mark. Coke argues that they have created such a strong identification with the shape of the coke bottle that, if anyone else uses that shape bottle, they would lose business.

What this says to me is that there is effectively no inherent difference between coke and other cola drinks and that, if someone makes the mistake and buys Pepsi Cola, they would not know the difference. Because they would not notice a difference, they might not pay any attention to whether a thing is Coke or Pepsi. Coke might lose sales. If, Ricardo forbid, it were not Pepsi, but Amrit Cola in Bombay, or Black and Gold from the supermarket sold at half the cost, people might buy Amrit or the generic brand because it is cheaper, as long as they can still partake of the whole hip, cool image that has been marketed effectively independent of the qualities of coke as a drink.

What is wrong with this? I do not think anyone would argue that because the bottle looks similar, people do not know that they are buying Black and Gold, or that they are buying it by mistake, really wanting Coke. If we assume that the consumers can and do differentiate, then the labels on the front are working. So what is the problem?

All those billions Coke spends to get Michael Jackson or Madonna to do Coke ads is the problem. Coke has gone to a lot of trouble to create the impression, basically a false impression, that Coke is something special, something different, even though it tastes about the same. They have gone to a lot of trouble to make people think that, if they drink this fantastic substance, they will live in fast forward with the beautiful and fit people doing exciting things and dancing all day, that they will be sexy and desirable, socially active and have attitude.

In Asia, marketing goes even further, pushing the idea that you will not only do all the things above, but you will live essentially as Americans, and not just any Americans, but like rich people from New York or Hollywood.

The issue is that, while a label is enough to ensure that consumers can identify a product, it may not be enough to exclude others from all the benefits of this marketing. But is the reason for trade marks to exclude others from marketing of products, like coke, which are in fact no better than most other products—products which are unnecessary, unhealthy and which cost a lot? And this is a real issue amongst the poor and among developing countries. There is evidence in many countries that the aggressive marketing of cola drinks has been so successful that people buy these products, which are very expensive relative to their income, and that they buy these products to try to give some part of the image which was created to their children. They buy them at the expense of food. It is a phenomenon known as cola malnutrition syndrome. Another famous case is the marketing of powdered formula by Nestle in Africa, which led to consumer boycotts worldwide.

Marketing is the sort of thing that lets tobacco companies promote their products as youthful, beautiful, healthy, liberating, sexy. The Marlboro man—cool, freedom and the ad that tells women `You've come a long way, baby.' A long way, indeed, now you can be targeted for aggressive marketing and psychological image creation, need creation, wrong association, in an effort to sell you something that will empty your pocket and rob you of your health. Marketing is the sort of thing that ensures that teenagers want a pair of $100 Nike or Adidas shoes made in Indonesia for $1 per pair, rather than the virtually identical non-famous brand shoes that sell for a quarter of the price.

For this type of image creation, labels are not enough. Coke wants the shape of its bottle. The image people want to create a multiple level of image and sensory association—shape, colour, smell, tactile cues—any hook to get you in. They want to create a complex set of cues and images to push a product more effectively, where effectively there is likely to be no inherent difference in the product, and often no reason for anyone to buy the product, or an entire class of products—such as cigarettes or cola drinks—which have no inherent benefit at all. There may be significant health and environmental reasons not to buy the product, which the marketing seeks to override.

But is it not consumer choice? Don't people like things such as coke or candy just because they like them, even if they are not good for them? I am reminded of the joke where a young boy blows out the birthday candles and is asked, `What did you wish for?' `I want to have periods.' `What! Why?' `So I can use tampons and go sailing, mountain climbing, surfing and horse riding!' It is an insight of humour that the needs created have virtually nothing to do with, and will never be satisfied by, the product promoted.

What we want often has nothing to do with what we buy. It has to do with the image and needs that have been created. Not only are the things pushed often bad for you, or for the environment, but the whole push to consume, consume, consume, is inherently bad for the environment. It leads to unsustainable use of resources and an immense social overemphasis on consumption and image, superficial qualities that blind us to the real qualities in ourselves and the people around us.

Is this what parliament wants to promote and protect with this law? There are also other issues in relation to sensory labels, and especially shape and aspects of packaging. Currently, there are other laws addressing intellectual property in design. Where it is inherent as a unique and intrinsic quality of a new product, an innovation, design can be patented. Where it is only a special shape, design law applies. But both of these have limits. Why do we now need to include shape here, in trade marks with an unlimited time frame?

Customs argues that it is only for the marketing but, currently, there are huge disputes around design laws about the use of design, such as auto parts designed to create effectively monopoly markets in areas such as auto spare parts. The danger I see is that, in extending trademarks explicitly to shape and aspect of packaging, we open the door for claims of this sort.

The people who run trade marks and make the decisions have spoken to us and they have probably spoken to others. I have little doubt that they have integrity, recognise the dangers and will, as they say they will, exclude such claims. But the law will remain and they may not be there forever to make good decisions. Also there will be more and more appeals, where companies with a lot of money can see tremendous advantage if they create monopoly conditions through shape trade marks.
Debate interrupted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Yesterday you revealed—
—Where is your leader?
—He is on very important business overseas. Minister, yesterday you revealed that you have expressed serious concerns—
—We just thought we would give you a rousing welcome.

—I am glad you are in here today for the condolence motion. I am very grateful to you. I am sorry you were not here for the bulk of the morning. Minister, yesterday you revealed that you have expressed serious concerns about human rights abuses in the Freeport mine area of Irian Jaya to the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Ali Alatas. Is it a fact, however, that the Prime Minister has refused to do likewise when he meets President Suharto because he concedes that he simply could not refute allegations that the Aboriginal community has been denied basic human rights:

QUESTION.PARA: I mean, he could point to problems we have—prejudicial views about the Aboriginal community denying them equal opportunity and access—what would you say about that?

Putting aside this plea of guilty in relation to your government's failure to tackle the real problems afflicting the Aboriginal community of Australia, why shouldn't President Suharto simply conclude that, whilst you have gone through the proper motions, the Prime Minister is simply not serious about alleged human rights abuses in Irian Jaya?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt about the government's concern—not just my concern but the government's concern—about the human rights situation in Irian Jaya. And there is no doubt about the registering of that concern so far as the Indonesian government is concerned in the context of the oral exchange I have already had with my colleague Ali Alatas and the much more detailed written letter I sent to him just 24 hours ago.

PARA.TAB: As to whether the Prime Minister raises this or any other human rights issue when he meets President Suharto, that is a matter for his judgment. The Prime Minister's working visit to Indonesia on 17 September is basically for discussions with President Suharto on our important shared interests in APEC and achieving a good result at the leaders' meeting in Osaka in November, and a vast range of bilateral and regional issues.

It is not normally the practice to identify publicly in advance a full agenda of the issues that will be raised for discussion. It is the Prime Minister's practice not to be specific about all the matters that he raises. He does make clear however, and has made clear on many occasions, that his discussions with the President of Indonesia, which have now taken place on several occasions, cover all the dimensions of our relationship. I stress the word `all'. The Prime Minister has in the past discussed human rights questions but the subjects that he discusses with him are not set by the media, and the Prime Minister is not inclined to preview the course of his talks in public. It would often be unproductive—indeed counterproductive—to do so, particularly when sensitive questions are involved.

Beyond that, I have nothing more to say. That is my clear understanding of the Prime Minister's position. I think that should be the public understanding of it. No inferences should be drawn of the kind that Senator Alston was trying to draw.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The only problem with all that is that you say that the Prime Minister's discussions will cover all issues, which presumably is meant to incorporate human rights issues. But the Prime Minister himself says he won't. He says, `Why should I, because they might ask me about human rights abuses?' Surely that sends the worst possible signal to the Indonesians: why should they not regard it as simply a second-order issue if the Prime Minister of this country is not prepared to raise that matter with his opposite number? What advice have you given him? Have you told him that it is appropriate for him to make sure that he communicates the concerns you have put down in public, or have you simply told him, `Nudge, nudge; wink, wink. Don't worry. You don't have to worry about that issue. You talk about the more important things to you'? Is that the advice you have given him?
—Whatever advice I might give the Prime Minister is a matter for the Prime Minister and me. It is certainly not a matter for Senator Alston.

PARA.TAB: Our relationship with Indonesia covers a vast range of economic, social, cultural and strategic interests for both countries. It is the case that any discussions the Prime Minister has with the President do cover all those different dimensions of our relationship. Beyond that, it is not the Prime Minister's practice to specify in advance what particular subjects he is going to raise.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he has. He has said he has ruled this out.

—He has not said he has ruled it out. He is not going to respond to an agenda written for him by the media. He is certainly not going to respond to one written for him by the opposition. These are sensitive and difficult questions. I am totally confident to leave it up to the very good judgment, the excellent judgment, of the Prime Minister as to how, when, where and in what context and to what extent he raises it.

—My question is directed to Senator Cook in his capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer. My question is prompted by the national accounts figures which were released by the ABS yesterday. Is it correct that in the June quarter, in seasonally adjusted terms, the economy recorded year-on-year growth of 3.7 per cent? If so, this seems to indicate that we have had not only quite a few minutes of growth but many quarters and indeed years now. Fortunately, this positive situation conflicts with a great deal of talking down of the economy in some circles. Could the minister inform the Senate of the true nature and extent of the growth as demonstrated in the national accounts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Colston for his question. Anyone that opened any newspaper today would see that universally, across the board, all newspapers have hailed the publication of yesterday's national accounts as indicating a very strong and sustainable growth path for the Australian economy. Indeed, it makes a joke and a total mockery of the jibe by the opposition leader, Mr Howard, about five minutes of economic sunshine. We have in fact had many years of economic sunshine.

PARA.TAB: The good story here is that the Australian economy is continuing to grow, and grow on sustainable growth paths. This is the 16th consecutive quarter of growth; that is to say, four consecutive years of economic growth for Australia. It equals the record since quarterly estimates commenced in 1959; that is to say, a record not surpassed for 3 1/2 decades. It is a record and an achievement of which Australia, Australian business and Australian workers can be proud. It is a record for all Australians to be proud of.

While the government does recognise that some people are still doing it tough out there, this sort of sustainable growth represents the light at the end of the tunnel for many of them. You can only get rising living standards across the board if you get this sort of sustained economic growth. You certainly will not get it by sitting back and denigrating the efforts of Australian business, by producing artificial rhetoric about the battlers and without any policies whatsoever, as is the case with the opposition, to deliver any sort of economic outcome. You will not get it by the blundering doorstop interviews that Peter Costello, the shadow Treasurer, did yesterday in which he made a complete goose of himself by not being able to answer direct reporters' questions on the state of the Australian economy.

Let me go to the figures in the national accounts and see what we have from yesterday's publication. We have continued strength in consumer demand. Business investment is up 16 per cent in year average terms. Business profits are up four per cent. Household incomes are up six per cent. Inflation continues to hover at a low level, around 2 1/2 per cent. These are all figures and achievements of which Australians, as I said, should be proud.

The continuation of business investment growth over last year has been particularly pleasing. In 1994-95, plant and equipment investment grew by a record 21 per cent and, as Moody's, the international rating agency, has said:

ANSWER.PARA: This is not investment in real estate or speculation. This is productive investment—investment that raises the income and the wealth for ordinary Australians.
The trend labour productivity index rose by more than two per cent in the year to June 1995. Trend productivity has now been rising for four consecutive years—the longest continuous rise on record.

PARA.TAB: What of industry performance? Manufacturing production is up by more than four per cent over the year and services output was up by seven per cent. Within the service sector, output in the communications industry rose 17 per cent, wholesale trade was up 13 per cent and transport was up nine per cent. We continue to show impressive gains on the employment front. We are creating 1,000 jobs a day at the present rate. In the year to July 1995, 308,000 jobs were created and almost 700,000 jobs since July 1991.

This is an impressive record of economic achievement. This is an occasion for the national parliament and the people of Australia to be proud of that. It is a celebration by this government with its partners in industry and in the private sector. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the minister elaborate on the growth performance he has just outlined in the context of Tuesday's balance of payments figures for the month of July?

—The results to which I have just referred build on Tuesday's considerable improvement in the current account deficit as well. It is an especially pleasing outcome for the July trade figures, and it shows that exports are surging ahead after a temporary slowdown induced by the drought and the recession in some of Australia's major markets.

PARA.TAB: The July figures show trend improvement in the current account deficit for the first time since December 1993. The current account will continue to improve as rising national savings will be able to finance future investment in the Australian economy. The government's long-term vision for superannuation will ensure increased savings throughout the next 10 years and beyond.

In summary, what we are seeing in all these figures is the result of the government's efforts to make industry more competitive, to reduce barriers to competition, to allow greater flexibility in our markets, to boost productivity through enterprise bargaining and to raise efficiency in government business enterprises. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Gareth Evans, Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Solicitor-General's advice concerning the payment of Dr Lawrence's private legal fees in an attempt to scuttle the Marks royal commission is that a payment can legally be made out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. The coalition has advice from a very well respected QC that, to enable such a payment to be made, the minister must be satisfied that the expenditure is urgently required.
—Will you table the advice?

—Do you want me to? Fine. I will table it. The opinion seriously questions whether the expenditure can possibly be urgent. Given that the matter is now several months old, no payments have been made, and, as you said the other day, we have only at best made a contingent decision, how can the Minister for Finance possibly be satisfied that the payments are urgent? Isn't it, to use your phrase, the truth of the matter that such a claim is simply laughable and that the legality of the payments is seriously in question? Have you and your cabinet considered your own potential liability as a consequence of that? (Time expired)
—Is leave granted to table those documents?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is the quality of the legal advice the opposition is getting, this makes this inquiry that has been set up all the more a total farce and waste of time. There is no substance whatsoever in that assertion that has just been made. The requirement under the legislation is twofold—that the expenditure in question, in order to qualify for payment out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance, has to be both urgent and unforeseen.

PARA.TAB: The unforeseeability of this particular payment is self-evident, because nobody could have believed that anyone would be so crass, vulgar, disgraceful, squalid, opportunistic, sordid or contemptuous of the democratic process as to go down the path of making an executive decision to set up a royal commission of this utterly unprecedentedly squalid kind. That is the unforeseeable part of it.

Nobody could conceivably have anticipated that anyone would have the indecency to set in train an exercise of that kind. Also, of course, the unforeseeability will also be a function of the unforeseeability that anyone could be so indecent, squalid, despicable and contemptuous of process as not to make the payments themselves for all aspects of the legal process defence that might be involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the urgency?

—So if we get over the unforeseeable hurdles we will then have the urgency hurdle. It is a matter of judgment as to whether you regard it as reasonable that someone should be required to wait for the payment of their legal bills for up to nearly a year after those expenses have, in fact, been incurred, because if we have to wait for the formal appropriation to take place in the April-May budgetary context—that legislative authority, presumably, would not be in place until the end of June, if it is not to be regarded as urgent—the payment would not be able to be made until next year. In all the circumstances that is so manifestly unreasonable in terms of the legal creditors that would be here involved that there would be, unequivocally, an element of urgency such as to meet the normal way in which that particular test is applied.

PARA.TAB: `Urgent'just means in the normal course of governmental business or in the normal course of decency is required to be paid sooner rather than later. Of course, anyone who is a debtor can say there is no urgency about paying a bill that is due to a creditor—`Just let the creditor wait.' If you adopt that particular brand of morality, which is equivalent to every other brand of morality you have on parade in this place, then you might come to that conclusion. But I would like to see the person who wrote that advice—the QC, the silk, whoever it was—taking the view that he is perfectly happy to wait up to more than a year for his bills to be paid. If he is prepared to accept the logic of that particular statement, I would be very surprised indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, do I take it you are advancing two meanings for the word `urgent' that you believe would be adopted by the High Court: firstly, that the meaning that would be attributed to `urgent' by the High Court is whatever cabinet decides is appropriate or, secondly, that `urgent' means, in the normal course of business, sooner rather than later?
—You really don't listen, do you?
—No, she is thick.

—Yes, metaphorically. There are ample precedents that I am aware of, and no doubt many more I am not aware of, which would justify this kind of payment being so regarded. The finance department, who have had the custody and control of these arrangements for a long time, have never been under any doubt at all, to my certain knowledge, that there is any problem so far as satisfying the criteria of the AMF are concerned.

PARA.TAB: There was a doubt about the issue of section 48 of the constitution which did need checking. That doubt was resolved, but there are no other grounds for doubt about this.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, and the question is in two parts: firstly, has the minister's attention been drawn to the worsening drought situation in New South Wales and, given that situation in New South Wales and of the continuing severe drought in Queensland, can the minister advise the Senate on the federal government's response? Secondly, has the minister's attention also been drawn to a media statement issued by the Deputy Leader of the National Party which claims that the coalition's policy, or non-policy, triggered this government's response to the drought?

—The New South Wales state agriculture minister, Mr Amery, indeed announced in the last 24 hours that drought could extend to 80 per cent of New South Wales by October if the much hoped for rains failed to come by then. Indeed, farmers are in an absolutely critical period now—if the crops do not get a drink in the next two to three weeks they will die. It was very soul-destroying for the farmers concerned in having their hopes raised, along with the rest of us, earlier this year with the rain that allowed them to plant the crop and finding the follow-up rains, to this point in time anyway, not having fallen.

PARA.TAB: The drought declarations in New South Wales were in fact falling. Unfortunately, we are now in the situation where they could increase to 80 per cent of the state in the next couple of weeks if it does not rain. I spoke to the New South Wales Premier, Mr Carr, yesterday about the situation. I reiterated to Mr Carr the Prime Minister's pledge that federal financial assistance to farming families will continue as long as it is needed. The Prime Minister also made this clear in public statements which he issued along the same lines in Sydney yesterday.

The same applies to Queensland, where more than a third of the state is still drought stricken. I noticed the other day a press statement from the President of the Australian Grain Growers Association, Ian McFarlane, which confirmed that in a meeting I had with him last week I gave the pledge that, as long as farmers are in need in the state of Queensland, government assistance will continue to be provided.

As for the second part of the question, I was fascinated to read Mr Anderson's press statement because it confirmed precisely what I said to the Senate, which was that the federal opposition leader did dump the coalition's drought policy in Roma this week. Mr Anderson's 20-paragraph statement did not once mention his own policy. It was an extraordinary press statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —No policy?

—No, it never mentioned it. There were 20 paragraphs attacking me and not one single mention of his own drought policy. Mr Howard officially buried this policy in Roma. I remind the Senate that Mr Anderson issued this policy, I think, a year ago yesterday. He described it then as a blueprint the government must adopt.

PARA.TAB: It contains significant policy differences to that of the government and that is why we did not adopt it. It advocated the immediate introduction of a fodder subsidy scheme, a return of severe drought to the natural disaster relief arrangements and, importantly, the proposal that the exceptional circumstances definitions be provided to farmers who have experienced extreme drought in two of the past three years.

None of those policies would ever seriously be considered, let alone adopted, by this government. The return of severe drought to the natural disaster relief arrangements is completely at odds with the national drought policy re-endorsed by the Commonwealth and all state governments, both Labor and conservative, only two weeks ago in Perth. One of the fundamental reasons we will not adopt the coalition's drought policy today—and this should be of interest to Senator Sandy Macdonald, as a senator from New South Wales—is that we would have to cut off thousands of families from drought relief tomorrow using that criteria.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. The minister has referred to the opposition leader's statement in Roma. The minister would be aware of the opposition leader's statement in Roma that fighting the effects of the drought is something that ought to transcend party political point scoring and petty argument. I ask the minister: do you agree with the statement by the opposition leader?

—I do. In fact, I made the point that I do agree with one thing that Mr Howard said in Roma and that is that this should transcend party politics. That message does not seem to have got through to his colleagues here in the Senate on either the front or back bench. I think that has been demonstrated.
—Fair go.

—Do not protest too much. You only have to have a look at the Senate Notice Paper. Senator Tierney has a motion on the Senate Notice Paper which purports to condemn us by quoting directly from a report entitled `The drought project strategy'. No such report exists. Part (d) of Senator Tierney's motion actually purports to quote directly from the report. The quotes do not exist and the report does not exist. The report is a working paper which is entitled `An approach for analysing financial viability and risk on farms', and contains none of the quotes in Senator Tierney's motion. He was quite happy to put that on the Notice Paper. Senator Tierney, we sent you a copy of the report. You know that you are wrong. When are you going to withdraw the notice of motion?

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. In view of the release of the report Australia's plantations and in view of the agreement by the executive director of the National Association of Forest Industries on Lateline last week that plantation harvests will double in the next 10 years, I ask: will the government now, firstly, act promptly to use this opportunity to reduce the pressure on native forests and protect significant tracts of forests before the next federal election; and, secondly, use the increasing supply of plantation wood as the basis for a far-reaching structural adjustment package to assist workers in the declining native forest industry to take up new employment opportunities in the plantation industry?

—The government has already announced that we will be taking initiatives. There is a lot of work going into them right now to increase the already rapidly increasing extent of plantations in Australia. I know that the question is prompted by the recent report that claimed that plantation timber could displace the need for logging in native forests. The consultant who wrote that report argued that the expansion of the softwood plantation processing sector will displace the native forests sector. However, the conclusion was based solely on an analysis of the plantations sector. There was no analysis of the native forest based industries.

PARA.TAB: The full utilisation and expansion of our plantation resource is a national forest policy statement objective to which the government is strongly committed. We do not believe, however, that the full utilisation and expansion of the plantation resource can be logically linked to a complete end to native forest based industries. The government's objective is to support an internationally competitive, value added industry based on the ecologically sustainable use and management of native forests and plantations.

A framework to achieve this objective is being developed through the wood and paper industry strategy that is currently being finalised. The fundamental native forest conservation issues are the establishment of a national reserve system and national standards to ensure ecologically sustainable practices outside these reserves. The government is actively pursuing this commitment with the states.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. I was unable to determine from the answer whether the new plantation resources will be used as an add-on to existing supplies or a substitute for that wood which is obtained from native forest sources?

—There is no question that, at the end of the day, plantation timber will supplant a lot of the timber that is currently being produced. But we are not in the happy position, at the moment, of being able to close down overnight that native timber resource because it simply cannot be provided from the existing plantation resources. Frankly, Senator Bell knows that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I understand that the Western Australian property development company Cedar Woods Properties Ltd has recently written to you giving their assurance that the environmentally valuable parts of the Creery wetlands in Mandurah in Western Australia can be protected. Can the minister confirm the details of the company's undertaking? Can he assure the Senate and the people of Mandurah that this environmentally sensitive area will be protected?

—I am pleased to confirm that I received a letter from Cedar Woods Properties Ltd this morning. The company has given me an assurance that it will fully protect the important areas within the Creery wetlands at Mandurah in south-west Western Australia. I strongly welcome the assurance that it has given. Cedar Woods has also agreed to enter into negotiations for a memorandum of understanding with the state and Commonwealth governments and the Mandurah City Council to manage these important wetlands for the long term. This is a far better outcome than the Commonwealth being forced to unilaterally list the area with the Ramsar convention.

PARA.TAB: The company's decision comes after months of negotiations with the Commonwealth. The decision also follows on a referendum and local council elections which indicated very strong community support for the Creery wetlands.

We have made our position on this quite clear from the outset. We made it clear to Cedar Woods that we will act to ensure that the Ramsar listed Peel inlet wetlands system is protected. The Creery wetlands is an integral part of this wetlands system. It is essential to protect Creery if we are to properly protect the whole wetlands system.

Creery wetlands, along with the rest of the Peel-Harvey estuary, forms part of the principal migration stopover area and, arguably, the principal drought refuge area for waterbirds in the south-west of Western Australia. It contains valuable salt marshes. It is in the top one per cent of south-west Western Australian wetlands in terms of waterbird species diversity and in the top two per cent in terms of waterbird numbers. Some of these species are listed for protection under the Japan-Australia and the China-Australia migratory bird agreements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer because it will allay the great concern in the Mandurah community about this matter. Can the minister advise whether or not the cooperative solution to this particular instance of management of Australia's wetlands might be applied to other problems around Australia and whether this might prove a role model?

—The company's decision signals a breakthrough in the approach to the management of Australia's internationally important wetlands. This is of particular significance in the lead-up to the Ramsar conference. Cedar Woods has taken a responsible environmental decision, and I think it is one that will stand the company in good stead and will be welcomed by the whole community. Their decision offers us a great opportunity to work constructively for the long-term management of those wetlands.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Nature Conservation Agency has already provided a draft memorandum of understanding for the consideration of the company, the state government and the local council. The draft MOU proposes that the important parts of Creery wetland should be designated an A-class nature reserve under Western Australian legislation. I have no doubt that the company's assurance guarantees that this area will be protected. The precise details of how that will occur will be a matter for negotiation and development under the memorandum of understanding.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Evans as Leader of the Government in the Senate and representing the Prime Minister. Is it not a fact that Dr Carmen Lawrence's expenses for her appearance before the royal commission will be met through the WA office of the Solicitor-General? Is it not a fact that the guidelines by which Dr Lawrence applied are the very same guidelines that her own Attorney-General tabled in the WA parliament in 1990 for her own royal commission? Is it not a fact that her very own guidelines put in place for her WA Inc. royal commission did not provide funding for appeals in other courts? Minister, in all your government's bagging of the WA government over expenses, are you saying that the rules should be changed just for Dr Lawrence?

—I am not aware that Dr Lawrence has received any formal advice or, for that matter, informal advice from the Western Australian government to the effect that she will be paid all the expenses that she incurs even for her appearances before the commission itself. I know a question has been raised about her briefing of interstate counsel in this particular matter, and other questions have also been raised with it.

PARA.TAB: There has been no definitive response even on the question of fees incurred before the commission, at least not one that I was aware of a couple of days ago when I last checked that particular matter. In that respect, she has ample grounds for complaint as does the Commonwealth that this matter is still unresolved as she continues to incur expenses day by day. One hopes that the Western Australian government will meet its obligations in that respect whether under those guidelines or under anything else.

So far as the additional costs that have been incurred in collateral proceedings, I am not aware whether there were any collateral proceedings in those earlier cases or whether the question has ever previously risen in WA. It has certainly risen in plenty of other jurisdictions. Mr Greiner went off to the courts to challenge the jurisdiction of ICAC as that affected him in New South Wales, and that tab was picked up by the Liberal government in New South Wales. It was certainly the case in Tasmania that when Mr Gray went off on a collateral frolic to challenge the jurisdiction of the Rouse royal commission, that tab was picked up by the government in question. Where there have been precedents of which I have been aware in other jurisdictions, the tab has been picked up.

There is nothing magic about guidelines. The guidelines are only a guide, as their appearance implies. It is a matter entirely for the discretion of the government of the day whether it ranges beyond those and makes a separate ad hoc payment. The guidelines that exist at the Commonwealth level, as we have made clear and which were the subject of a great deal of fulmination and carry on earlier on, were guidelines that applied only to defence of legal proceedings properly so called—criminal matters and civil litigation. They are silent on the question of royal commissions.

Equally, I am prepared to accept what you say that the Western Australian guidelines are silent on the question of support for collateral proceedings. But the fact that they might be silent does not mean that it is beyond the capacity of the Western Australian executive government to meet a need which is legitimately incurred in this particular instance.

Anyone who is on the receiving end of this kind of witch hunt—this kind of mean spirited, miserable, despicable, contemptible exercise in abuse of executive power, which is what this establishment of a royal commission amounts to—is entitled to challenge that when it goes to the validity, the propriety and the proper exercise of the jurisdiction in question. Those opposite are supposed to have some regard for the principles of parliamentary privilege and some understanding of the concept of cabinet confidentiality. I do not expect you will ever have to experience that in practice.

I would have thought that those opposite who are aware of the existence of these principles and have some regard for them would understand the absolute legitimacy of a challenge being mounted to the operations of the commission which have reference and regard to the overriding character of those principles and which rule out a number of aspects of the royal commission's competence. It is perfectly reasonable under those circumstances to be mounting the kind of attack upon the commission that Dr Lawrence has mounted.

Under all those circumstances, I think the question is utterly empty and utterly without substance. The Western Australian government should accept its obligations to cover the whole range of funding that is involved, stop ducking and weaving and make it unnecessary for the Commonwealth to even have to consider the question of supplementary funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. In other words, Minister, you are saying that in fact the rules should be changed precisely and only for Dr Lawrence? Could I also ask you this: is it not also a fact that her guidelines only allow for ministers of the Crown, staffers of those ministers, and public servants at the time to be entitled to assistance? Is it not a fact that it was limited to those people, which meant that nobody from the opposition could get assistance—or anybody else for that matter? Isn't that the reason why John Halden cannot get expenses with regard to his position before the royal commission? Is that not because of the restrictions that she put in her own guidelines?
—You are always saying what a wonderful, civilised lot you are. Why should you feel yourselves bound by any restrictions that might have been put in there by your predecessors?

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to his answer to my question without notice regarding ATSIC being accepted by the UN as a non-government agency and I ask: does the government continue to hold to the view that ATSIC is an NGO despite the decision of Justice Hill in the Federal Court yesterday where he found sufficient jurisdiction over the board of ATSIC under the ADJR Act to set aside the decision of the ATSIC board to allocate $10 million of the $12 million of land acquisition money to the Northern Territory?

—I am sure the UN NGO committee will be deeply moved by that particular judgment that you refer to. I cannot believe that it would have any significance in terms of the application of the committee's criteria. The committee was fully aware of the nature of ATSIC's role and the statutory foundation for it and the character of its existence. The committee made its judgment accordingly. I don't think they will be in the slightest bit tempted to change their view as a result of what happened yesterday.

—If ATSIC is an NGO, why is the Australian Government Solicitor representing ATSIC in a Federal Court action seeking a declaration that ATSIC has exceeded its power in seeking and obtaining NGO status at the UN? As a consequence of your answer, Minister, what does it say about the status of other NGO bodies which the United Nations accepts and the access that our indigenous people and indigenous people all round the world have if they have a problem with a government statutory agency being the peak body for NGO questions?

—There is no reason to believe that the system that has been applied by the UN in this respect would be revisited by the UN in the light of this further information and these further developments. The UN has its system for dealing with what it likes to call NGOs. There are other criteria and other considerations that apply in other contexts.

PARA.TAB: The important thing is that ATSIC be able to express its views on behalf of indigenous Australians at the highest levels within the UN system. I am very surprised, Senator Chamarette, that even with your well-known distaste for ATSIC in this respect you should want to deny an Australian representative of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people that kind of access at that kind of senior level in the UN system. All you seem to want to do is claw down the capacity of our own indigenous people to be effectively represented in those bodies. I do not know what sort of triumph that represents for whatever constituency you purport to represent in that respect, but I do not think it does you much honour to pursue the matter in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Bob Collins. Did the minister state on Tuesday that the coalition's drought policy had been condemned outright by peak national farming organisations across Australia? Is it not a fact that this statement is totally untrue? Is it not also a fact that the substance of the coalition's policies for drought income assistance, drought preparedness and drought exceptional circumstances was implemented by the government? Will the minister apologise for misleading the parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that, if I wanted an illustration about what I was just talking about, I could not have provided a better illustration if I had written that question myself.
—You probably did.

—No, it is not a dorothy dixer, Senator Robert Ray. It is another pathetic attempt to score political points—just what Mr Howard said you should not be doing, Ron—and to take attention away from the opposition's policy and dishonesty of dumping their policy without actually telling anyone.

PARA.TAB: Yes, I did say that to the Senate. I did say that it had been condemned outright by farm groups right across Australia the day it came out, and it is true. I have a file in my office that I am happy to make available to you, Senator Boswell. There is not enough time to do it now, but I think it might be summed up by what the Country Hour said the day the policy came out. I quote from the Country Hour transcript:

ANSWER.PARA: To Canberra, where the coalition's so-called new drought policy has received a distinct thumbs down from the sector it's supposed to benefit.

It is a fact: it was condemned outright. But why was it condemned? The reason it was condemned was because the day it was announced I discovered, to my astonishment, that the shadow minister had not bothered to spend five minutes consulting with a single industry body in Australia—not one.
