He had not been to the Grains Council. He had not talked to the National Farmers Federation. He had, in fact, talked to nobody. There had been no consultation in putting it together.

PARA.TAB: I will tell you, Senator Boswell, the fundamental reason why I will not adopt your policy, particularly dot point three of it. It is a fact that, particularly in New South Wales, if I adopted it, the majority of families that are now receiving our assistance would not be getting it. If I adopted your policy on exceptional circumstances today, as I just said a few minutes ago, I would have to throw out tomorrow thousands of families getting assistance.

Your policy was condemned because you did not consult. But what did the Leader of the Opposition, your leader, say as well as saying you should not been scoring points on this and you should give the government credit where credit is due? He also said that he supported or would press the government to continue its existing relief. But, as far as an opposition policy was concerned, he said he would sit down with farmers after the election and consult them about putting a drought policy together. Read the speech.

Mr Anderson, in that extraordinary press release I talked about, actually said that the brilliant initiative of sitting down with the farmers to discuss with them after the election what the policy should be arose from a discussion he had had with Mr Howard. Wow! Read the press statement. So we have now moved from the extraordinary position of a year ago where we had a policy from the opposition with no consultation to today where we have got consultation with no policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have just condemned yourself. Did the National Farmers Federation last November adopt a resolution seeking the implementation of a national core breeding livestock retention grant? Was such a program endorsed by other farm bodies? Don't these endorsements and the government's own adoption of our measures put the lie to the minister's claim that the coalition's policy was condemned outright by national peak farming organisations and prove that he has misled parliament? I seek leave to table press releases from the New South Wales Farmers Federation and the Cattlemen's Union.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that I have proved that you completely misled the parliament by these press releases, will you, therefore, abjectly grovel and apologise to Mr Anderson?

—I will say no to the second one because I have to tell you, Ron, that neither you nor I are built to grovel, mate. I am glad Senator Boswell mentioned the New South Wales Farmers Association policy. Yes, I am very familiar with it. It was sent to the National Farmers Federation with no detail and no costing. We did a rough estimate on it. The NFF sent it back to the New South Wales Farmers Association and said, `Fill in the blanks.' We did a rough costing of it. Roughly, it would have cost $50 million a month to fund. I have not heard of it since, Senator Boswell, until you raised it now. It has not been brought again to my attention by the National Farmers Federation. So I assume that, when they sent it back to the New South Wales Farmers Association to fill in the blanks, it never actually returned.

—My question is to the Minister for Family Services. Has the minister seen comments by an American sociologist, Professor Brigitte Berger, that Australia is putting its prosperity at risk by devaluing the nuclear family? Given that she is an American academic, how are these comments relevant to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Neal for her question, because I have seen reports on comments that the visiting American sociologist, Professor Berger, has made along the lines that Senator Neal outlined in her question. With due respect to Professor Berger, I think she may be unaware of the enormous difference between the circumstances of families in Australia and in the United States. Just as importantly, the evidence suggests that the trends in Australia are not at all similar to those in the USA. So we should not expect that we are moving in the same direction as the United States.

PARA.TAB: I would note, for example, that the United States has the highest divorce rate in the Western world. It is 91 per cent higher than in Australia. While there was a jump in the divorce rate following the introduction of the Family Law Act in 1975, the divorce rate in Australia has fallen since 1983. The proportion of divorces involving children has also fallen from 63 per cent to 53 per cent since 1983.

In Australia, the rate of teenage births has fallen dramatically. In 1971, around 5.5 per cent of teenage girls gave birth, and it is now about 2.1 per cent. In the USA over the same period, the rate fell only from 6.2 to six per cent; that is, the teenage birth rate in the USA is nearly three times higher than in Australia.

In common with many countries, we have seen increases in the proportion of births outside formal marriage. But, in Australia, the majority of fathers actually acknowledge their paternity—over 80 per cent—whereas in the USA only one-third do. This makes a very significant difference if you look at the amount of money that is paid through our Child Support Agency on behalf of children by the non-custodial parent father compared with figures in the USA. In the USA, the figure is about 17 per cent; whereas in Australia, it is over 70 per cent.

We have got policies that are putting considerable effort into improving the position of families, particularly families with children, sole parents and two-parent families. We have increased the real level of benefits for a sole parent with one child in private rental by 27 per cent and for an unemployed couple with children by more than 31 per cent. A low income working family has had increases in its real disposable income of between 25 and 40 per cent. Today in the Australian, the editorial includes the following statement:

ANSWER.PARA: In other ways, however, the evolution and refinement of government social wage policies has promoted the family and subsidised the raising of children. Through targeted family payments, such as the new maternity allowance and a home childcare allowance, the building of childcare facilities and national health insurance—

successive Labor governments have provided a solid safety net to protect families. And unlike other social democratic countries, in Australia these policies have generally been rooted in sound fiscal policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to Senator Bolkus representing Duncan Kerr, the Minister for Justice. I refer to claims by Mr Eoin Cameron, the member for Stirling, that his office was raided by Australian Federal Police as a result of a complaint by me and that the raid was politically motivated. Conscious as I am of the proper reluctance of the Australian Federal Police to comment on operational matters, I ask the minister whether he is able to confirm: first, that I made no specific complaint to the Australian Federal Police about Mr Cameron; second, that the execution of the search warrant was as a result of the AFP's own inquiries and investigations; and, third, that such warrants are only issued and executed with the most careful, proper and serious consideration.

—I want to pick up on part of Senator Crichton-Browne's question. It is, of course, normal policy not to confirm or deny whether a particular matter is under investigation. In this case, I can say that the AFP have already publicly confirmed that they are investigating complaints made by you. I am advised that the complaint was made on 15 June 1995 and that, as publicised already, it relates to threatening facsimile messages. As for individuals, Senator Crichton-Browne, I think you would understand that I am not able to comment on the specific details of your complaint, including against whom that complaint was made.

PARA.TAB: With respect to the search warrants, I can say that in the course of their investigations into your complaint the AFP have executed search warrants. The seeking of search warrants is not a matter lightly undertaken by the police, as everyone here would understand. I am unable to comment on the specifics of the investigation. I can say that the process for obtaining search warrants is governed by statutory provisions and, of course, a significant amount of case law. The police must have sufficient information to satisfy a justice of the peace or a magistrate that a search warrant should be issued. They are not easily obtained, they are subject to challenge in court and they need to be based on adequacy of evidence. They also need to be exercised and executed in accordance with strict legal requirements.

I also cannot comment on the specific details of any particular search warrant executed by the AFP in the course of their investigation. I am advised, however, that in relation to your complaint the AFP is investigating possible breaches of section 85ZE of the Crimes Act 1914 which relates to harassing or menacing via telecommunications services and section 28 of the Crimes Act 1914 which relates to interfering with political liberty. As I said, Senator Crichton-Browne, I cannot go to specifics as against whom the complaint was made and operational details, but I can give you that framework of operation which governs the Australian Federal Police in matters like this.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. As this is Child Protection Week, I ask the minister: is he aware of Mr Justice Fogarty's continuing criticism of the Victorian government's child protection services and, secondly, of the recent report by Mr Allan Morris MP documenting the number of homeless youth as the same or greater than the 20,000 identified in 1989 by the then Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin? What specific action is the minister prepared to take in both these instances? More specifically, is the minister prepared to legislate the international covenant on the rights of the child in domestic law, as recommended by the National Children's and Youth Law Centre, which the government is funding?

—Yes, I am aware of Mr Justice Fogarty's continuing criticism of the Victorian government's child protection services. He is one of many voices in a long and extensive chorus of criticism in this area. I am also aware of the Morris committee report on aspects of youth homelessness. The Youth Bureau in the Department of Employment, Education and Training has responsibility for coordinating the preparation of the response to this report. That response is due by the end of the year. In respect of the federal government's response to this particularly important and sensitive area, I think the senator would appreciate that the way to tackle this particular problem is through diverse policy initiatives. I will get for him from the relevant ministers a coordinated answer on those problems which go, for instance, to initiatives through the justice statement, initiatives on child abuse, initiatives on youth homelessness and the like. Hopefully I will be in a position to give you that answer very soon.

PARA.TAB: We take our obligations under the Convention on the Rights of the Child seriously. That is why, in 1993, we decided that the convention should be an international instrument for the purposes of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act. As such, the commission can now inquire into Commonwealth acts, practices and legislation that are inconsistent or contrary to that convention. The commission can also conduct research on the basis of that instrument. We have no current intention of legislating the Convention on the Rights of the Child into domestic law, I can say that as well. With respect to most of your question, Senator, I will take that part on notice, and I will come back to you with the raft of initiatives the government has taken on a wide range of policy areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice. Does the government disagree with evidence which has been presented to the Hanson inquiry that the AFP failed to properly interview seven key witnesses identified in Operation Wallah; that the AFP effectively ran dead in relation to a key witness by telling him, before they interviewed him, that there was no evidence against him, and that passages contained in the AFP's Operation Gallon report, referring to a key witness, were deleted? In view of this very disturbing evidence, does the government still maintain its charade that the AFP's investigations of matters arising from Operation Wallah was, to quote Minister Kerr, `thorough and entirely proper'? Why should the public not agree with eminent criminologist Professor Paul Wilson that, `It seems investigations into powerful political figures are not pursued with the same vigour as those involving the average citizen'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm with you, Senator Chapman, that there is a charade going on here. The charade is in fact on the opposition side, and the charade is that you are honest and clean and take a new approach to government and policy in this area. The charade that John Howard has brought in a new approach to the parliament and to procedures in the parliament and to the protection of rights and the reputations of individuals is the charade going on here, and you have been allowed to continue with this charade for a number of months now, let me say, in a way that has seen an organised question time, one where you ask questions which have been sanctioned by your leadership. The charade is that John Howard is as tacky as the rest of you because he allows this behaviour to continue. That is the charade.
—On a point of order, Mr President: this question was not a licence for Senator Bolkus to tip personal abuse—
—I was asked about a charade.

—You were not asked about charades in general; you were asked about a very specific charade. Mr President, you know very well that he is not in any shape or form answering the question. I would have thought it was an open and shut case of a refusal to comply with the standing orders. The question of relevance applies, and he ought to answer that question and nothing else.
—Order! You are digressing, Minister. I would ask you to get back to the point.

—Let me say to you, Senator Chapman, and anyone else who may be interested in this little interventionist sleaze, that the AFP often investigates politically sensitive matters. At the conclusion of inquiries they sometimes brief the Minister for Justice who, of course, has no right, nor should he have any right, to intervene at any stage of the process.

PARA.TAB: Let me also refer you to evidence from the Commissioner of Police, not just in estimates committees of this parliament but evidence which he put before the Hanson committee and statements he has made publicly. As far as he is concerned, and the government relies on the assurances of Mr Mick Palmer, the Commissioner of Police, this was an exhaustive and extensive inquiry by the AFP, and one which should be acknowledged. In terms of whether it was a cursory investigation or not, this is what Mick Palmer said:

ANSWER.PARA: There have also been claims that the AFP investigation was cursory, and that it lasted only a few weeks, and was conducted by junior staff. The reality is that the investigation took some seven months, was handled by some of our most experienced investigators. Between them these investigators have over 60 years experience.
In terms of the comprehensive nature of it, let me also place on record his belief that the AFP had properly investigated all the offences involved. When appearing before the inquiry he said:
There was no cover-up, there was no cutting of corners. This is a very objective, comprehensive and completely thorough investigation.

Senator Chapman, you have been told this before. You asked police commissioner Mick Palmer a number of questions extending over a number of hours with respect to this. You have to cop his evidence, Senator Chapman, otherwise you are the one who should be accused of coming in here and spreading misinformation in the interests of damaging the reputation of innocent officials. That is the standard that the opposition applies; that is the standard on which they should be judged.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr President. He is doing it again. He is attacking Senator Chapman's motives and reputation and not answering the question.
—I thought he had completed answering the question. Do you want to continue, Senator Bolkus?
—No.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. At the conclusion of his answer the minister referred to Mr Palmer appearing before Senate estimates committees in May of this year. In addition to putting to him again the three particular issues which I raised regarding the failure to properly interview seven key witnesses, effectively running dead in relation to a key witness and passages being deleted from the Operation Gallon report, which he failed to answer a moment ago—the key parts of my first question—I refer him to further evidence to the Hanson inquiry that Mr Palmer did indeed provide misleading answers to me before that estimates committee. He may like to deal with all four issues this time and answer the questions directly.

—I did answer some questions. Let me refer you, Senator Chapman, to a press statement of Commissioner Palmer on 23 August with respect to the Gallon report. I would presume someone who takes an interest in this matter, like you do, would take an objective interest and maybe take into account the comments made by the federal government's most senior law enforcement officer when he says with respect to Operation Gallon that there were arrangements that governed the release of information there, relations that go very much to the operational processes between law enforcement agencies and, as a consequence, as often happens, some information could not be made available because it would bring into question our relationship with other law enforcement agencies in other operations. That is the reason why Operation Gallon was not published in full.

PARA.TAB: We are talking here about the most senior law enforcement officer in the government. We have also been asked to answer questions of an operational nature. The government's position is that the senior law enforcement officer of the government has responsibility. We do not, like you, trundle through the bottom of garbage cans to find out why someone was or was not investigated. That is the basis of my answer. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Environment, Sport and Territories. Media reports have recently quoted Robert de Castella as saying that the health, fitness and coordination of young Australians has deteriorated.
—And the older ones.

—We will come to the older ones later. Other reports have previously suggested that participation in sport in Australia is on the decline. Can the minister comment on what the government is doing to promote sport participation and fitness in this country, particularly amongst young people.

—The government is committed to taking a strong and active leadership role in encouraging a sport for all philosophy and ensuring that all Australians have access to a wide range of sporting opportunities at all levels of interest and ability. Through the ASC the government has developed a number of participation initiatives that are aimed at increasing participation and indirectly the health and well-being of Australians. In particular, I would like to highlight the Aussie sports program, which has made a significant contribution to the sporting programs and experiences of Australian children at school and in their local school sports clubs. It has an emphasis on fun and skill development, rather than just targeting those children who have particular natural sporting abilities. It is critical to lifelong participation that children have positive and enjoyable experiences of sport so that they choose to have active lifestyles beyond their school years.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you have mentioned the Aussie sports program. Has that received international recognition?

—Interestingly enough, the quality and success of the Aussie sports initiative has received international recognition. I am pleased to advise the Senate that the ASC has won the UNESCO award for distinguished services to physical education and sport. That is something which on that side of the chamber I am sure they are very contemptuous about. But on this side of the chamber and right around the country I am sure there is a lot of pride that that award has been won by the Sports Commission.

PARA.TAB: This award is presented by the UNESCO intergovernmental committee on physical education and sport. It is the first time that any Australian institution or individual has won this award. I think it is very clear recognition that the Aussie sports program is providing the youth of Australia with the best possible introduction to sporting experiences available in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Crowley, the Minister for Family Services. In Mr Keating's Agenda for Families he promised to provide a strong, sound economy. How strong and sound can our economy be when we have a current account deficit hitting over $3.1 billion in May and over $2 billion for 11 consecutive months, and foreign debt rising $12 billion to a record $180 billion in just three months? How secure can Australian families feel when, under Mr Keating, Australia is carrying this massive debt for every man, woman and child in this country?
—I am not sure that this is in your area of responsibility, Senator Crowley, but I leave it to you as to whether you want to answer it or not.
—Mr President, thank you for that. The first point is to say that the question, as written, is much more appropriately addressed to Senator Cook.
—And Senator Evans.

—Certainly, to the Leader of the Government. It is a very important and timely question because of the splendid answer that Senator Cook has given about these matters today. He has told us just what are the benefits of the continuing sustainable good growth in this country.

PARA.TAB: As you were quoting from the Australian Agenda for Families, Senator Troeth, let me remind you that this is the first time ever that there has been a document about families associated with our budget. It came out of the International Year of the Family. It does point to strong, sustainable growth. That is what Minister Cook has said today. That is what those figures show. That is what this government is so proud to have at the moment.

Those figures do not allow me to talk about the other things that this government's policies are also doing for families. They are not part of your question, Senator. If you want to ask me about those, ask me again.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook. I note that the minister has announced the signing of three information technology partnership agreements this week, with Olivetti, the Dell corporation and Pitney Bowes. Can the minister tell the Senate what significance these agreements have for Australia? More importantly, I ask why the minister believes these companies have put their faith in the Australian information technology sector.

—The reason why they have chosen Australia to set up as major players in our market is that we are a competitive site. We are a very competitive site in terms of highly skilled people and we are a very competitive site in terms of cost. We have one of the biggest information technology sectors in the whole Asia-Pacific area. The value of the three agreements all up is an investment of $146 million by the three companies in information technology development in Australia; $88 million by Pitney Bowes, $39 million by the Dell corporation and $19 million by Olivetti.

PARA.TAB: The Pitney Bowes $88 million will be over four years and will include the export of mailing equipment and systems and local development of hardware and software. This activity will substantially increase their overall level of activity in Australia and will concentrate several of their international-regional activities in Australia. The second agreement, with the Dell corporation, is committed to developing Australian information technology by investing and exporting from Australia. They will be employing an additional 46 people over four years, to meet the advantage of the $39 million they are investing as a corporation. Olivetti will be putting in $19 million, creating an additional 40 to 50 high technology jobs as part of the company's overall push in the marketplace.

These are companies that have chosen Australia. After refereeing the best sites in the world, they have decided to come here. These are international corporations that discriminate. We have passed the test, which is some indication that the rest of the world sees us as a highly competitive economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer, but I was particularly interested in whether the minister could tell us what significance this might have for Australia's economic position in Asia.

—Australia is the second largest information technology market in Asia after Japan. If you take Japan out of the Asian region, we have 50 per cent of the information technology market in the whole of the region. We are twice as big as Korea. We are a more significant site than any other country in the area. This is the fastest growing industry in the world. Australia is ideally placed to be in the leadership of that industry.
—I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

PARA.TAB: Contingent motion (by Senator Margetts) proposed:

That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Margetts moving a motion that questions may be put to Ministers until 28 questions, including supplementary questions, have been asked and answered.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had 28 questions.

PARA.TAB: Amendment (by Senator Alston) proposed:
Omit ", including supplementary questions,.".

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government, of course, will be opposing this motion. Let us be very clear about what we have here today. This is the opposition smarting because they were done over in question time yesterday; smarting because they came up with the tactic in question time to say, `We will abrogate our right to have question time. What we will do is move a censure on Senator Gareth Evans. We won't have any questions,' and did so understanding full well that the consequence of moving that censure motion would be that there would be no question time.

PARA.TAB: Of course, what we had yesterday, instead of one hour's question time, was a three-hour censure debate in this chamber. That is what occurred. The geniuses, the tactics committee on the other side, that have run out of questions today, decided yesterday to derail question time when Senator Gareth Evans made it very clear that your question time would be forgone. What was said yesterday by the minor parties? They said, `Oh, we weren't consulted. We object, government; we weren't consulted by the opposition.' You haven't consulted us today, Senator Margetts, you hypocrite. You haven't consulted us. How dare you come in here—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask for the word `hypocrite' to be withdrawn. Senator Faulkner is quite aware of the fact that, first of all, we put on notice that we were concerned about the loss of questions yesterday, and we did—
—You have made your point of order.
—No, I haven't got my sentence finished.
—If you have a personal explanation, you can make it later. You have made your point of order about the word `hypocrite'.
—I ask for the word `hypocrite' to be withdrawn.
—Would you withdraw that word, Senator Faulkner? There is plenty of precedent.
—If it is unparliamentary, Mr President, I withdraw it. It is nothing more or less than double standards to talk—
—You will withdraw it unconditionally.
—I withdraw it, Mr President, unconditionally. Any way you would like it withdrawn, I will withdraw it. You suit yourself.
—You grub.
—Mr President, I ask that Senator Alston be made to withdraw his last statement.
—I didn't hear what was said.
—`You grub' was the expression used across the table.
—I don't care what they say.
—I care. I want to maintain some standards in this place.
—Senator Gareth Evans has requested that Senator Alston be made to withdraw his comment.
—I withdraw, but I also think you ought to at least protect yourself if you are going to allow him to talk in those terms and not withdraw things, except in the most scurrilous fashion.
—You are doing the same thing yourself now. I would ask you to withdraw unconditionally, too.

—So, of course, there is no consideration for the fact that ministers on this side of the chamber in fact do have schedules—we do have a cabinet meeting this afternoon. There is no consideration of these issues. When other changes are proposed to the sitting hours or the routine of business in this chamber, you always oppose them. You are never willing to sit one extra minute in this place—never!—for the good order of this particular chamber. Never are you willing to make a compromise.

PARA.TAB: The notice of motion given by the Greens (WA) on changes to question time embraced the concept of 28 questions including supplementaries. That is exactly what we have had today. We have had 16 questions and 12 supplementary questions. They have all been answered very effectively by ministers on this side of the chamber.

Yesterday, you kicked a procedural own goal. You made the decision that you would forego your right to ask questions in this chamber. Senator Hill, when he was sitting in that chair, made that decision—and doing a much more effective job than you, Senator Alston, have done today. So if you are trying to get your 16 votes, Senator Alston, keep trying; you are embarrassing your own colleagues. Keep struggling, you have a long way to go.

Senator Hill accepted the principle that if he moved that censure motion, he would forgo question time. And this question time has gone a lot longer than any other question time that I can remember, certainly in the life of this parliament. It has gone for over one hour and 10 minutes and that is longer than any other question time, with 28 questions being asked. Why don't you admit you blew it? The government will oppose the suspension of standing orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister's time has expired.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner cast some doubts on opposition motives. I do not even direct any comments to them at all. It is an opposition's job to have a bit of a lark in here, to be a bit opportunistic and not to think of when they were in government and the positions they took at the time. It is the old story: they will take one view this time and if they are ever in government, it will be 180 degrees different. I accept that as part of the cut and thrust of politics.

PARA.TAB: After all, Mr President, when you add up the devastating questions we got today, who wouldn't want to continue this for a few more hours? At least we can say the ABC has probably reverted back to a children's program and tripled their ratings in the last 11 minutes.

But it is true to say that today we did manage 16 questions and 12 supplementaries. Senator Gareth Evans did not get to his feet at 3 o'clock, he got to his feet at 11 minutes past three to put further questions on notice; but I understand that.

What are the motives of the Greens (WA) for moving this? It really is a philosophical difference about the balance between the parliament and the executive. Their view, I think, is that the executive is at their beck and call every minute of the day. But for the good governance of the country, quite often we allocate between 2 o'clock and 3 o'clock for question time.

This does not affect me today, but on some days this becomes a repeated pattern. You have to cancel meetings. Sometimes people have flown all the way from London or Washington to see you and you have to actually buzz them off and not see them. So you do try to have an ordered program through the day.

It does not affect the Greens, they could not care less. They are the anarchists of Australian politics. They could not care about good government. They care about accountability; that is good; but they could not care less about good governance. These two and their predecessor often moved these sorts of motions because they could not care less. As long as they can do something they think will needle the government, something that they know will be acceptable to the opposition that they crawl to all the time, this absolutely suits their purposes.

You are right that you are entitled to your say. You got one per cent of the vote in the last Senate election, so of course you are entitled to dominate things with your casting vote. You are empowered in this chamber because you bludge off the long-term difference between the government and the opposition. So you sit there like Tweedledum and Tweedledee flicking your vote backwards and forwards, never assessing the consequences.

I do not expect the opposition to always go along with that. Sometimes they do and sometimes they do not. Today it is a big lark—why not keep the ministers here until 4.30. What a good joke; we will upset their programs. They can do that. But they know they will get that back in spades if they ever make it to this side of the chamber. That usually makes them a little hesitant to support such ratbag motions. It is not as though we have not been fair today. We have had 16 questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twelve supplementaries.

—Sixteen questions and 12 supplementaries is a pretty good effort for any one day. You set the rules on question time, not us. You put the time limits on questions, answers, supplementaries and everything else. You made the rules for taking note of questions after question time. You put all these rules in and now you are saying, `On a better view today, we want to change them.' You enforce these rules on us yet you will not live by them. You were the ones that took the points of order to waste time during question time. You did that, not us. Now because you want to crawl to the Greens you say, `Oh, well, let us have another 28 questions or another hour.'
—Not another 28.

—Another 12 questions. Are you not going to count the supplementaries with the 12 questions you have asked for, Senator Alston? You have just opportunistically jumped on the bandwagon in this particular case. You really should understand the great political motto: what goes up comes down. You are setting the standards for future governments, whether it is you or someone else, with any precedent you set in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Obviously we are not going to have an election. You only get responsible three to four months out from an election. Every time we have changed standing orders for the better of this place it is just when you think you are about to get into power—just when you think it may affect you. At the moment you are suffering from amnesia. You think that all these precedents and all these rules will never apply to you and that you will be exempted from them if you are ever in government. It is a wish list or a cargo cult. Those on that side think that in the future none of these precedents will ever apply to them.

At any time, if they are in government, we will, with whatever bunch of opportunists we can round up at the time, be able to extend question time when they have important meetings or cabinet or whatever and they will go along with it. There is a balance between accountability and good government. This motion does not meet that.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard the most amazing speech from Senator Ray. We have asked for 28 primary questions today. If we had not had this time wasting debate and if this motion had been supported most of those questions probably could have been asked and answered by now. What you decided to do was stand up and make a big scene and carry on. The answer we received from Senator Faulkner is the only answer we have got that tells us that the Left needs a new leader in this parliament. Martin Ferguson is welcome to replace you, Senator Faulkner, after that hopeless performance on your part.

PARA.TAB: The question was asked from the backbench: what did you do when you were in government? You might be interested to know that on average 28 questions were answered day after day in this particular chamber. How are you going? In 1994, 21 questions including supplementaries were answered; in 1993, 22 were answered; in 1992, 22.6 were answered; and in autumn and winter 1995—is this the precedent you guys have set for the future?—19.6 were answered. That is an absolutely miserable time wasting performance. Just once we have said, `Lets have a decent number of questions asked and answered in question time.' We have asked that just once, and does Senator Faulkner go bananas!

This is a very reasonable motion. If the motion is carried—I hope that it will be—the fact is that we will proceed down this track. Most of the questions would have been asked by this time and would have been given. This is a great tactic, Senator Faulkner. Again you have done it. Martin Ferguson can hardly wait to come in and give some guts to the Left.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of theatre, posturing and nonsense goes on in this place. One thing that does at least keep us partly sane in the middle of all this nonsense is that people do, by and large, keep their word. When they state something as a matter of fact and when they give an undertaking across the table, it is honoured. What I have found today—it has not been the first time—is that Senator Alston is incapable of keeping his word. He is incapable of stating something, encouraging a course of action from another side and then sticking to it.

PARA.TAB: Let me explain what happened today. We came in here hearing the word around the chamber that there was going to be some attempt to extend question time by maybe doubling it by an hour or having another 28 questions; it was something of that kind. I asked Senator Alston at the beginning of question time what the state of play was and what the opposition's intentions were in this respect. He said, `Well, because of what happened yesterday, we reckon that we are entitled to some more questions. We want to ask of you 28 questions, including supplementaries.' I said, `Including supplementaries; you are clear about that? There would be 28 questions, including supplementaries, starting from 2 o'clock. You will be happy with that?' He said, `Yes, we'll be happy with that.'

I said, `That will take us some considerable time to get through.' Senator Alston said, `It is up to you. You'll just have to speed it up, then, won't you. It is up to you. When you've had your 28 questions, including supplementaries, we'll be satisfied.'

On that basis, applying the normal rules of this place, which involves accepting people's word and that there is a bit of personal decency involved, we sat here quietly. I did not get up. We kept track of the questions and the supplementaries. I got up on my feet, not at 3 o'clock but at 3.11 p.m., on the basis that that was the arrangement.

TALK.START.PARA: —We saw Faulkner go around and tell everybody.

—I told them to speed things up. Of course I did. That had been the suggestion of Senator Alston himself. I do not like retailing these private conversations—you ought to be able to have a private conversation and keep it private—but I am sick to God of being dudded by basically dishonest people. I am not going to put up with it. That is the reason why I am getting up and putting this on the record. You are a disgrace, and I am never going to trust your word again.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—You are a bloody disgrace.
—The first remark from Senator Evans `You are a disgrace' is unparliamentary. The second remark `bloody disgrace' is also unparliamentary. He should withdraw both of them.

—On the point of order: Mr President, I recall that yesterday you referred to senators as a national disgrace. I was pleased to hear you say that, because `disgrace' has been ruled unparliamentary before. But, now that you have set a new standard, it is quite in order for Senator Evans to say that. I ask you to rule that it is now in order.

—Thank you very much, Senator Faulkner! I believe that in the past it has been ruled to be unparliamentary. It should not normally be used, except that I think it was a very accurate description yesterday.
—It is an accurate description here.

—Order! The level of language used is generally inappropriate—I have said that many times—whether or not it is unparliamentary. In the interests of Senate harmony, Senator Evans, I ask you to withdraw.
—Will Hansard please record that he waved.
—It is confirmed that he withdrew. Senator, would you withdraw.
—I withdraw.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to participate in the debate further.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us be clear what this is about. This is about the practice of the government over a period of time to reduce the number of questions asked in this chamber. We have now reached the point where you are determined to answer as few questions as possible. Let us be clear about what has been proposed today.
—Tell us what was agreed today?

—Will you just listen? Do you want to know or not? I will tell you. What happened today is, as I understand it, the Greens indicated—and I thought it would have been more than just something Senator Gareth Evans picked up around the chamber; I gather from their nodding that it was communicated to the government—that it was our intention effectively to double question time to make up for yesterday. That was the proposal.

PARA.TAB: As we all know, there are certain forms of the parliament that have to be used in order to achieve that result and the appropriate form of this parliament was to use a contingent notice of motion which provided for 28 questions including supplementaries. Senator Evans asked me on what basis we were proceeding today and I pointed that out to him. He said to me, `How long is this going to take?' and I said, `If you tell people like Senator Cook to halve their answers, you will make a lot more progress.'

TALK.START.PARA: —What!
—Precious though you may be, even you could not take offence.
—Mr President, he is misrepresenting me. He is someone who just made up a yarn and told it across the chamber.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I said to Senator Evans, as he is just confirming to you and me, that if he told Senator Cook to halve his answers we would make a lot more progress.
—You said that to me.
—Indeed.
—That is what you said to me. I didn't agree with you.

—You may not have agreed with me, but you clearly did not communicate that to Senator Cook. All I know is that you moved along the front bench and, as a result, five supplementary questions were asked by the government. That is the fundamental breach of faith in this whole exercise. We were concerned about getting through the questions as quickly as possible. You knew that. It was in your hands to speed up answers.

PARA.TAB: You are having it both ways if you go off and tell people on the one hand to keep their answers short but on the other hand to ask as many supplementary questions as they can. You are not exactly honouring the bargain, are you? As a result, we simply achieved the same result by deleting the reference to supplementaries. That puts you back where you know you ought to be, and that is enabling us to get back to the level of questions that were answered at a time when governments were prepared to cooperate and treat question time as a genuine exercise in seeking information, not simply as an opportunity to filibuster and stonewall.

That was our proposal. That was made abundantly clear to Senator Evans, and that, as I hope Senator Kernot understands, is the position. It was never intended that we have another 28 questions after question time but simply that question time be allowed to continue until 28 questions had been asked on the normal basis. It was not on the basis that you would then go off and make sure you strung things out by having as many supplementaries as you possibly could. That is what you have done. That is the breach of the agreement. Don't run away from it. I am sure you know what this is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are lots of accusations flying around the chamber. The intention of the Greens needs to be made clear. I need to point out to people that the kinds of negotiations that have been discussed here were all made prior to the motion actually being flagged by Senator Margetts. It is really obvious that it was not just word flying around the chamber, and Senator Faulkner's accusation that the Greens did not consult the government is not accurate either.
—Who did you tell?
—I told you, Senator Faulkner.
—Rubbish! You know that's a lie.
—Order! There are too many interjections on both sides. Senator Chamarette has the call.

—Yesterday, it was made clear in the chamber, it was flagged by Senator Hill, that because the debate was raised and we were robbed of question time he would be willing to support a double question time today. That was made quite clear. It was flagged.
—Hill told us, did he? Come off it!
—Order! Senator Faulkner!

—Prior to my leaving the chamber following the discussion on the Jervis Bay legislation, I said to you, `We're going to make your day, Senator Faulkner; we're going to have a double question time.' I did not mention the mechanism by which we were going to do it.

PARA.TAB: I knew that a contingency motion was going to be moved at the end of the first question time. I did not have to tell you the mechanism. I told you we were having double question time. The misunderstanding that Senator Alston had, which he communicated to Senator Gareth Evans, came about because he also did not realise the mechanism by which we were going to have a double question time. That is the position.

The reason why we are having a double question time is because yesterday the opposition, without consulting the Australian Democrats, the Independents or the Greens, moved a censure motion—about which I believe they had consulted the government. That prevented us asking our questions. In recognition of that, the opposition then agreed that it would extend our democratic rights to us. It is perfectly legitimate, seeing we were denied yesterday—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you really think they consulted us about the censure motion?
—Order! Senator Faulkner!

—Senator Faulkner, yelling at me will not change the fact that I let you know that we were going to approach the Senate for a double question time. That is exactly what we have been doing. Senator Hill flagged it yesterday. I told Senator Faulkner today. I did it as a courtesy. I did not tell him the mechanisms by which we would do it. If he wanted to second-guess the mechanisms by which we would introduce it and try and subvert it before we even moved it in the chamber, that would be even more proof that I consulted him.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that when Senator Margetts moved this motion it was not a ratbag motion; it was not a motion by which we will benefit because it will allow—it would have allowed, if we had not wasted so much time discussing it—other people to ask questions, not just the Greens. I urge the Senate to pass this motion and get on with the questions so that the people who wish to ask questions can do so.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I now understand why I had the wrong understanding, too, because it all hinges upon what `double question time' means. To Senator Alston double question time meant getting a total of 28 questions including supplementaries. But today double question time means a total of 28 questions, not including supplementaries, because the naughty government asked supplementaries and government senators are not supposed to do that. That is the problem.
—You are not in the schoolyard now.
—Senator Knowles, you resort to personal abuse every time. Senator Crichton-Browne knows well enough about that.
—Order! Address the chair, Senator.
—I'll bet you are pleased with that comment.

—I am perfectly happy to take that interjection, Senator Knowles. It reflects on you. It reflects on the way you operate in this chamber. Mr President, that is the misunderstanding: are we or are we not entitled to count the government's supplementaries? That is what it all hinges on. I ask Senator Alston whether he is now proposing that, in order to get to 28 primary questions, we now have 12 primary questions and no supplementaries. What is the opposition's definition of a double question time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I short-circuit this and say that I would be voting for the amendment on the basis that it is 12 questions.
—With or without supplementaries?
—Without supplementaries—12 questions—
—He said yesterday with supplementaries.
—That is as I understood it.
—Bring back Hilly!
—Could I just make the point—
—Bring back Hilly!
—Order! Senator Faulkner! You will not get another warning.
—Could I just make a point about the questions? In the Senate Hansard yesterday notice was given on page 694. What Senator Hill said is very clear there. Senator Hill said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the best solution is a two-hour question time tomorrow—two hours or a minimum of 28 questions. I am pleased to announce that I cannot be here tomorrow.

Well, he is lucky. But those 28 questions presumably were in the context of Senator Margetts's motion yesterday, which was for 28 questions including supplementary questions to have been asked and answered. That was her motion yesterday. As I understand it, if we can get on with the 12 questions that Senator Alston's amendment seeks, it would serve us all well.

PARA.TAB: Amendment (Senator Alston's) agreed to.
Original question put:
That the contingency motion (Senator Margetts's), as amended, be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That questions may be put to ministers until 28 questions have been asked and answered.

SPEECH.PARA: In the interests of time, I propose that this motion be put without debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move that `28' be deleted and that `12' be inserted therefor.
—Does that include supplementaries?
—All that we have in mind, and I think the government understands this, is that there should be another 12 primary questions—no more, no less.
—And no supplementaries?
—Supplementaries do not count.
—Order! This is complex enough without interjections from all sides. Senator Harradine, your amendment does not make sense because it would actually mean that we would have 12 questions in total.
—Correction, Mr President. The word `additional' should be included in my amendment.
—Without supplementaries?
—Of course; 12 additional questions.
—We were talking about 12 primary questions, not supplementaries.
—Without supplementaries?
—With or without. You know that the standing orders distinguish between—
—Order! Senator Alston, are you seeking leave or are you speaking to the motion?
—I am seeking leave to speak.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it perfectly clear. The standing orders distinguish between questions and supplementary questions. We are talking about questions. If you want to elaborate on that and say `primary questions', we are talking about 12 primary questions. Whether or not you have supplementaries is irrelevant to that proposition. I do not expect that either side would ask supplementaries as a matter of course, and I am sure both you and I hope they do not.
—Why would we trust you?
—I am not asking you to. I am simply saying that `questions' mean primary, and you know it.
—I seek leave to explain what my amendment was meant to do.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My amendment was to have 12 additional questions, including supplementary questions. I formally move:

PARA.TAB: Omit `28 questions', substitute `12 additional questions, including supplementary questions'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: could I clarify the situation? I understood that we had a division—
—What is your point of order?
—I am just stating it.
—Order! Senator Cook, he is trying to.

—I understood that we had a division on a question which involved my deletion of the words `including supplementary questions'. In other words, you are left with 28 questions, and that is to include what has preceded this point in time. If that has been carried, as it has, I cannot see how we can now revert to another question which would be contradictory of that earlier proposition.
—You idiot, sit down. The motion we divided on was a contingent notice of motion to do something—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—I am on a point of order too.
—He should withdraw the word `idiot'.
—You obviously do not watch the Footy Show; he does. He knows what we mean. He understands the humour of it. What we were using was a contingent notice of motion—
—Mr President, on a point of order: I ask him to withdraw the word `idiot'.
—Senator Ray, will you please withdraw the word `idiot'.

—I withdraw the word `idiot', Mr President. I will let the jury consider its own verdict here. What we were on, Senator, was the use of a contingent notice of motion which mentioned content. You amended the content. Now it is up to Senator Margetts, who has properly moved the substantive motion to which Senator Harradine has moved an amendment. So your actual amendment was incorporated in hers, and it is now being moved that it be amended at the substantive stage. All we have to do now is vote on it.

—That is perfectly correct. The question now before us is Senator Harradine's amendment to Senator Margetts's substantive motion changing question time. I will put that. Those of that opinion say `aye', to the contrary `no'. I think the ayes have it.

—Mr President, can we all be clear on this, because there has been a lot of misunderstanding today. If this amendment is lost, we then revert to Senator Margetts's motion, which would involve the original proposition of 28 without any mention of supplementaries; is that not right?
—That is right.
—Yes. So we are against.
—Senator Harradine's motion has already been added. We voted on that.
—When?
—Just then.
—You had not called it, and I had said no.
—I called it.
—No. I said, `The noes have it', and because it was being queried—
—Nobody else said it, and I called it.
—On a point of order, I certainly said no, Mr President. You did not hear me, but I certainly said, no—and I think Senator Abetz did, too. You ought to clean your ears out.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Harradine's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Senator Crowley, your government is spending $12.5 million on an advertising campaign funded by the taxpayer to push the benefits of superannuation. Mr Keating has gloated that an average wage earner joining the work force now would retire with nearly half a million dollars in superannuation. How much would the average woman who works for 25 years, not the 39 years of the average man, and at 85 per cent of male earnings, have in her superannuation when she retires? Aren't you simply conning Australian women? Isn't this why Eva Cox has described your superannuation policies as neither fair nor equitable for women? Would you like me to repeat it because you couldn't hear it?
—I do have to say that I only heard half of that question. I wonder whether it could be asked again.
—Order! Senator Patterson, would you repeat the second half of it?

—How much would the average woman who works for 25 years, not the 39 years of the average man, and at 85 per cent of male earnings, have in her superannuation when she retires? Aren't you simply conning Australian women? Isn't this why Eva Cox has described your superannuation policies—
—No.
—Mr President, I am actually asking Senator Crowley, not Senator Cook.
—Senator Cook, that does not help things at all.
—Isn't this why Eva Cox described your superannuation policies as neither fair nor equitable for women?

—Here is a question that is trying to turn the great positive of this government's superannuation for men and women into a negative. This is a question that wants to make a sadness out of the great gains for women, most of whom did not have superannuation but now do. This is great good news for the government. As to the details of Senator Patterson's question, I will take that on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I refer to the release on Tuesday of the latest Yellow Pages Small Business Index. I understand this small business index reflects information gained from a survey of 1,000 randomly selected small business proprietors from all metropolitan and non-metropolitan regions of Australia. Has the minister been able to consider the survey results? If so, do the results provide any indication of the strength of the economic recovery?

—I thank Senator Childs for his question. The Yellow Pages Small Business Index is a credible index. Every quarter it samples 1,000 metropolitan and regional small businesses with fewer than 20 employees. The one that came out earlier this week showed some very good signs for the economy, which also back up the accounts figures which were released yesterday, as we well know. It showed that confidence remains relatively strong across the sector. Small business confidence is higher in the recreation and personal service sector. Expectations for growth are relatively stable.

PARA.TAB: It is significant to note that interest rate concerns have fallen substantially, with only two per cent of respondents expressing concern, compared with eight per cent in February and six per cent in May. Over half of the respondents expect to increase sales over the next 12 months and expect inflation to be at about four per cent during the next 12 months. They have expectations for employment growth in the current quarter, and that has firmed slightly.

These are, again, a clear sign that the government's economic policies, both at the macro and the micro level, are working very well. That is why we have heard such diversions from the opposition today, not asking any questions on the economic front.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. According to the most recent Bureau of Industry Economics report, Australia's waterfront efficiency is at the bottom of the list of 18 when compared with Asia, Europe and North America. The principal Australian ports of Melbourne and Sydney are in fact rated 17th and 18th. Doesn't this make a mockery of WIRA reform, and doesn't this report reflect the abject failure of the government's attempt to reform the waterfront and require Mr Brereton to resign, as you should have in 1992?
—No.
—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. How many five minutes worth of economic sunshine has Australia had since the end of the recession?
—With 16 quarters of consecutive growth now recorded in this week's national accounts, the answer, on my calculation, is 420,480. Since the beginning of question time, we have had another 25.

—My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it the case that the countries of the OECD, with the exception of Australia and Canada, are seeking to phase out the non-recyclable use of lead by the year 2005, and that Australia and Canada are resisting this proposal? Does the government accept that lead is a cumulative poison that has particularly damaging effects on the intellectual development of children, and that any continuing non-recyclable use of lead adds to the total burden of lead in the environment? Does the government accept that, to the extent that it resists attempts to clean up the global environment, it leaves Australia with an increasingly tarnished reputation as well as outmoded industries which will inevitably become less profitable? Does this move by the government also presage an attempt to maintain the export of lead waste to Third World countries under the pretext of recycling it there?

—Australia, along with other OECD countries, strongly supports cooperative action to reduce the risk of lead exposure. We support a flexible action program, which would include an industry initiative funded by the international lead industry. We proposed a ministerial declaration to demonstrate OECD members' continuing commitment to improving lead risk reduction measures, and to highlight the progress they have made on reducing risk to exposure to lead. There are other alternative policies that have been proposed. I will tell you more about them, in writing, at a later stage.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. Why did the minister for health, Carmen Lawrence, allow a seven-week delay in funding for Aboriginal medical services in the Kalgoorlie-Boulder region? How many other services have been similarly affected during her personal distraction of trying to duck the Marks royal commission? Will you ensure that she does not go to Beijing next week and try to tell other countries how to treat their indigenous people when she causes such neglect and distress to our Aboriginal people? How will you ensure that she does not forget such vital funding, as she seems to forget everything at the moment?

—On the information that has been provided to me, there is very little substance about the delays of payments to the Aboriginal communities in terms of their Aboriginal health allocations. But, in terms of those details and that particular centre, I will take it on notice.

—My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the minister's attention been drawn to the establishment of a committee of inquiry into the alleged lack of regional services which will look at, among other things, the drought? Will the minister look at the findings of this committee inquiry? If it adopts a policy on drought, will the government accept such a policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention was drawn to this commitment about 10 minutes ago, as a matter of fact. The announcement of the establishment of this committee is a cruel hoax on the residents of regional Australia. In fact, it has been designed to give to the residents of regional Australia the false impression that the Liberal Party has a commitment to improving government services in the area. No such commitment exists.

PARA.TAB: What is extremely curious—and I look forward to the findings of this committee, Senator McKiernan, as to whether I can adopt them or not—is who is not on the committee. Conspicuous by his absence is the shadow minister for regional development and infrastructure, Senator Ian Macdonald, who is not on the regional committee that has just been established by the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the last effort, why would you expect him to be?

—Precisely. He is, in fact, chairman of the coalition's regional task force. But why wouldn't the coalition—and it would be interesting to know—put their own shadow minister for regional development on this committee that was announced only a few weeks ago?
—They don't trust him.

—That is right. A letter to the editor in the Townsville Bulletin of a few weeks ago might, in fact, give us a clue. This is a paragraph from it. This is a letter very critical of Senator Ian Macdonald, and it actually asserts that Senator Ian Macdonald does not even understand how his own party works. It says:

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that Senator Macdonald clearly has no understanding of the decision making processes within the Queensland coalition.
It is signed by Jim Barron, State Director, Liberal Party of Australia, Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. The number of Australians holding basic hospital cover has fallen by 98,000 in the last three months, which means only 35 per cent of Australians now carry private health cover. That brings the number of people who have dropped out of private health insurance in the past five years to 1.3 million. It is now predicted that by the year 2001 a mere 20 per cent of Australians will be covered by private medical insurance. Why have the number of people with private health cover continued to decline despite the changes passed earlier this year which you said would stem the flow out of private cover? How low will you allow the number of people carrying some private health cover to go before the public system falls over? What is the government now proposing to do to make private cover more attractive to Australians? Why was the Medicare levy increased in the last federal budget when the government says it is attempting to stem the flood of people leaving private insurance?

—I suppose we could ask, Mr President, why that is not called four questions. The number of people, as you say, Senator, are falling. I am not sure what figures you were giving, but I think it is impossible to extrapolate what the figures will be by the year X.

PARA.TAB: We can agree that the figures from 1991 have fallen from 43.7 per cent to 35 per cent in 1995. You ask why people have been leaving. People have been leaving health insurance for two reasons: one, because of the costs; and, two, because until recently private insurance entitled people to a very big bill. So people who used private health insurance found that it was not much help to them at all.

The legislation that was introduced in this place has not really had time to make a difference to the private insurance numbers. But already a considerable number of agreements are in place between hospitals and insurance companies which mean that people will have 100 per cent cover for their hospital expenses. And if there are arrangements and negotiations between doctors and the insurance companies, that kind of 100 per cent cover for medical costs may also be provided to the patients who might have to use it. So it depends very much on what happens as a result of the negotiations still under way between the insurance companies and the medical communities. So far the doctors have started a vigorous campaign to reject any participation and, therefore, any opportunity to give patients 100 per cent cover.

It is a matter of waiting and seeing how these insurance changes make a difference and bite into the community. The insurance companies are interested, the community is interested and the hospitals are participating on behalf of the people of Australia. Let's see if the doctors join them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I understand that the minister yesterday launched a new national accreditation scheme for sports administrators. Will the minister please advise the Senate as to how this scheme will help the development of sport and recreation in Australia.

—I am very pleased to do that. The national accreditation scheme for sports administrators is an initiative of the Australian Society of Sports Administrators. It will, in fact, provide two industry focused short courses for clients who see sports as a possible career choice and for those who are already engaged in managing sport and recreation groups.

PARA.TAB: The new look national accreditation scheme for sports administrators represents very much an ongoing commitment by the Australian Society of Sports Administrators who have developed very high standards for sports administration in Australia and reflects the national direction in industry training reform. I commend to the Senate the documents that I launched.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Approximately two years ago the government gave a guarantee or an assurance that the Reserve Bank would act as a lender of last resort to an Australian bank which was subject to a run on its deposit base as a result of depositors withdrawing a high percentage of their funds from that bank. Since that time there have been certain suggestions that that protection may be somewhat qualified support. Can the minister confirm that the Reserve Bank still has an unequivocal policy and resolve of acting as lender of last resort to all Australian trading and savings banks?
—I will take that question on notice.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Rural Woman of the Year Award

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Last Friday, the minister addressed the regional and state finalists of the rural woman of the year award. At that time, you expressed your concern at the lack of involvement of women in primary industry decision making and industry bodies. Would the minister advise the Senate of how he feels this award is contributing to solving this problem?

—The answer is that it is significantly contributing. I would like to congratulate Robyn Treadwell from the Kimberley Region on being awarded the rural woman of the year award. She is an extraordinary primary producer in terms of the property she is running. It is very good indeed to see someone from northern Australia being given this type of recognition.

PARA.TAB: She is not only just an outstanding rural woman: she is an outstanding farmer. I have said before that the lack of women involved in rural policy making and farm industry bodies is of real concern to me. On last Friday morning I addressed about 40 women who were either regional or state finalists in the rural woman of the year award. I congratulate the ABC for commencing the award and for the assistance that it has given for the advancement of rural women in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In March 1992 and again in February 1993 the Prime Minister made it quite clear that if Australia was not able to achieve four per cent economic growth then it could not improve the employment outlook. Is it not the case that currently the number of under 25-year-olds in employment is 94,900 fewer than prior to Mr Keating's recession in July 1990—that is, there are 94,900 fewer young people in employment? What message does the slowing growth rate announced this week send out to the thousands of young unemployed who are still awaiting an opportunity to provide themselves with employment, and particularly those in depressed regions where the unemployment rates for young people are upwards of 40 to 50 per cent? Is it not a fact that Mr Keating's recovery has indeed passed a large number of our youth and many Australian families by?

—I will not confirm that figure. At previous question times the opposition has given me figures purporting to be accurate but which, on closer examination, have been not found to be accurate. So I will not confirm it. I will check it and come back to you on that.

PARA.TAB: As far as the total levels of youth unemployment are concerned, we have had this debate in this chamber many times. Most youth in the age group we are talking about here, in the cohort 16 to 20, are in training. They are at high school, university or technical college. They are engaging in some form of training and they are not in the work force, nor are they seeking jobs. So the figures that you are giving are a biased representation of that age cohort, and you know it. We have had that debate many times.

On the question of employment, at the present state of economic growth we are creating 1,000 new jobs every day. We have created nearly 700,000 jobs since the beginning of this term of government. Under accord mark 8, the agreement we have with the trade union movement, we are committed to creating 600,000 new jobs in the next period of our government following the next election. That is a record. The opposition just cannot match it. On this subject we are credible. On this subject you are incredible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. In recent times, the focus has been on the situation of families in rural and remote communities. Can the minister advise of any developments in child-care services in these areas?

Also, there is $7.5 million in the last budget for initiatives for rural families. We do recognise the importance of child care for rural families. The details are much more than that. In light of reasonableness this afternoon, I will provide those further details to Senator Denman.
