TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer to a question on notice from Senator Harradine referring to Dr Helen Ware's appointment to the Beijing delegation. Dr Ware is branch head of the sector program and review branch of AusAID. As such, she has a particular responsibility for ensuring that AusAID's policies and strategies for furthering the issues of population health and economic development are incorporated into the Australian brief and negotiations.

PARA.TAB: Dr Ware will be an asset to the Australian delegation to the Beijing women's conference. She is an experienced UN negotiator with a detailed working knowledge of issues which impact on poor women in developing countries. She was rapporteur for the women's conference in Nairobi in 1985 and has a long professional interest in improving the health and status of women in developing countries.

The Australian government has made it clear on many occasions that coercion has no place in family planning programs. We support the provision of safe, voluntary family planning services in the interests of women's health and family wellbeing. Australia will uphold these principles at the forthcoming conference.

In the context of major international conferences such as Beijing, the government has been cautious about introducing contentious issues into deliberations. For example, the world conference on human rights did not address specific country situations even though UN bodies are dedicated to the promotion and protection of human rights in specific country situations.

The overwhelming approach by governments is that it is desirable to focus on the big picture issues and not to get embroiled in specific country situations. To broach any such situation raises the question of where to stop. The discussions at the Beijing conference will be focused on global issues of concern to women and in reaching agreement on a plan of action to address these problems. I seek leave to incorporate this document.
Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: ANSWER TO QUESTION ON NOTICE FROM SENATOR HARRADINE TO
SENATOR CROWLEY : 23 August 1995
Dr Helen Ware's appointment on Beijing Delegation and Human Rights in China

Dr Ware is Branch Head of the Sector Program and Review Branch of AusAid. As such she has a particular responsibility for ensuring AusAID's policies and strategies for furthering the issues of population, health and economic development are incorporated into the Australian brief and negotiations. Dr Ware will be an asset to the Australian Delegation to the Beijing Women's Conference. She is an experienced UN negotiator with a detailed working knowledge of issues which impact on poor women in developing countries. She was rapporteur for the women's conference in Nairobi in 1985 and has a long professional interest in improving the health and status of women in developing countries.

The Australian Government has made clear on many occasions that coercion has no place in family planning programs. We support the provision of safe, voluntary family planning services in the interests of women's health and family well being. Australia will uphold these principles at the forthcoming World Conference on Women as we have done at previous international forums.

In the Context of major international conferences such as the UN Fourth World conference in Beijing, Governments have been cautious about introducing contentious issues in the deliberations—for example the World Conference on Human Rights did not address specific country situations even though UN bodies are dedicated to the promotion and protection of human rights in specific country situations. The overwhelming approach by Governments is that it is desirable to focus on the big picture issues and not to get embroiled in specific country situations. To broach any such situation raises the question of where to stop. The discussions at the Beijing Conference will be focused on global issues of concern to women and in reaching agreement on a plan of action to address these problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 June last, Senator Watson asked me a question concerning speculation on his behalf about delays in tax refunds being delivered this year because of alleged industrial activity at the Australian Taxation Office. I have been provided by the Assistant Treasurer with an answer to that question. It runs for one and a half pages. I am quite delighted to read it into the transcript, but I suggest that the sensible course would be to allow me to incorporate this answer. I seek leave to incorporate it.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
Senator Watson asked (Hansard, p 1818) the Minister representing the Treasurer a question without notice, on 27 June 1995:

Can you assure the Australian taxpayers that there will be no delays in receiving their income tax refunds this year, given an environment of threatened industrial action resulting from suggestions of rolling strikes over workload disputes and problems in income tax design changes that, according to Shane O'Connell, a union representative, could result in greater ATO processing errors in determining taxes payable with the possibility of delays of up to six weeks for refunds?
I ask a supplementary question, could the minister explain what internal evaluations took place in ensuring the correctness of the tax pack in the first place?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Commissioner of Taxation informs me that the CPSU has not presented him with any information to substantiate the claims made in its media release, nor indeed has the CPSU formally presented any concerns to ATO management on this issue. He is therefore disappointed with the CPSU's decision to alarm the taxpaying public in this manner.
The media release alleges that delays will result from the introduction of a new return form and from the ATO not having recruited enough staff to process returns.
This year's return form has been changed in two main ways:

it has been redesigned, following a review of TaxPack, to make it easier to fill in. For example, the form now carries textual item identification in lieu of just question numbers. It also provides more room in which to write. As a result, the form is now larger.
it contains space for new information not previously collected, including:
for payment of interest on amounts paid in advance of the due date
for electronic funds transfer of refunds or debits.
As a result there will be marginally more information for processing staff to key.

There are other changes such as the use of colour, which was introduced to assist taxpayers to navigate between the form and TaxPack. The form therefore looks significantly different and staff will need to become adjusted to handling it.
Trialing of keying indicates that, with experience, there will be only a marginal impact on keying times.
In addition, staffing has generally been set at equivalent levels to last year, where the ATO achieved very effective turn-around times.
The ATO bettered its published processing time standards last year and, notwithstanding the changes to the return form, expects to do so again for the current year.
The ATO is presently way ahead of its service targets and six weeks into its peak season is currently issuing between $60m and $90m in refunds daily.
In relation to your supplementary question, I have been advised that each TaxPack 95 question was allocated to operational and technical staff in each ATO region.
Each region was asked to examine their questions, making sure:
each question was updated with any new legislation
technical issues raised through the review of TaxPack 94 and suggestion scheme were considered
key internal and external stakeholders were consulted
any superfluous material was removed and
the final question was checked for accuracy.
After this, another quality control clearance was made by senior technical staff in each region and the question was forwarded to the TaxPack 95 editorial team.

Each question was then put into a consistent format, examined for further possible reduction in the amount of text and the language was simplified where possible. It was recognised that attempts to give the general public a clear, plain English view of the law presented tensions in places and editorial and technical staff worked together to achieve a balanced outcome.
Each question went through several clearance procedures involving the ATO's Tax Counsel Network and, in the case of superannuation and foreign income issues, the respective specialist areas.
This process was designed to ensure the legal integrity of TaxPack 95.

Because of the need to factor in a review of the overall TaxPack concept, production of TaxPack 95 was commenced later than normal. The timetable compressed the period normally spent on technical checking and also prevented wider circulation of drafts. This will be coResolution reported; report adopted.ected in future years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to supply some additional information that I undertook to supply regarding a question without notice to me from Senator Harradine in the chamber on Tuesday. Senator Harradine asked me what the government's forecasts for youth unemployment would be in the year 2001 after the Working Nation strategy had run its course. I remind this place of the government's commitment under Working Nation to an overall unemployment rate of five per cent by the turn of the century.

PARA.TAB: We are creating jobs well in excess of the 200,000 required annually to meet our targets. Obviously, if we move to the five per cent target, we would expect improvements to the significant youth problem commensurate with the continuing decline in overall unemployment.

Historically, youth unemployment has always been higher than the overall unemployment rate because the turnover of young workers is greater than for the overall labour force, resulting in a larger pool of workers between jobs. However, under Working Nation, the government has committed the resources and provided the program flexibility to skew the labour market equation in favour of young people and ensure that they share in sustained jobs growth. The evidence is there. Over the year to July 1995, the number of young people seeking full-time employment fell by five per cent. For long-term unemployed 15- to 19-year-olds, the number has fallen even further by over 20 per cent, and by 30 per cent for the 20- to 24-year-olds.

Education and training do significantly increase the chances of young people getting and holding a job. The latest ABS labour force data shows that the unemployment rate for those 15- to 24-year-olds who did not complete secondary school was 28.2 per cent, twice the rate for those with a post-secondary school qualification—that is, 12.9 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 4.30 p.m., we should proceed to general business. Would you care to incorporate the remainder of your remarks in Hansard?
—I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my remarks in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: That's why this government is committed to a target of ninety five per cent of nineteen year olds completing year twelve or participating in post-school qualifications, education or training by the year 2000. Currently around eighty per cent of nineteen year olds meet these requirements.
This target combined with the Working Nation initiatives will significantly increase a young person's chances and opportunities of finding and obtaining work.

It will also ensure that increasing demand for educated and skilled labour is met as industry shifts towards the services sector and manufacturing industry moves from basic extractive to a new technology basis.

National Board of Employment, Education and Training—Australian Research Council and Higher Education Council—Report—Maximising the benefits: Joint ARC/HEC advice on intellectual property, August 1995

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That—
(1)The Senate notes:

TAB.TAB: (a)continuing disquiet among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people about the decision of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) Board to set aside $10 million for land purchases in the Northern Territory and $2 million for other priority national purchases in each of the next two years;

(b)growing concern among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people about the recent appointments by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) to the Indigenous Land Corporation Board;
(c)the failure of ATSIC to fully account for their decision to the Parliament and people of Australia; and
(d)the failure of the Government to fully account for the agreements it made with ATSIC and certain Aboriginal organisations about the allocation of money from the Land Fund.

PARA.TAB: (2)A select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Certain Land Fund Matters, be appointed to inquire into and report, on or before 19 October 1995, on the following matters:

TAB.TAB: (a)whether the decision by the ATSIC Board referred to in paragraph (1)(a) was equitable and reasonable;

(b)what were the terms of the agreement between the Government, ATSIC and any Aboriginal organisations about special treatment for the Northern Territory for land acquisitions from ATSIC's Land Acquisition and Maintenance Program;
(c)whether there were any other agreements between the Government, ATSIC and/or Aboriginal people arising from negotiations on the Native Title Act or the Land Fund Bill; and

(d)whether any of these agreements constitute a deception or a breach of faith on the part of the Government or ATSIC toward Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people or the Northern Territory Government.

PARA.TAB: (3)The committee consist of seven senators:

TAB.TAB: (a)two nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b)three nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c)one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats;
(d)one nominated by the Greens (WA) or Senator Harradine.

PARA.TAB: (4)The committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(5)(a)The chair of the committee be elected by the members of the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: (b)In the absence of agreement on the selection of a chair, duly notified to the President, the allocation of the chair be determined by the Senate.
(c)The deputy chair of the committee be elected by the committee from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair.
(d)The deputy chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting.
(e)In the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or the deputy chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.

PARA.TAB: (6)The quorum of the committee be three members.

(7)The committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place and to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(8)The committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the senators appointed to the subcommittee.
(9)Without limiting its power to pass procedural or other resolutions that are not inconsistent with this paragraph or these terms of reference, the committee observe the following procedures:

TAB.TAB: (a)As a general principle, evidence be invited in the first instance in the form of written submissions and following examination of submissions, the committee decide which witnesses are to be called for examination.

(b)Subject to any contrary order in relation to a particular submission, the submission to the committee by a person of a statement relating to the inquiry be deemed to be the giving of evidence before the committee by that person in accordance with that statement.
(c)Evidence be heard in public session except in instances where the committee or a subcommittee resolves to hear evidence in camera.
(d)The chair be authorised to make statements to the media on behalf of the committee concerning its activities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Broadcasts and re-broadcasts of public proceedings

TAB.TAB: (e)The recording, broadcasting and re-broadcasting of public proceedings is authorised in accordance with the rules contained in the order of the Senate of 23 August 1990, as varied by the Senate from time to time, concerning the broadcasting of committee proceedings.
(f)The secretary is authorised to supply for correction, copies of proof reports of both public and in camera proceedings to the witnesses whose evidence appears in those reports.
(g)Subject to any contrary order in relation to a particular submission, each document submitted to the committee be published.
(h)Subject to any contrary order, evidence which adversely reflects on a person be forwarded to that person inviting their response.

PARA.TAB: (10)(a)The terms of reference of the inquiry be appropriately advertised in the media.

SPEECH.PARA: (b)Written submissions be sought and examined by the committee and oral evidence be heard.

PARA.TAB: (11)The committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee, with the approval of the President.
(12)The committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(13)The committee may report from time to time its proceedings and evidence taken or any interim conclusions or recommendations arising from its inquiry, and may make regular reports on the progress of its proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of how the ATSIC board of commissioners came to the decision to award $20 million to the Northern Territory for land acquisition over the next two years while $4 million has been kept aside for emergencies or for land acquisition in the states is a very serious matter which deserves the deepest scrutiny of the Senate through our invaluable committee processes. As many senators are probably aware, yesterday the Federal Court in Sydney set aside the decision of the ATSIC board. In doing so, the judge made it very clear that:

Far from taking into account the Government policy as enunciated by the Prime Minister that there not be an inappropriate increase in acquisitions of land in the Northern Territory, ATSIC did the opposite. It embarked upon a course which would ensure that this policy would, at least to the extent of some of $10 million allocated, be frustrated.

This matter has been the subject of a great deal of debate in this place and elsewhere. It has been raised in several ways, with very unsatisfactory responses so far from the government: during the land fund bill debate; during question time; calls to order; a successful censure motion against the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Bob Collins; and in the estimates committee.

PARA.TAB: The Federal Court judgment adds to the concerns expressed in the Senate and contrasts with the arguments which were raised by the government during those debates. The Federal Court action was taken against ATSIC by the New South Wales Land Council, the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre and FAIRA from Queensland. These three Aboriginal organisations felt deeply aggrieved by the decision of the ATSIC board and their position has been vindicated by the decision of the Federal Court.

However, the decision of the court has far from settled the matter. There are a number of issues which have only been highlighted by the case. These can be summarised in the following questions: if there was a belief within ATSIC that there was an agreement with the government about giving special treatment to the Northern Territory, where did that belief come from? How did the ATSIC bureaucracy come to write the briefing paper on which the board based its decision? How did that briefing paper get the endorsement of the legal section of ATSIC if it was manifestly wrong? How did that briefing paper get the endorsement of the deputy CEO of ATSIC if it was manifestly wrong? How did the board of commissioners of ATSIC come to make such a manifestly unreasonable decision on such a sensitive matter?

In some ways this is actually a very simple matter. There are really only two options about how this whole affair arose. The first option is that somehow the ATSIC bureaucracy managed to create a briefing paper on a highly sensitive matter which was manifestly wrong. In this case there is serious cause for concern about how such a briefing paper came into existence. The Senate committee should look at how the internal processes of ATSIC conspired to create such a brief.

The second option is that the ATSIC briefing paper was right and there was an agreement with the government that the Northern Territory would be given special treatment for the next two years. In this case there has been gross deception on the part of the government and particularly the Prime Minister; a deception which resulted in the passage of a bill through this place; a deception which would rightly be called one of the most important wrongdoings by this government. I would like to quote from page 46 of Justice Hill's judgment:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no evidence before me of any discussions which would lead to the conclusion to which the author of the option paper, upon which the decision was based, came. This is not surprising. For there to have been such discussions and agreement with the Prime Minister, what the Prime Minister said in parliament would have to have been deliberately misleading. I would not lightly infer that the Prime Minister intended to mislead the House in this way. The fact that no evidence was called by ATSIC is also relevant to my conclusion.

Honourable senators may ask why it is that I have continued to pursue this matter with such vigour and why it is that we keep making such serious allegations against this government. Senator Bob Collins and Senator Gareth Evans have accused me of having some kind of grudge against ATSIC or distaste of ATSIC. Far from this: anyone listening to the questions that I have asked will be able to recognise their legitimacy. If you take a close look at the evidence which we have been able to uncover, then this is really the only conclusion which one can honestly draw from the evidence.

PARA.TAB: No, we do not have any evidence which makes it explicit—not yet. The decision is the strongest evidence that we have. The need for a committee is to establish the basis on which a manifestly wrong paper came to be written. What we do have is a great deal of evidence which alludes to the fact that there was an agreement. ATSIC was a willing party in an agreement which was reached with a handful of people, including the Prime Minister.

The Senate has a responsibility to look after the interests of all Australians. By setting up a statutory authority with a partially elected board of commissioners, the parliament did not abrogate our responsibility to the Aboriginal people of Australia. Indeed, ATSIC remains accountable to the parliament for its actions, just as it remains accountable to the Federal Court.

In the Federal Court case, ATSIC attempted to argue the point of jurisdiction but failed. It ran its case on jurisdiction and the right of the Federal Court to make a determination. No evidence on merit was provided to the court. No evidence on merit was provided because, if it had, it may have exposed the Prime Minister. `We have no argument for the option paper being wrong' was the statement that was made. We don't have that argument. The inquiry which this motion seeks to set up will allow us to inquire into such matters and the questions I mentioned earlier.

I cannot believe that the government is still going to endorse this decision that has been set aside by the Federal Court. In order to be brief, I close with another quote from the Federal Court to remind us of the role of ATSIC:

SPEECH.PARA: ATSIC exists to redress the imbalance of the past colonisation of the continent. To this end it is funded to assist Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders acquire land. ATSIC does not exist for the purpose of furthering the interests of Aboriginal persons in a particular place. A decision by it, for example, that it would favour residents of a particular state or territory over residents of another state or territory would clearly be invalid. The residence of beneficiaries is not of itself a relevant factor. Where public moneys are made available for distribution to a particular group in society, in the present case, persons of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander descent, it is necessarily implied that all persons within the class of beneficiary will be open to consideration for that benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the motion from Senator Chamarette. Senator Chamarette has actively pursued this subject in this chamber, through the estimates hearings and the supplementary estimates. She is quite correct in her own words: there has been no evidence of this matter that Senator Chamarette is obsessed with. That is what it is—an obsession, and an unreal one, because there is no evidence. I know that and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has stated it on the record, but Senator Chamarette keeps coming back to the minute.
—Can you tell me where he stated it on the record?

—The Prime Minister has clearly stated that there was no deal. Senator Gareth Evans has stated that in here on his behalf and so have I, Senator Campbell. There was no deal. Not only that, I have spoken to the people who were actually at the meetings with the Prime Minister, every one of them. These are Aboriginal people, people whose integrity I respect.
—They can come to the inquiry.

—Thank you for that invitation in terms of the pompous self-delusion that you, Senator Chamarette, operate under. You talk about not having an anti-ATSIC agenda and you have prompted me to say that by that pompous interjection. I thought the interjection you made earlier today was quite extraordinary. I put to you today that you have an anti-ATSIC agenda. I put to you today that you have never given up an opportunity to boot ATSIC.

PARA.TAB: I am not saying that ATSIC is the most perfect organisation in the world, but it is the only one at the moment that actually has got a national democratic method of Aboriginal people electing its membership. Of course, as with all democratic institutions, there are many disaffected constituents in the Aboriginal community—as there are in the community at large with the people who elect these parliaments.

But the difficulty you have, Senator Chamarette—and I put it to you fairly—is that you just cannot handle the concept of independent Aboriginal decision making. You simply cannot handle it. When Aboriginal people, for whatever reason, rightly or wrongly—I made my disagreement clear; I do not think I could have made it clearer—take a decision, it is a question of whether they are entitled to take it or not.

So I put that to you today and said, `Why are you always booting ATSIC and attacking ATSIC? What is wrong with ATSIC? Why can't people be represented through it?' I wrote down what you said in response. This is what you said in terms of the Greens' role in this parliament: `We speak'—that is, the Greens—`for all indigenous people who don't want to speak through this government.' Well, talk about self-delusion!

I would not presume to even speak about the situation that Aboriginal people are in anywhere else except the Top End of the Northern Territory—and I am very familiar with them. Senator Chamarette, they do not even know you exist. For you to take the mantle of the Greens in Western Australia and say that you are—and I quote again—`speaking for all indigenous people who do not want to speak through this government', just indicates the extent to which you are deluded.

You keep coming back to the one piece of evidence you claim does exist, and that is the minute. Just look at it through different eyes, Senator Chamarette. Instead of looking at it through your obsession, try to actually consider whether there is another explanation for that reference—and I know there is. You have simply distorted the words of that agreement. All those words in the minute refer to is the agreement that did exist between the Aboriginal people who met with the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister, which was given effect to in this parliament.

I took the ATSIC legislation through here. Originally, the government had intended—as Senator Evans and I have stated again and again in here, and it was publicly known—that we would incorporate all of the land acquisition powers into the new body and that we would remove from ATSIC the continuation of the role it has played, and played very well, in acquiring land for Aboriginal people for some years. That was the original intention of the government. There are no bones about that.

What was agreed to at those meetings with the Prime Minister, and I have spoken to the people who went to the meetings, was that the government would change that position; that the government would prevent the new body converting into inalienable freehold title the land that it had acquired but it would allow ATSIC to continue to have land acquisition powers as well for a transitional period. That was the agreement referred to in the minute.

If you like to re-read the minute and cast away your obsessions for just a second, you will see that is in fact the explanation for what the so-called agreement refers to. There is no other evidence, Senator Chamarette. At no time, and you have said it yourself, have you found any. You want this Senate to waste more time on a fishing expedition—and you have admitted it yourself—to try to find it, and it does not exist, solely on the basis of what is said in this minute paper.

This is despite the fact—you have quoted a bit of him, and I will quote a bit more of him—that, with all of the processes of the Federal Court at play, the judge, Mr Justice Hill, found there was no evidence in his court that such an agreement had existed. We have provided you with endless answers to questions without notice and to questions in the estimates committees. A huge pile of documents—six kilograms of them, as I understand it—were given to you, and there is nothing in any of that which indicates that this obsession you have is justified.

I know that Cathcart is writing a book. I understand the working title is `Mabo: the real story'. Father Frank Brennan has just published a superb book on Mabo. I commend it to anyone who wants to read the best exposition of what the actual judgment says and an interpretation of what I think is a passage for reconciliation in Australia. But I have to say that I get a bit irritated knowing that that six kilograms of paper is going to be used by Cathcart to write his book and that this Senate is to hold Senate inquiries to provide him with a bit more material for his book. If that book includes as its central element the proposition that this deal existed, it will not be the true story at all about Mabo. The story will be false.

I also want to draw to the attention of the Senate the comments made by Mr Justice Hill. I read the judgment last night, and it is a very interesting judgment indeed. I will quote from page 46 a little more extensively than Senator Chamarette did. Mr Justice Hill said:

ATSIC also erred in taking into account what it took to have been the outcome of discussions with the Government and as being the underlying rationale for parallel programs, namely that there should be special treatment for the Northern Territory through grants by ATSIC in the two years before the "sunset" period. There is no evidence before me of any discussions which would lead to the conclusion to which the author of the option paper, upon which the decision was based, came. This is not surprising. For there to have been such discussions and agreement with the Prime Minister, what the Prime Minister said in Parliament would have to have been deliberately misleading. I would not lightly infer that the Prime Minister intended to mislead the House in this way. The fact that no evidence was called by ATSIC is also relevant to my conclusion.

SPEECH.PARA: The next paragraph states:

PARA.TAB: It seems abundantly clear that ATSIC saw its task to be to set aside the maximum funds it could (after providing for land maintenance) and allowing only for $2 million for special acquisitions so as to give effect to a belief that this was Government policy when it was clearly expressed not to be so. In my view, in the circumstances, the Commission erred either by taking into account an irrelevant consideration (the supposed discussions which I infer did not reach the suggested conclusion) or by failing to take into account a relevant consideration (the real Government policy) as well as by coming to a decision that in all the circumstances was so unreasonable that no reasonable decision-maker could come to it.

SPEECH.PARA: There was endless opportunity for the plaintiffs to present in the Federal Court the evidence that Senator Chamarette still insists exist, which it does not, but it was not produced. The judge in his judgment clearly said there was no evidence before him that any such arrangement did exist. I must say this: it does not exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you think of a reason why ATSIC would not produce that evidence?
—The evidence was produced by no-one, Senator Campbell. It was not produced by the plaintiffs either, despite your screaming, yelling and irrational behaviour.
—Think of a good reason, you mug.

—Why didn't the plaintiffs produce it if they suggested it existed? It was produced by no-one in the Federal Court. Read the judgment. You can try to politicise the judge's decision all you like, but it is there in black and white. In fact, it could not be clearer. The Federal Court found there was no such conspiracy, but Senator Chamarette still will not agree. I know that she is desperately trying to help Cathcart's book, but I say again, if he wants to call it `Mabo: the real story' he had better not have this as its central element because that will not be the truth, it will be a lie. Those individuals I spoke to confirmed to me no such deal had occurred. The ATSIC board made its own decision about how it would allocate its funds, and the basis of the board's decision was set out in the chairperson's press release on 11 April.

PARA.TAB: Another point needs to be made. I said in the Senate when this matter was first raised, when we were taking the legislation through the Senate, that I did not believe that the ATSIC board would actually make this decision. This was to the aggravation of the land council, and I have never ever hesitated to aggravate them if I thought that something needed to be said. They were aggravated by what I said but I made my own personal position on that decision very clear. I was entitled to do that but not to interfere with that decision in the sense of causing the government to direct them to change it. It was open—and I said this—to the disaffected people to take action. They have, and they have a judgment.

The problem you have, Senator Chamarette, is you cannot handle the concept of Aboriginal people, the ones you do not agree with, making decisions and having the right to make them without interference. You wanted them directed to do otherwise by the government. The New South Wales land council took the course open to it. It is a public fact that the decision was a controversial one inside the commission. All that is public. It was a tied vote. It was hotly contested inside the commission. On that day the New South Wales land councils did not get up.

I made my judgment in here, and it was an opinion I expressed, that it would not happen based on the internal politics of the organisation. What I did not allow for, of course, was the well-known persuasive powers of territorians against the odds. They persuaded others to take a different decision but it was hotly contested and the vote was tied. The New South Wales land council, Senator Chamarette, then took action available to it and got a judgment, and they are entitled to do that. That does not mean we have to interfere in this process at all. That is what you cannot handle, Senator Chamarette. The ATSIC board made its own decision.

Senator Chamarette, I did read this judgment last night. In respect of the central issue that you are pursuing—a deal which does not exist—it found very clearly there was not. But there are some aspects of his honour's judgment that I do find curious. If I were a lawyer I would not even hesitate to express this personal view I am expressing—and I read the judgment last night—but I am not a lawyer; I am just a mug politician. So any opinion I express on a legal matter is not worth a dam thing. As a mug politician I find aspects of this judgment quite curious. As the person who took the ATSIC legislation through the Senate chamber, one in particular I find very curious indeed, and I will refer to it. His Honour said, starting on page 42, that the applicants had two grounds of appeal—two. The first was this—and I am quoting from the judgment:

SPEECH.PARA: First it is submitted that the decision of the commission to set aside in each of two years $10 million of the $12 million to be allocated in that year for land acquisition to persons seeking to acquire land in the Northern Territory was a decision so unreasonable in the administrative law sense that it amounted to an error in law.
That is fair enough. He then went on to describe the second ground:
The second ground relied upon was the failure on the part of ATSIC to take into account in determining the allocation of its funds government policy as enunciated by the Prime Minister.
Then, at the bottom of that same page, he said this:
In my view the applicants should succeed on each of the submissions made.

So the judge found on two grounds: firstly, so unreasonable as to be wrong in law—fair enough—but the other, very curious, when he upheld it; that it was wrong because they had not taken into account government policy as enunciated by the Prime Minister. The reason I find that curious is this: I took that legislation through the Senate. To the best of my knowledge there are no provisions in it that require ATSIC to take account of determining government policy as enunciated by the Prime Minister. Not only is there not in my recollection any requirement of ATSIC to take account of government policy as enunciated by the Prime Minister, but their charter, in fact, is to be independent of the government.

PARA.TAB: There is an overriding power of direction from the minister to ATSIC to be taken in the last resort—a power I might add which he has never to the best of my knowledge ever exercised. If we had wanted an organisation—and I can safely say this in terms of the policy foundation of ATSIC—to take all of its decisions consistent with government policy announced by the Prime Minister, we probably would have kept the operations entirely within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, where that could easily have been accommodated. The reason the government—and this is a political point not a legal point—established ATSIC was deliberately to have a process where Aboriginal people could make decisions independent of the government and indeed, and it is a matter of public record, at times in conflict with the government.

It is a matter of public record that the chair and the board of ATSIC have on many occasions disagreed with the government, and we have had that out in the public domain. That is something we are very comfortable with. That is one reason why ATSIC was established—to allow Aboriginal people to express a view.

I am not a lawyer. I might be absolutely up the creek on this one. Just as a lay person reading a judgment, I was fascinated that one of the grounds relied upon was `to take account of the obligation that ATSIC had to have regard to government policy as enunciated by the Prime Minister'. I do not believe they have any such obligation. I do not believe there is any provision in the act—and I will check later—that requires them to do so. I found that a curious part of the judgment.

Having said that, let me say that there is another section of the judgment that attracted my interest, where the judge placed great value on documents talking about ATSIC's obligations to be equitable in its distribution of grants. I say, again as a non-lawyer: does this mean that it has to be equitable in each and every year of the allocations? Can the equity be considered over a period, for example, of 10 years? I ask the question: would it be open to the ATSIC board to take a decision on land acquisition in one year which was deliberately designed to correct what they saw as the inequity of distributions in previous years? Is that necessarily inequitable? I do not think so. Is there a requirement for ATSIC year by year or allocation by allocation to be equitable, in that sense, on a yearly allocation? I am not sure.

These are important questions in the judgment that need to be looked at. I do not know. I am curious about that in respect of the judgment. As I said before, the fundamental curiosity I have about the judgment is that, as one of the two grounds on which the judge said he relied for his decision, he relied upon a ground that the ATSIC board should have had regard to government policy as enunciated by the Prime Minister. I would like some lawyer who is smarter than I am to point out where in the act or anywhere else—

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps you should have been the lawyer.

—I am not a lawyer. I say that, as a lay person, reading the judgment, I am curious about that. The lawyers will tell me later where I am wrong, I have no doubt. The fundamental question is: does this conspiracy exist? Are there grounds for wasting more of the Senate's time and public money in pursuing this obsession? I do not believe so. I urge the Senate to judge this motion for what it is—grandstanding and time wasting by the Western Australian Greens and the opposition on an issue that has been fully investigated in all the processes of this chamber, in the courts and in the press. I urge the Senate to reject the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to a couple of things the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) said which I think demonstrate either his will to further confuse or mislead this chamber in relation to these matters or a very sad lack of perception as to the judgment. He has said he is not a lawyer. Nor am I. He has said he is a mug politician.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I do happen to have, believe it or not, an extraordinary regard for the parliamentary system. I cannot think of anything that offends me more than a suggestion that I would mislead the parliament. I do not mind the first bit of it, but the rest is imputing motives that I in fact do not have. I ask Senator Campbell to withdraw that imputation. I would never mislead the Senate, not deliberately.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I put it as one of a number of alternatives.

—It had certain overtones of a deliberate intention to mislead. If, however, it was an unintended intention or neutral aspect to mislead, there is no need to overrule. You could advise the chair of your intention.

—I will, in the interests of getting on with the debate, and with respect to the minister's intention, withdraw any connotation that he intentionally sought to mislead. But I will say that I found much of what he said to be confused. He, on his own admission, has said that he is not a lawyer, and, I must say, I am not either. A number of aspects of what he said misconstrue what the judgment was all about in the first place.

PARA.TAB: We are here to debate the motion of the Greens from Western Australia about the need for an inquiry into this matter. This matter is a very important one. When we first saw this legislation, we smelled a rat. We saw a convoluted scheme. We raised it prior to October, if I remember correctly; we raised it at the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in October; we raised it throughout the lengthy debate on this matter; and we raised it again, with some anger and vigour, when ATSIC announced its decision.

The judgment does not refer to a deal. It was not a judgment about whether a deal was done. It was not a judgment that sought to find evidence of a deal. What it found was that the person who wrote a minute, a briefing note, which was given to ATSIC commissioners had put in that briefing note on the decision that was to be preferred by the ATSIC commissioners that it was based on discussions with the government.

Senator Bob Collins will have us believe—and he may well be right or he may be wrong—that all the discussions we are talking about took place at that meeting in June 1994. If Senator Bob Collins can assure the Senate that there were no other discussions about the land fund, either prior to that date or since that date or since the passing of legislation, then I will go home and I will rest easy. But I do not think Senator Bob Collins would even seek to tell us that that would be the case. I would be very surprised; in fact, I would be disappointed.

TALK.START.PARA: —How would discussions since be relevant?

—I am sure we will actually talk about that in the future. I hope you do listen, and I hope I am able to impart some knowledge to you that you do not already have. Could I just go back to the minister, who seeks, referring to page 46 of the judgment, to talk about how the judge found there was no evidence.
—Before the court.
—He did not say that there was no evidence. He said, `There is no evidence before me.'
—Ha, ha!

—If you want to be further amused by the judgment, Minister, you might also go and look at what the words `no evidence before me emerges' mean in the language of this judge. I am not someone who actually goes around reading a lot of judgments. I really prefer to read other things. I have read the Mabo judgment. I have read the odd judgment here and there.
—The judge can only have regard to the evidence before the court.

—Of course. But I do prefer to read other things. On page 46, on another issue, the judge uses—of course, as you say, Minister, by way of interjection—the words `as there was no evidence before me', as he is required to do, and he talks about the `connivance' of the Indigenous Land Corporation.

PARA.TAB: This is a very important point. He says that the scheme, to be successful, if there was some discussion with the government, would require the `connivance' of the Indigenous Land Corporation. First, ATSIC has to make a decision to spend virtually all of its money in the Northern Territory, then it has to go to the ILC and say, `We don't want you to spend any of your money in the Northern Territory,' and the ILC then has to have a meeting and agree to do that. The judge has said:

SPEECH.PARA: It hoped—
and he refers, of course, to ATSIC—

for the connivance, in this end, of the Indigenous Land Corporation. That corporation has not yet made any grant, nor, so far as the evidence before me emerges, has it reacted to the suggestion that it play its part in the connivance. It would be inappropriate for the Indigenous Land Corporation to assist in frustrating the evident policy behind section 191U.

That evidence—and we cannot question this judgment, I presume—was obviously not before the judge. But the senators who follow this debate and the poor public who are following this debate know very well that that evidence is before us, because back in June a press release was issued by the Indigenous Land Corporation saying that, indeed, they had. They would not have said they connived but, to use the judge's word, that `connivance' was given public airing. The first meeting of the ILC board was held and part of that connivance was agreed and published. Indeed, David Ross, now the chief of the ILC, held a press conference in this very building the day after and told the public of Australia that his part in the connivance had been achieved.

PARA.TAB: So, of course, that was one bit of evidence that was not before this judge, before the Federal Court. Another piece of evidence that was not before the Federal Court was the so-called discussions with the government referred to in the minute. There may well not have been evidence before this Federal Court in relation to that matter. Senator Collins would have us believe that nowhere in the world is there evidence as to discussions with the government.

There are probably only one or two people who know about any so-called discussions with the government. Senator Collins gives what may well be a very valid reason why the person who wrote that minute or that briefing note described them as discussions with the government. It may be entirely innocent. But it is not innocent for those who will have, through this decision making process, their dispossession entrenched as a result of the scheme that was set up as a result of discussions with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). This scheme emerged because of discussions with the Prime Minister.

This committee proposed by Senator Chamarette to be established by way of this motion would seek to look at the establishment of that scheme and to look at the discussions that took place with the government. Quite clearly, the government and the Prime Minister have absolutely nothing to fear from this inquiry if there was no sort of connivance, if there was no sort of agreement, if there was no sort of discussion that would have led the person who wrote that minute to believe that the Prime Minister had not misled the parliament. I hope for the sake of Australia and for the sake of Aboriginal affairs that the Prime Minister did not mislead the parliament; but these are matters that do need to be resolved.

My view, after having given this much thought over the past weeks and certainly much thought since Justice Hill brought down this judgment yesterday, is that the Senate select committee process is the best way to do it. I do not envisage, as having previously chaired the land fund bill inquiry, that this select committee would need to—

TALK.START.PARA: —How much did that cost?
—Senator Kernot, you are concerned about that. I cannot give you the answer to that question. But if you are genuinely concerned, I am sure you could ask the clerk to provide that information to you.
—It undertook a lot of travel.

—It did a lot of travel; it did 12 hearings in something like 11 days and spoke to something like 400 witnesses. All of that is now in the records of the Senate, and I think it was a very worthwhile exercise.

PARA.TAB: I have given thought to how this investigation should take place. I have no doubt that it must take place. An enormous number of questions remain unanswered. They are not questions that the Federal Court was asked to decide; it has decided a range of issues and I believe that the minister has confused the chamber. Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not seek to say that he even sought to confuse the chamber deliberately, but the judgment does not go to that.

A lot of public policy issues need to be resolved. My first view was that we should find an existing committee structure to do this investigation to basically save the problem of having to go through this lengthy debate and establish a new committee. I looked at the estimates committee process and I of course saw the sort of intransigence and lack of success with which Senator Chamarette has been confronted to date after an enormous amount of effort on her behalf and that of her staff, Cathcart Weatherly, who I guess has been subtly attacked by the minister in here. But I am sure Cathcart won't mind that.

Secondly, we could have gone down the track of looking at a standing committee. I am informed by the clerk that the relevant standing committee is that very distinguished committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, on which I have had the great pleasure and honour of serving with you for some five years. I believe that because of the workload, the incredible number of references and the incredible number of hearing days that that committee has planned between now and Christmas that it would be entirely inappropriate for that committee to hear yet another reference—a reference that that committee does not have an institutional knowledge of.

The alternative committee I contemplated—and Senator Kernot has foreshadowed that she may be amending the motion before the chamber at the moment in this regard—is the Joint Committee on Native Title which has had a name change to the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Fund. There are two practical reasons why that is not the appropriate committee to conduct this inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's the cost of these committees a day?

—I will get to that, Senator Sherry. That is a very good question and it is one that I sought the answer to. Stay tuned and you will get the answer. There are two good reasons why the joint standing committee should not hear this reference. The first one is that the Joint Committee on Native Title has one of the heaviest workloads in this parliament. It is charged with the responsibility of conducting a major review of the native title legislation on the second anniversary of that legislation in December.

PARA.TAB: It has now entered into discussions as to how to conduct that review which is very important for all people in Australia, be they in industry or be they Aboriginals. It has also scheduled visits to other parts of Australia and has meetings organised with Justice French and a range of other people. I know from a meeting of that committee on Wednesday morning that it would be entirely inappropriate and impractical for that committee to conduct this inquiry.

To answer Senator Sherry's question, a select committee can be formed without the Senate incurring much additional cost. It is quite likely that the committee would not need to move out of the building because a lot of these matters relate to ATSIC and the personnel the committee would need to take evidence from are based here. The staff of the Senate Select Committee on the Land Fund, with the exception of one person, were seconded from other committees. This committee could do the same. I am informed by the clerk that the additional costs of setting up a Senate select committee that has a short reporting date and that does not travel away from Canberra—

TALK.START.PARA: —We heard that before about a whole range of committees.

—You can stand up and debate the issue with me if you like. I am telling you as candidly as I can the process I have gone through to reach the decision that I have taken and that the opposition supports me in making—that is, that a Senate select committee is the most appropriate structure to undertake this review.

PARA.TAB: The coalition will support the motion moved by Senator Chamarette. We will listen carefully to Senator Kernot's points in relation to the joint standing committee. I have privately told her my reservations and I have now put those on the public record. I am not going to say that I will totally knock that out of the court, but I would not hold my breath, Senator Kernot, waiting for the coalition to support it.

There was one other practical argument I did not put to the chamber in relation to the joint standing committee—that is, it has an institutional knowledge and also a statutory obligation to oversee the Native Title Act and more recently the ILC legislation. The substance of the motion that Senator Chamarette has put to this chamber only incidentally touches on the land fund. The guts of the inquiry, to use a colloquialism, is indeed about the processes within ATSIC, which certainly come under the purview of that joint standing committee.

I do not say that that is the biggest argument against it. I think the practical side of it is what weighs most heavily on my mind. I am not entirely sure that that is even appropriate because the joint standing committee does not have much of an institutional knowledge of the processes of ATSIC—it certainly has developed one in relation to the Native Title Act—and it is a matter of being able to conduct that inquiry in an efficient and effective manner so that progress can be made. That is the coalition's position on this motion.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Before calling Senator Kernot, let me inform the Senate that a question was asked about the costs of the land fund Senate committee. I have been advised that the costs are $90,000, comprising $66,000 in administrative costs and $24,000 in salaries. I remind honourable senators that these costs exclude senators' travelling costs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of issues overlap with respect to this debate that we are having. There are a lot of principles and there is a lot politics that we have been revisiting since we began dealing with the native title legislation a couple of years ago. It is my personal view that some of the issues we are still debating go back to the politics of the native title legislation. I will come back to that in a moment.

PARA.TAB: Look at where we are. ATSIC made a decision. People expressed surprise and other emotions about the decision that was made to quarantine that amount of money over two years for the purchase of land in the Northern Territory. However, we have talked a lot in this place about self-determination. It is true, I think we should argue, that ATSIC had the right to make that decision in the same way as those who feel aggrieved by that decision had the right to appeal that decision. They did that. The Federal Court set the ATSIC decision aside.

It seems to me that one sensible course of action would be for us to wait and see what ATSIC does now. We do not know whether ATSIC will appeal or whether the board of commissioners will revisit that decision. That is one option. It also seems to me that the numbers in this place are very close to deciding on some kind of inquiry. Perhaps we will get down to that in a minute.

There has been a bit of inconsistency when we have talked about self-determination in here. I vividly remember the disagreement we had in the land fund debate over whether self-determination meant that individuals should be allowed to purchase land and then sell it to others, thereby, I argued, undermining the amount of land to be held in the land stock. In terms of self-determination, it would affect the capacity of many other indigenous people to, for example, inherit that land. So you cannot be selective. It is okay in the case of that land fund debate for self-determination to exist to that extent, but it is not okay for it to exist as it applies to ATSIC's right to make a decision with which we may disagree. I really want to point that out. There has been some great inconsistency about whether we accept self-determination.

I acknowledge that there was disquiet about the decision. I acknowledge that we have a right to discuss how we should deal with that disquiet. My first option would be for ATSIC to have the opportunity to take whatever decision it chooses to next. The second point I would highlight is whether there have been adequate opportunities for those members of parliament, including those in the Senate, to scrutinise the material surrounding that decision. As I understand it, there has been a combination of numerous freedom of information requests, which have been complied with—those requests have been served on both the government and ATSIC—and many documents from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read this, it's a disgrace. There's a lot blacked out.

—But that often happens in freedom of information, doesn't it? There have been three hours in estimates with Lois O'Donoghue and Pat Turner from ATSIC in attendance. There has been a lot of time in parliament, including a long censure motion of the government. There have been returns to order which have been complied with.
—Partially complied with.

—In your view, partially complied with but supplemented by other procedures. As I understand it, Senator Campbell, you referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I understand you used the opportunity on that committee to pursue this issue when you were meeting in Adelaide. You yourself have had another opportunity to pursue this matter.
—No, October 1994.

—Having had all those opportunities for scrutiny, the case has been taken to the Federal Court and the Federal Court set ATSIC's decision aside. We have to ask: what else are we going to achieve from another parliamentary inquiry? That is where I think the politics comes into it. I said when I began that I think we have inherited a lot of politics from the native title debate.

PARA.TAB: That is not unnatural. The native title debate saw the emergence of a new group of Aboriginal spokespeople. The crudest interpretation of it is that some who had been accustomed to speaking for Aboriginal people in a very public way did not really like this realignment. So we had two groups. That was unusual. Normally we have expected some monolithic view from indigenous people.

In the essence of this request for a committee inquiry, we have a continuation of the debate about the A-team versus the B-team, sovereignty versus non-sovereignty and whether ATSIC should incorporate the views of sovereignty. That is what it is. It is a continuation of Aboriginal politics. We should keep out of it. We should let them get on with sorting out the way they want to deal with these issues as in fact the New South Wales Land Council did in taking this issue to the Federal Court. That is a totally appropriate way to deal with this issue.

The second layer of politics we have, which is a reality and which will continue to mirror things that we see in our own society, is the rivalry between the larger, more entrenched, more wealthy land councils who have had success in claiming a reasonable amount of land for their people because they happen to come from states where there is a lot of land able to be claimed. So we have a continuation of this. Again, I think we should stay out of that, except I agree with you on the matter of due process.

Is that, of itself, sufficient for us to warrant setting up a select committee? I do not think so. To answer some of the questions Senator Campbell raised about why he said it should be a select committee, it is not just a matter of cost but of course we should be conscious of the cost of all the committees we set up here. It is not just a matter of cost, for me it is a matter of appropriateness.

I remember we had the debate. We said, `Let's include monitoring of the implementation of the land fund under the purview of the existing joint standing committee.' I remember saying at the time that it was a good idea because it is a flow-on from native title and those people will have expertise. I think it is good too that it is a joint committee because it means that those in the other house can also have input and be kept up to date with the monitoring.

I do not think it is impractical—although I would be interested to hear from the chair of the committee, Senator Chris Evans—to send this matter to this committee in view of what Senator Chris Evans advised me when I consulted him: his committee is definitely able to deal with a reference to it without any great delay.

I am not persuaded that we need to set up another select committee. It is not my first preference. I believe we should wait and see how ATSIC deals with it. If we are to have a committee, it is the Democrats' preference that we refer a different term of reference to the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. I have given the Senate my reasons for that belief.

I seek to change the terms of reference to include part (a) only of Senator Chamarette's motion because I think it is appropriate to acknowledge the disquiet. But I want to exclude the assumptions of conspiracies, deceptions or whatever. I believe that it is much more appropriate to say that we note the continuing disquiet. Because section 206 of the Native Title Act says that it is appropriate to do so, we therefore refer part (a) only. We refer this matter to the committee for inquiry and report on or before 30 September 1995.

I do not want to walk away from scrutinising decisions of other bodies, but does this mean that if ICAC makes a particular decision against the New South Wales Land Council we then say that we want to look at that in here as well? When do we stop saying, `We want to have another look at these things as well'? I think there have been enormous opportunities for scrutiny. I believe we have had almost sufficient time devoted in this chamber in the last few years to important issues like this.

I do not think we should go down the path of yet another select committee, in the same way as I did not think we should do that relating to the legal expenses being paid to Dr Carmen Lawrence. We successfully sought to refer that matter to an existing committee—the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee. For those reasons, I move:
Omit all words after "That", substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: "the Senate notes continuing disquiet among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people about the decision of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Board to set aside $10 million for land purchases in the Northern Territory and $2 million for other priority national purchases in each of the next two years and resolves that, pursuant to section 206 of the Native Title Act 1993, this matter be referred to the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, for inquiry and report on or before 30 September 1995".

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not prepared to vote for the entirety of Senator Chamarette's motion in the way it is currently framed. However, I adopt the view that I have always adopted here: if there is a matter of widespread concern about a particular issue one should not stand in the way of an examination of that particular issue before a committee. I think that is the point Senator Kernot was making.

PARA.TAB: I have thought about the matter. Unless there is some convincing expression in Senator Chamarette's response, I am not prepared to vote for the first part of her motion. In my view, parts (a), (b), (c) and (d) are unnecessary. When it comes to part (2) of the motion, I believe that part (a) should be deleted. I foreshadow a further amendment which would delete part (1) of the motion and substitute certain words in lieu of those currently contained in part (2)(a).

I suggest that because this morning I saw the decision of the Federal Court in respect of the action that was taken by the New South Wales Land Council and the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre. I think it would be rather strange if, in a motion on the very day after the decision was made—and I think he made it yesterday, did he?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—That on the very day after the decision has been made, we should not advert to that. I would be adverting to that in substitute paragraph (a) to note the Federal Court decision or to suggest that we should, in light of that decision, which set aside the ATSIC decision about which there has been a certain amount of concern, examine the process that led to that decision. I think that may be appropriate.

PARA.TAB: I must acknowledge ATSIC and thank ATSIC for providing me with a letter in the last two days which explained its situation. I must say that nothing that has been said by me should be taken as a reflection—and I have never reflected, as far as I can recall—on ATSIC, particularly on its executive director or its chairperson. I just make that point very clear so that we might be able to short-circuit this by removing the first part and by changing part (2)(a) along the lines that I mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —It still says `a select committee'.
—I am sorry, (2)(a) does say `a select committee', Senator Kernot. I have heard what you said.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Order! Comments through the chair, please. Hansard are having trouble.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard what Senator Kernot said. I listened to what Senator Chamarette and Senator Campbell said about the matter.
—Listen to what the chair says.

—Yes, I am going to listen to what the chair of the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund is about to say. It seems to me that this is a sort of focused matter which is more appropriate for a select committee. I also acknowledge the advice that I was given from the minister's office about this and I know that there would be an ability by the joint committee to consider this. But this is a particularly focused matter which, to my mind, is more appropriate to have before a select committee which has an early reporting date and which, naturally, as has been indicated, would not mean a great expenditure of money. Having said that and having foreshadowed my views, I will now listen to what the chairman of the joint committee might have to say.

—I feel a certain pressure now, Senator Harradine, by those remarks of yours, but I want to enter the debate purely to put a few comments on the record based on the role of the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Fund, because it has been raised as an issue in this debate. I think it is appropriate to say that, in my view, if the numbers are in the Senate for this matter to be referred to a committee, then it is appropriate that the committee that was established by this parliament to be responsible for native title and, more recently, for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander land fund matters ought, some two months later, be given the opportunity to fulfil the role that we as a Senate decided it ought to have.

PARA.TAB: I can say that the committee did finalise its program for the year at a meeting the other day. There was nothing in that discussion that ruled out our ability to handle a reference of a piece of legislation or any other matter. Given the proposed reporting date of 30 September, I do not see there would be any difficulty in the committee dealing appropriately, and with responsiveness, to any resolution with that sort of deadline.

I did raise one matter with the committee about its workload towards the end of November, which related to my partner's expectation of our second child. I did make it clear that I was not too keen on our having hearing dates around that time, but the deadline of 30 September should allow us—barring any premature birth—to accommodate my duties there as well as to the Senate.

I would say that the committee so far has been a very good committee of the parliament. It has worked with consensus and has been able to put down two unanimous reports. I accept that this sort of political reference will challenge the committee's ability to maintain that consensus. But I do think the committee is building up a reputation as a positive influence in the debate in Aboriginal affairs. We are building up a rapport with many of the key players and a certain expertise both in the secretariat and in the members of the committee.

In essence, I think it is appropriate, therefore, that we continue the work. The reality is that, if a select committee is established, the same players—Senator Campbell, Senator Chamarette and I—will find ourselves in another guise doing the same job, so to that extent, I suppose, one could argue that it does not matter. But I am personally, as chairman, a bit disappointed that other members of the native title committee do not feel it can perform this function.

Given that this was the role the parliament set for it—and we actually changed our name to include the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund only a month or two ago—it is quite clearly within our area of expertise and within our competence. If we have all been honest about this, I think this really comes down to an issue about whether or not the opposition or the government have the numbers on the particular committee.

Senator Harradine, I put to you that the difference between the reference going to the native title committee or the select committee is that, on the native title committee, the Labor Party has five members; the opposition, four; and the Greens, one. I suppose there is some concern that the government may use its numbers there. The proposition from Senator Chamarette provides for two nominations—

TALK.START.PARA: —Two out of seven.

—Two out of seven provided by the Labor Party, three by the opposition, one by the Australian Democrats and one by the Greens or Senator Harradine. So, clearly, this is a question more about the numbers on the committee.

PARA.TAB: There is no logical reason in terms of expertise, workload and cost. There is no justification for this reference to go anywhere else. I do not want to get too precious about it, because it is clearly about political numbers on that committee. I think that is a bit disappointing because I am sure the committee would be able to deal with the reference maturely and responsibly—if not continue the tradition of unanimous reports, but we would have to hear the evidence before we came to that conclusion.

This is really about the politics of who has the numbers on the committee. Let us be honest about that. If the view is that, to have a proper committee in the Senate, the opposition and the Greens have to have the numbers, then so be it. But I think the committee has operated in a constructive manner and is more than capable of accepting and dealing properly with any reference. I do not want to add any further remarks; thank you.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to the amendments that have been proposed by Senator Kernot and Senator Harradine. First of all, I want to reply to the comments made by Senator Collins in his response on behalf of the government. I have no problems with groups of people making decisions that I do not agree with. I am more than happy for any group of Aboriginal people or non-Aboriginal people to make a decision, as long as it is a proper decision. What we are talking about here is a decision which was part of a debate and about which concern was expressed. The Federal Court set it aside, and it found that the ATSIC board decision in all the circumstances was so unreasonable that no reasonable decision maker could come to it. I believe having a double standard for Aboriginal groups or non-Aboriginal groups is just as patronising and wrong as the kinds of implications and imputations that have been directed towards me.

PARA.TAB: I affirm everybody's right to make decisions that they are entitled to make, but I believe that where they are subject to administrative law or to the courts they should be able to answer that scrutiny. Secondly, I agree that this parliament has not abrogated its role in the setting up of ATSIC in looking at the way government expenditure—about which we debated on a piece of legislation in this chamber—is dealt with. So I believe there is evidence, and I do not think it is fair to accuse me of some kind of grudge or inability to accept that Aboriginal people can make their own decisions. I have no problem with that. The implication of Senator Collins was that that was the case.

Senator Collins stated that the evidence does not exist and used that as the reason or proof that there was nothing to look at in this inquiry. If the evidence was not able to be produced to the Federal Court in those circumstances, we have to ask ourselves why. How could it be that the ATSIC CEO and the ATSIC legal officer could present a brief, which was the basis of this decision that has been set aside, to the ATSIC board that was so manifestly wrong? We have a responsibility to look at that, scrutinise it and set it up in such a way that the ATSIC board is not misinformed about government decisions, parliamentary decisions and its own options about which it can make its own decisions.

Thirdly, Senator Collins said that ATSIC had no obligation to have a regard for government policy and that it has a right to be independent. He queried the implication that ATSIC should comply with the commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. I quite understand that, but my understanding of the way it was referred to in the court judgment was simply to explain that the brief which was purporting to present an agreement made between ATSIC and the Prime Minister did not reflect something that the Prime Minister had said was government policy in the House of Representatives debate.

The fourth point was one that Senator Collins made about equity. He discussed the possibility that that can be seen over the long term and that we should overlook the inequity that is patently obvious in this decision because it might all even itself out. Senator Campbell's reference that there is a danger of being additionally conniving to perpetuate inequity needs to be looked at. I think he raised that point quite adequately.

The arguments against Senator Kernot's amendment, which I do not support, are four-fold. Firstly, the reason I believe that it is not appropriate is that it blurs the terms of reference, and it makes its inquiry and report by 30 September as the only basis for that committee to operate. Secondly, it suggests a joint committee rather than a Senate committee. I have had personal experience with difficulties of this Senate imposing terms of reference on a joint standing committee. I will not go into details, but I can assure you that a joint committee does not usually take very kindly to the Senate imposing terms of reference on it—as I found in the reference relating to women's representation in parliament to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters.

The third point I want to make—one that Senator Evans appropriately raised—is that I believe there is a reason that a Senate committee could be more appropriate than the joint standing committee.
