In political terms, because the government has the numbers on that standing committee and we are asking government members to be part of that committee that may well put them in a conflict of interest. If government members are expected to defend the hostile approach to these investigations that its representatives—namely, Senator Collins, Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Faulkner—during estimates have demonstrated, then I am not optimistic that a fair result will ensue.

I have no concerns about Senator Chris Evans as the chair of the committee; it is more the political matter he raised about numbers. He can easily argue—and I will leave it up to the Senate—that, because a select committee might have the numbers that relate to the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens, we are using that. My point is that we are putting the government in an invidious position by taking a committee where it has the numbers and where it may have a particular view. As we are looking to matters that cast some question over the procedures of a government agency and also of the Prime Minister it would be better in terms of that accountability to have a committee that was swayed in the terms of the opposition.

There is a precedent to my decision on the numbers in that I opposed a reference going to a select committee where the opposition had the numbers in a case where I felt there may have been a conflict of interest in those terms. It means that there is a balance on that committee, which cannot be accused of having been biased in the government's favour or of having covered up. I believe that committee will be able to address the matters that are brought before it in a way that cannot be compromised if they do come forward to clear ATSIC, the Prime Minister or the government of any difficulties in that regard.

The fourth point is that it may well be that the topic we are addressing is not best kept in the purview of the native title committee because the topic of this reference is to look at ATSIC, rather than the express purpose of the committee, which is to review the operation of the Native Title Act and the ATSIC Indigenous Land Corporation. If there is any ill-feeling engendered by this inquiry in relation to the topic under examination then it is best to set it up separately.

TALK.START.PARA: —Land fund.

—Senator Kernot informs me that I have just, in error, referred to the native title committee as referring to ATSIC and the ILC rather than to the land fund. I accept that. Thank you, Senator Kernot. For those reasons I would rather not see the matter referred to the joint committee on native title, as is proposed in Senator Kernot's amendment. But I acknowledge that, with Senator Evans, there is expertise on the native title committee. I have no quarrel with that. I have mentioned my concerns. I believe it is not a slight matter that we are looking at ATSIC rather than, and only incidentally, at the land fund in this case. I am happy to accept Senator Harradine's proposed amendment. I would be prepared to look at that. I encourage the chamber to support this motion with the amendment I am happy to accept of Senator Harradine.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Kernot's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand now that Senator Harradine wants to move an amendment which he has not circulated. Perhaps he could read it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: Paragraph (1), omit the paragraph.

SPEECH.PARA: Subparagraph (2)(a), omit the subparagraph, substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(a)In the light of the Federal Cout decision of 30 August 1995 which set aside the ATSIC Board decision of March 1995 `that in all the circumstances was so unreasonable that no reasonable decision maker could come to it,' to examine the process which led to that decision".

SPEECH.PARA: Subparagraphs (2)(b) and (d), omit the subparagraphs.
I understand that that is now a matter that may be acceptable to a broad range of senators.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the establishment of a Senate inquiry by the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee into the consular services available to Australians abroad, including an investigation of foreign judicial proceedings involving Australians,

(ii)the predicament of an Australian academic, Dr John Flynn, held in detention without trial since June 1994 in Tihar Jail, New Delhi, India, under what is reputably claimed to be a `trumped-up' coin smuggling charge, and
(iii)the precarious medical condition of 59-year-old Dr Flynn, who is presently under guard in intensive care in a nearby hospital;

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Australian Government to take urgent action to secure the release of Dr Flynn pending a proper resolution of this matter; and
(c)draws the case of Dr Flynn to the attention of the Senate inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a brief statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this motion—apart from drawing attention to this problem—is basically to request that the Senate inquiry include the issue relating to Dr Flynn in its inquiries. It is not a direction to the Senate inquiry, but I understand by my making this kind of request and drawing the attention of the Senate inquiry to this motion that it has the effect of requesting the Senate inquiry to include the case of Dr Flynn in its inquiries. I commend the motion to the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In making this personal explanation, I just want to highlight the warped standards of Senator Collins.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! If you are making a personal explanation, it should be about a reflection on you. You have started by making comments about another senator. I do not think that is quite in order for a personal explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave leave to make this.
—You did not.
—Order! You were given leave to make a personal explanation. I call upon you to make that personal explanation.

—I briefly want to explain why the personal explanation is necessary. I sought the leave of the Senate earlier to answer a question specifically put to me by Senator Collins and Senator Collins refused that leave.
—It was after question time.

—So what. I asked for leave and Senator Collins, after having asked me a question and made inferences in that question, then refused to give me leave to answer the question. I just want to highlight the standards with regard to questions being asked and the leave not being given. The personal explanation I wish to make relates to a committee inquiry into regional and rural affairs being set up by the federal Liberal Party organisation. I take this opportunity simply to emphasise and highlight the work of this particular committee.

PARA.TAB: In 1948, the federal Liberal Party established a regional and rural committee. It was one of earliest committees set up by the Liberal Party federally. I am very happy to indicate that this committee has been given a reference to conduct an inquiry into the lack of services available in regional Australia. Under this government, those services are very much lacking. In making this personal explanation, I want to highlight the work that this committee will be doing. The committee will be working right around Australia taking evidence—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald, you are straying a little into the work of the committee rather than the personal explanation. If you contain your remarks to those that affect you personally, that would fit within the ambit of what a personal explanation in the Senate is about.
—Thank you for your help. This committee comprises a number of elected people.
—But not you.

—Not me. I am also not on the coalition's committee overseeing regional development. There are a number of other committees that I am not on, and nor is any other shadow minister. I suspect that none of the people on the front bench opposite are on any of the committees of the Labor Party. I suspect that they are much the same.

PARA.TAB: The committee contains a number of very good people. The Queensland representative is Mr David Crombie, who is a practical farmer and businessman. There are a number of other very worthwhile and appropriate people from around Australia on it. My federal parliamentary colleague Mr David Hawker is the chairman of that committee. The committee also comprises Mr Neil Andrew. David Hawker was on that committee long before I came into parliament. He replaced Mr Neil Andrew, also a parliamentary colleague, who was chairman of that committee long before I came into the parliament. Most of the members of the committee have been on that committee for a long time.

I enthusiastically endorse and support the work of that committee. I will be circulating appropriate rural groups in Queensland to ensure that they are given the opportunity of making submissions to the committee to expose this government's absolute insensitivity to the people of rural and regional Australia. As the shadow minister and someone who has been in parliament for only a relatively short time, I am not on that party organisation committee. But the people on it are excellent. It is a very good committee. That committee will investigate the lack of services in health, rail, infrastructure and disaster relief amongst others.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald, you are testing things. You are back to canvassing the merits of the committee as whole rather than the personal explanation. I ask you to confine your remarks to those elements that refer specifically to you.
—I know it is sad, Senator.

—Nobody ever takes any notice of Senator Collins. The only reason I raise this is simply to highlight the very good work that that committee will do. It is a committee that I enthusiastically support. It will highlight the inadequacies of this government in rural and regional Australia.
—I seek leave to move that the Senate take note of the personal explanation. I am sure that leave will be granted.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Is leave granted?

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely not.
—What! After me giving leave to you! What a yellow-bellied boofhead you are. You are gutless.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think Senator Collins's last statement was unparliamentary and unwarranted. He should withdraw.
—Senator Collins, did you make remarks that were unparliamentary? I unfortunately could not hear what you said. If you did, would you withdraw them.

—I certainly will withdraw. In withdrawing, I table the press statement setting up this committee, which is actually headed by the parliamentary Leader of the Opposition, John Howard. Senator Paul Calvert from Tasmania is on it. Half of the coalition back bench and front bench are on it.
—On a point of order: Senator Collins is out of order. Senator Collins is not entitled to put on the public record that Senator Ian Macdonald in fact misled this house.
—I table the press statement, which points out the fact that almost everyone is on this committee, except the shadow minister.
—I would like to know how come—

—Order! Senator Collins, please resume your seat. Senator Panizza, please resume your seat. I have been a bit lax in exercising control here in the last few moments. I intend from now on to be quite precise in the rulings. I have asked Senator Collins to withdraw if he made remarks which were unparliamentary. Senator Collins did make what I rule to be a conditional withdrawal. I ask you now, Senator Collins, to make an unconditional withdrawal.
—Of course I comply.
—This is Senator Collins talking.
—Order! Senator Collins has the call.
—We did not give him leave to take note of the answer.
—I have not seen you, I have not recognised you, Senator Panizza. Senator Collins, I have asked you for an unconditional withdrawal.
—That is the reason I rose.
—So you have unconditionally withdrawn.
—Absolutely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the report from the Bureau of Industry Economics that Australian waterfront efficiency is declining in several key areas,
(ii)that the completion of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority's reforms in 1992 only increased Australian ports' competitiveness for a short time and now there is notable decline, and

(iii)the report says that, in a survey of 18 common destinations, ship operators rated Australian ports in comparison with Asian, European and North American ports as follows: Brisbane 12th, Adelaide 15th, Melbourne 17th and Sydney 18th, and that 85 per cent of ship companies surveyed said turnaround times had improved faster overseas than in Australia for the past 5 years; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Government and the Minister responsible to explain to the Australian shipping industry why the above situation exists when Australian taxpayers funded $450 million in 1992 on waterfront reform, obviously a total waste.

SPEECH.PARA: This is certainly the latest time—6.15 p.m.—we have started general business since we have been in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you have a 2 1/2-hour question time? You have to pay a penalty.
—It has nothing to do with a penalty. It should start at 4.30 p.m.
—You voted for it.
—How long have you been here? General business starts at 4.30 p.m, you idiot.
—Oh, I see. I am required to withdraw but—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator Panizza—

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw. I was dismayed yesterday to read in the Sydney Morning Herald and the Australian Financial Review about the state of our waterfront. The headline in the Sydney Morning Herald was `Waterfront reform too slow, study reveals' and the headline in the Australian Financial Review was `Report slams Australia's waterfronts'.

PARA.TAB: Going back to about 1991 we heard very much about Australia's waterfront reform where some $430 million or $450 million was allocated for this reform. Senator Collins, especially at the time he was Minister for Transport, told us how that waterfront was going to be really reformed and cleaned up. The $430 million or $450 million has been spent, but what have we got for it? Very little from what I can see.

The Bureau of Industry Economics report that I read yesterday referred to what is going on in the waterfront. The report is not yet released. It shows that Australia's waterfront standards still have a disastrous rating even by world standards. Today I asked Senator Collins a question on that. I thought it was a reasonable question to ask because, firstly, it was a very bad report and, secondly, he was the minister at the time and all he could say in reply was no. I asked him if he knew what it was.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perk up a bit. It is supposed to be a vigorous attack.
—Order! Senator Sherry!
—At this hour of the day I can understand that Senator Sherry needs something to keep him going. I will excuse you if you go and do what you want to do.

PARA.TAB: I asked him a simple question hoping that he would give us some reason why the Australian standard on the waterfront, compared to the other 18 normally used ports around the world that we trade with, is disastrous. Is that loud enough, Sherry?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is better.

—I believe that that report was supposed to be released some time ago, but the minister has kept it under wraps. He has been going backwards and forwards because of the BIE review. The BIE review is the government's own review into what goes on in industry and our efficiencies. The matter has been going backwards and forwards so the authors of it would come up with better findings for the government.

PARA.TAB: All this should sound alarm bells for the government. What has the minister decided? Not to release it. An example of what was said in that report can be found in the executive summary. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Recent declines in container stevedoring productivity has resulted in Australia falling well behind similarly sized overseas ports.
Remember, $430-odd million went in. Other examples I would like to quote in the short time we have left on this debate are from the body of the report. It states:
However, rather than witnessing progress in waterfront productivity, the past year has seen some serious setbacks in crane rates.
The overall five port average fell between September 1993 and December 1994.
Another item refers to the national transport planning task force document that was concluded at the end of 1994. It says:

Users and operators also noted recent significant declines in workplace performance and questioned whether present levels of competition were sufficient to maintain the pressure for continuing improvement.

It is little wonder that the government has chosen to use out-of-date figures, as Mr Brereton did yesterday in the House of Representatives when he was answering a question from Mr Sharp, the shadow minister for transport. He used well out-of-date figures, yet he knows that that report is there and waiting for the government to deal with. That is all he could do. I think it goes somewhat towards misleading parliament if you know the report from BIE is there and yet quote out-of-date figures. That act speaks for itself.

PARA.TAB: I will give you another example. In regard to container productivity, most overseas ports have moved ahead while Australia has gone backwards. It has not even maintained that slight improvement it made for that $430 million.

What happened to that $430 million? Almost half of it was used to pay out wharfies to reduce the numbers on the waterfront. At that time, an average wharfie was earning $34,000 a year. At the beginning of this year, the same grade of wharfie was earning $75,000 a year. So under this government, under this restructuring, it went from $34,000 to $75,000. You could say that that could be part of the restructure and the benefits of the restructure. But about half of those who took the package of $100,000 are back on that wharf. The figures are here. That is a total disgrace. This restructure was supposed to have brought about improvements.

One of the figures I found damaging was that it generally takes 50 per cent to 100 per cent longer to unload and load a container ship in Australia than in a comparable overseas port. The report further states:

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, the lowest charges in Australia are equivalent to the more expensive ports of the west coast of North America.

Our lowest charges in Australia are equivalent to their highest. What situation does that put us in in relation to our export industry, which is Australia's income? One must bear in mind that this report has been prepared by the government's own body. It was not done by the coalition, it was not done by the NFF and it was not done by the Chamber of Mines and Energy. It was not done by anyone but the government itself. The government's own body has given it a report that damns its waterfront reform.

PARA.TAB: What did Senator Collins do today? He just dodged the issue, just as Mr Brereton dodged it in the other place. If you cannot rely on the Bureau of Industry Economics, then whom can you rely on to give you an expert judgment on the waterfront, or indeed anything else? That report is there for everyone to read.

The newspaper articles on this report highlighted the survey of 18 common destinations, which rated Australia poorly in comparison to Asia, Europe and North America. We are always told when we compare our waterfront with Asia that Asia has cheaper labour, more labour, more of this, less of that and less of something else. I am willing to leave Asia aside, but to get a true comparison we have to compare ourselves with North America. That is the area we export to with our agricultural, mining and manufacturing exports.

It works both ways. Our exports to the rest of the world go through the wharves and we import machinery and all sorts of products. That is why our balance of payments is always blowing out. We go through the ports twice because, as well as exporting, we bring in machinery, fertiliser, chemicals and that sort of thing. We have to compare ourselves with the rest of the world. How can the government say that things are going well? By Collins's non-answer today?

TALK.START.PARA: —Please address senators by their proper titles.
—I do not know what I have neglected—
—When one is referring to honourable senators, one refers to them by saying `Senator' and then their surname.
—I am sorry; I thought I did.
—You didn't, Senator, and I am asking you to do that.

—I stand corrected. I say, `Mr Brereton' and `Senator Collins'—`Collins, R' to make sure you, Mr Acting Deputy President, do not get mixed up with the other Collins. He said in 1991 that he was going to resign if waterfront reform was not carried out. He reckoned it was all completed. Yesterday in the other place Mr Sharp asked about the situation. Mr Brereton used all the old figures on earth and hid the ones from this report, hoping that no-one had the benefit of that report.

PARA.TAB: How can this government say that things are going well on the waterfront when Sydney—probably in its own opinion the premier port of Australia—is 18th out of those commonly used ports that our exporters and importers have to use. Melbourne, the other so-called top port of Australia, is 17th. Even Adelaide—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Burnie? Where's Burnie?

—Burnie does not even rate, so stop talking about Burnie. Then we come to Adelaide, which I think is a reasonably efficient port. Adelaide rates 15th. That Sydney rates 18th out of 18 does not give anyone confidence in the matter of competing with and exporting to the rest of the world.

PARA.TAB: Instead of reforming the waterfront, the government spent $440-odd million of taxpayers' money on redundancy packages. I do not have the figures, but I presume that the lion's share of that $440 million would have gone to Sydney. Of course, Melbourne would take a fair slice as well. I do not know that the port of Fremantle and the port of Kwinana received too much. We are not talking about a massive number of wharfies; only 4,000 workers were involved in those redundancies.

The government is still telling us what sort of beautiful job it is doing. One simply has to read Mr Brereton's answer to Mr Sharp in the other place yesterday to see another example of this government misrepresenting the truth of how well Australia is performing. Unless this report goes backwards and forwards—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read it?
—Yes, I have read it.
—Why are you quoting from newspapers, then?

—I sent the report over to you but you sent it back to me. I am quoting newspapers because it was from the newspapers that I picked up the information that the report was around. I made it my business to get hold of a copy of the report. If you want to look at the report I am quite happy to lend you mine. Perhaps Mr Brereton will lend you his. Everyone knows that Mr Brereton has the report. If this report keeps going backwards and forwards, one day the pigeons will come home to roost. Unless the report is completely butchered the truth has to come out. Senator Collins lost that portfolio. I do not know whether he lost it because of the waterfront or for some other reason.
—Pay TV.

—That is right. Senator Collins said he would resign if he could not achieve results on the waterfront within 12 months. He gave us some odd figures concerning what he had done. I think he achieved one enterprise agreement. After one enterprise agreement he said he had solved all the problems. He brushed it off. We then see the $440 million going out the door.

PARA.TAB: Of course, he did not resign; he did not have to resign, the Prime Minister moved him because of a misdemeanour with pay TV. Since then he has moved on to primary industries. I will let honourable senators judge Senator Collins's performance in primary industry. The farmers of Australia will also judge him. I know that he has totally neglected the pastoral industry in the east Gascoyne region of Western Australia. I will keep telling him that until I get it through to him.

I believe it is now up to Mr Brereton to resign over this waste of money. What do we have for the $440 million that went out the door? The figures are there. Sydney is 18th on a list of most commonly used ports, Melbourne is 17th, Adelaide is 15th, and Burnie did not rate a mention—it is probably not a commonly used port.

What sort of benchmark do we have for other industries in Australia? What progress can this government point to? When is Mr Brereton going to come clean with this report? I suppose he will come clean one day—if he does not butcher it. When can we expect to be able to compete with the rest of the world on a equal footing? As a primary producer and a small player in the mining industry I am sick and tired of bearing the brunt of micro-economic reform in Australia. If we are going to reform and truly compete, even with subsidised countries, then let us have reform right around the country.

Most things that BHP, the Big Australian, says are taken as a pretty studied judgment. I do not think that anybody, even you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would disagree with the findings of BHP. I will quote what it had to say in its report:

SPEECH.PARA: According to the BHP transport studies, Australia's non-terminal charges and stevedoring costs are high by international standards. Port authority and ancillary charges are the main cause of the difference between Australian and overseas non-terminal break bulk charges.
It goes on:

BHP transport concluded that despite a significant reform process in the stevedoring industry throughout the 1980s and 1990s, the Australian industry still lags behind world best practice. BHP's stevedoring operations have improved but their competitors have as well. As a result, many of BHP's competitors have retained an advantage in stevedoring costs and productivity.

Just another indicator that our waterfront is under-performing by a long way, despite the enormous federal reform program with $440 million already spent. The government always says that things are getting better—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are!
—They are, but when you read that report, as far as the waterfront is concerned, it is very far from the mark. It is just not good enough, as this yet-to-be-released report said in its conclusion.

PARA.TAB: That was also a finding in the BIE report on Australia's coastal shipping released in July of this year. It seems to be the same old story. Despite the improvements in the Australian shipping industry, the rate of improvement has slowed in recent years, and is becoming increasingly slower so that probably, before long, it will be back to pre-1991 standards. They were shocking compared with the rest of the world. The cost of operating vessels has fallen by less than in most other countries. That is why we now have ANL on the market and it is attracting very little interest.

This report found that Australia's competitive cost standing did not change, despite the existence of the supposed shipping reform process. The BIE identified high manning costs—namely, leave and wage on-costs—as the main cause of Australia's uncompetitive position.

The cost of operating vessels in Australia was around 22 per cent higher than in the United Kingdom, and, as far as shipping and the waterfront is concerned, that is not a great country to be comparing yourself with.

The bottom line is how we shape up internationally. As I said, as a primary industry exporter, I am sick and tired of putting up with what we have to put up with. Despite the high costs to the taxpayer, this government's reforms have been very insufficient. It is time that Mr Brereton released that report and got the government to do something about it so that our export industries can truly compete with our trade partners in the world market.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I am conscious of the time available on this matter, but I want to place on record the government's very vigorous reform program and the economic benefits that have flowed from it in the waterfront area. As I said, I am conscious of time. Senator Panizza was a little repetitive. I noticed the frustration of Senator McGauran and a couple of other senators opposite who do want to contribute. We did have a long question time, and time has got away from the program due to the inefficiency of the opposition in running question time today.

PARA.TAB: I did challenge Senator Panizza about whether he had actually read the report. I have read the report and I am a little disappointed that Burnie did not rate a mention. I live in the port of Burnie, Senator Panizza.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you live in the port?

—My front living room looks straight across the national highway into the port of Burnie. I understand it is the fifth largest container terminal in Australia. I am a little disappointed—in fact, I am very disappointed—about your remarks, Senator Panizza. I shall refer your remarks to the member for Braddon, Mr Miles. He does not live on the waterfront in Burnie like me, but he does have his office in Burnie. I think he would be more than a bit disappointed by the throwaway, casual remarks that you made about the port of Burnie.

PARA.TAB: In fact, the port of Burnie has the largest crane in Australia—I was at the opening last year. It is a very impressive port with very progressive leadership and management, and, as I said earlier, it is the fifth largest container traffic port in Australia, which is quite remarkable for a Tasmanian port.

Before I go into more detail on the Bureau of Industry Economics report, I want to express my disappointment at your remarks, Senator Panizza, about Senator Bob Collins's performance as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Even your own colleagues over there were quite shocked that you should make those comments, because they know, like I do, from moving around the rural and regional areas of Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha! You're joking!
—That is not a very pleasant interjection. I was talking to Rick Farley only six or eight weeks ago—
—Rick Farley, he'd be independent, wouldn't he?

—He would be. He is, Senator Panizza. He is only one of the independent people from whom I have seen letters praising Senator Bob Collins's contribution in the area of primary industry. I think you are just being rebuked by Senator Ian Macdonald for interjecting and wasting time.
—Don't be so silly; you're a fool.
—Sorry, Senator Ian Macdonald.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator Ian Macdonald, withdraw that remark please.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one are you ruling is unparliamentary?
—Senator Ian Macdonald, you have been here for quite a long time. You know exactly what I am referring to. I am asking you to withdraw it.
—I am afraid I don't. If you mean `you're a fool', I have never—
—That is the remark I am asking you to withdraw.
—I have never seen where that has been unparliamentary, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—Order! You may not have seen it, you may never see it; but, whether you do or whether you do not, you are being asked by the chair now to withdraw. I am demanding a withdrawal.
—In that event, it is a bit late in the day, and perhaps we might have to consider that. Although I know there are a number of people who—
—Come on, Ian.
—You just mind your own business.

—Senator Ian Macdonald, I am asking you to resume your seat. I am going to ask you once again to withdraw. If you do not withdraw, I shall name you and then procedures are in place which the Senate chamber would make determinations on. I am asking you to make that withdrawal now, and I am going to recognise Senator Ian Macdonald and Senator Ian Macdonald only.
—On the same point of order—
—It is not a point of order; I have made a ruling.
—On another point of order—
—Until we get this matter out of the way, I am not going to accept more points of order. I am asking Senator Ian Macdonald for a withdrawal.
—I am sure that my second point of order will help the Senate in the deliberations over the first point of order.
—Yes, Senator McGauran.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, your request of Senator Macdonald is of course your entitlement and, as I have taken the position in the chair myself, I might not disagree with your ruling. However, given the lateness of the hour and the tension in the air—which has been created from the other side—if you could allow Senator Macdonald to make a personal explanation with his withdrawal, I think that would bring proceedings to a close and satisfactorily so.
—I thank you for the remarks you have made. It is not a point of order. I think I have already met the request you just made. I am now asking Senator Ian Macdonald for a withdrawal.
—Because I want to take part in this debate and because we might have to pursue this otherwise, I think we should get on with the debate. I will withdraw in deference to your ruling.
—Thank you, Senator Macdonald.
—I did not think it was getting particularly heated in the chamber. I was making the point before this occurred—
—Just partisan.
—Of course, I am partisan—I am defending a reformist government with a very impressive record.
—Well, not you. I am not talking about you being partisan.
—Well, who are you talking about being partisan, Senator Macdonald? I call Senator Sherry.

—In terms of the attack mounted on Senator Collins's record as primary industries minister, as I was saying before we were rudely interrupted, Senator Collins is a fine primary industries minister. He is recognised as such by rural communities right around Australia. I was in Shepparton a couple of weeks ago and Mildura the week before last—
—I thought we were on the waterfront.

—You attacked Senator Collins's credibility as primary industries minister, and I am entitled to defend him. I hear nothing but praise about Senator Collins's record as primary industries minister. In the same context, let us move directly to the waterfront and look at Senator Collins's record as Minister for Transport and Communications, when he led with great vigour an appropriately balanced reform program on the waterfront.

PARA.TAB: He is recognised as one of the best performing ministers not only in this government but internationally, and he is one of the great reforming ministers in the area of the waterfront generally. I reject the assertions that Senator Collins—as Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and as Minister for Transport and Communications—did not perform adequately. He performed very adequately and very impressively by any standards.

The same can be said of Minister Brereton, the current Minister for Transport. He is another impressive minister in this government and a very vigorous reformist. I got involved last year in discussions about airports, which is another very vital transport centre for domestic and international passenger movements—and freight movements for that matter. I am chair of the perishable goods air freight subcommittee as parliamentary secretary to Bob Collins. I have had extensive dealings with Mr Brereton, the Minister for Transport. He is a very impressive minister. He has an iron will in determination to continue the reforms so as to improve Australia's competitiveness.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that Senator Panizza read the report. I was pleased to see that page 128 of the report referred to some of the typical comments about Australian ports. I am pleased to see that it said that Tasmanian port charges were close to world standards. I am just drawing your attention to page 128—

TALK.START.PARA: —How many ships go into Tasmania compared with Sydney, Brisbane and Melbourne which are the ones that are falling behind?
—Are you calling me a liar, a fibber or what?
—Don't denigrate—
—What are you calling me?

—No, I am not calling you a liar. Don't get so worked up. I am just saying there is a reference in the report on page 128 which says that Tasmanian port charges were close to world standards. I live at the port of Burnie. It is a fine port. I have already mentioned the port of Burnie being the fifth largest container terminal in Australia. It is a major Australian port. I hear continual denigration from the opposition about the port of Burnie. Go and talk to the member for Braddon, Chris Miles, and tell him your criticisms of the port of Burnie. You should read this report.

—Point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I did not say anything of the kind. I just said that the three major ports in Australia had fallen behind and that Tasmania was not as big a port as Sydney, Brisbane or Melbourne.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—That is not a point of order, Senator Brownhill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gosh, they are sensitive tonight. I am attempting to contribute to the debate and I get streams of abuse from those opposite as well as points of order that you have ruled out of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I understand their impatience because they all want to speak on this issue and time is running out, but we did have a long question time today. The opposition let question time get out of control. But to come back to this report, the Bureau of Industry Economics report confirms the success of the—
—What report are you quoting from?

—The International benchmarking—waterfront 1995 report put out by the Bureau of Industry Economics. From the facts I am going to give you and the alleged facts you gave us, Senator Panizza, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President—
—Point of order: I think that `alleged facts I gave the Senate' is imputing that I am a liar and I ask him to withdraw.
—Were you imputing that, Senator Sherry, and, if you were, I would ask for a withdrawal.

—I wasn't, but I withdraw it anyway just to keep you happy, Senator Panizza. But, after listening to your speech and looking at the facts I am going to put before the Senate, I really wonder whether we did read the same report. I do not want to impugn your integrity, Senator Panizza, but I really do wonder whether we read the same report.

PARA.TAB: The Bureau of Industry Economics report confirms that productivity in terminals increased during the waterfront reform process and was reflected in reduced terminal charges. Stevedoring charges fell 25 per cent as a result of the reforms—you did not mention that, Senator Panizza.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the turnaround of the slips is slower.

—Don't get rattled, upset and uptight. I know time is drifting away and I know that lots of people want to contribute to this debate, but the government has got a position. We are going to make a contribution to this debate because we have an impressive record to put before the Senate.
—But you are not competing with the rest of the world.
—I will get to that in a moment, be patient. With all these interjections I have got only seven minutes left. I think there is only seven minutes left for the debate.
—Give us a go.

—Just have a bit of patience and I will get to some of these statistics. This report states that port authorities have also become more profitable and that charges have fallen. You can look at the details of the charges in the report because I have not got time to, in part due to all the interjections and points of order that I have been subjected to during this debate.

PARA.TAB: But charges have fallen. This report notes that the introduction of Hilmer related competition policy reforms is likely to further stimulate improvements on the waterfront. I do not want to digress too much from this report but just to make a brief aside about Hilmer, the national competition policy. That is part of the general—

TALK.START.PARA: —Point of order on a matter of relevance: Senator Sherry has already out of his own mouth said that he does not want to transgress too far from the subject. That in itself means that he is going into irrelevant areas. I ask you to bring him back to the motion before the Senate.
—I think he was actually foreshadowing he was going to do that. I would ask you not to do that, Senator Sherry. Stick to the motion that is before the Senate.

—Thank you for your ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am sure that ruling will be as vigorously enforced on those speakers opposite. They may regret a ruling of that tightness. I have plenty more to say. I have not read every page of this 183-page report—
—You are not on the right report.
—Do you know what the Sydney Morning Herald said about it?

—We are getting interjections about the Sydney Morning Herald and the Financial Review. Have they read the report? It just seems to me that, from the lack of detail that they have given the Senate so far, they have not read the report in sufficient detail. The Bureau of Industry Economics report refers to coal handling charges at our major coal ports. Burnie is not amongst them, but it is a major woodchip port. In fact, I live opposite the Burnie port, as I have mentioned to the Senate on a couple of occasions during this debate. It is a very fine port, as I have mentioned. Regrettably, there is a nice big woodchip pile there now, and that has spoilt my view. I am a bit concerned about that. But I am a supporter—
—A scathing assessment of Australia's waterfront.
—They have solved that problem.
—It's getting in the way of your view.

—Settle down! We are so touchy tonight. I will not digress and talk about woodchipping, because I think we would agree on substantial areas of woodchipping. I have been interrupted so much that I have got through only half a page of my two-page notes. I have four minutes to go. Fair go! You are really causing me some concern here tonight. I am going to have to read the notes very rapidly. I am not going to read a speech. None of us would do that in this place. Before I was so rudely interrupted when speaking about woodchipping at Burnie—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise another point of order. I have to make these points of order because Senator Sherry, out of his own mouth, is transgressing the standing orders. As we all know—it may be an out-of-date standing order—you are not to read speeches in this house. None of us will enforce that unless it is actually brought up in debate. It has been brought up in debate by Senator Sherry. He tells us that he is not going to read his speech, but that he is going to read his notes. I challenge the chair to define how his reading notes is not transgressing standing orders.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the same point of order: I do not think he has the ability to read any notes anyway from the way he is going on and not talking about the facts.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Senator Brownhill, that is not a point of order. There have been a number of previous rulings from the chair in this place that one can quote from not only brief notes but also copious notes. I am ruling that that is what Senator Sherry was doing: he was quoting from notes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I have been looking at the data in the report here. As I said, I am a bit frustrated because I have only three minutes left. This is the longest speech I have given in the Senate for some time. The facts are further supported by research undertaken by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics, which found that shippers have now saved more than half a billion dollars. Half a billion dollars has been saved since this program ended.
—How do you relate that to Burnie?

—Burnie—that very impressive major port of Tasmania, the fifth largest container port in Australia? I am sure it has got its fair share of that half a billion dollars. The Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics also found that the average crane rate for Australia's five major ports rose from 13.4 per hour in 1989 to 19.9 in March this year—a 50 per cent increase. The average time taken to stevedore a vessel has correspondingly fallen. For example, in Sydney—not Burnie—the average stevedoring time fell 60 per cent; it fell from 44 hours in 1989 to 26 hours this year.

PARA.TAB: The report has noted that, despite the significant progress, our stevedoring industry still needs to take some steps to match the performance reliability and price of our overseas competitors. More has occurred under Minister Brereton, a very impressive minister, and Minister Collins, an equally impressive minister, than all of the reform put together by previous Liberal governments in the previous 100 years.

The current minister has made the point repeatedly about the need for further reform. The government has established the framework for continued waterfront reform. Massive capital programs are needed. It is not just about reform of labour, although those opposite concentrate on labour. They bash unions all the time. Conaust proposes to reduce berthing occupancy from 70 per cent to 40 per cent, to increase hourly handling rates by 75 per cent and to introduce the 24-hour day. This has been agreed to by the workers. It will invest $140 million. You need new equipment like the impressive new crane at Burnie. Senator Watson may have seen that crane, which is the largest in Australia. Senator Watson, please ask your colleagues opposite to stop attacking Burnie as a port.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a report that has generated some controversy. In fact, there was a very critical article in the Inside Sport magazine, which I think was released yesterday, which says that the Senate committee basically should have found the Australian coach, Mr Eddie Thomson, guilty of behaviour that was inappropriate to the extent that he should have been sacked. I believe the report by the Senate committee was very fair and balanced. On the evidence presented to us, I think the conclusion was that there was no evidence which indicated that Mr Thomson had received any money or had behaved in a way which brought him any improper benefit. It seems to me that that evidence stands.

PARA.TAB: In this article it is put that we had found that the coach should be retained as the Australian coach. We did not find anything other than that there was no evidence presented to us to justify the recommended penalty by the Stewart inquiry into soccer that he be dismissed. In other words, the negative that we present does not necessarily mean we are taking a judgment that he should have his job. In fact, we ended up criticising him for having behaved inappropriately.

It seems to me that various people in the media who seem to have some axe to grind on this have decided to totally ignore that finding of ours that he had behaved inappropriately. They may well have taken that view because the Australian Soccer Federation failed to take any action on the national coach, despite our finding that he had behaved `inappropriately'.

I do find it strange that the Australian Soccer Federation, which professed great concern and great hopes that this inquiry would put the problems of soccer behind it and would get rid of all the innuendoes and attacks—I had hoped that would have been the outcome of our inquiry—by failing to take any action, even by way of gentle reprimand, has allowed a situation to continue so that people have certainly expressed to me the view that the Australian Soccer Federation did not care what the Senate inquiry came out with. In fact, this article in Inside Sport magazine, in a sense, criticises the ASF, particularly Mr Hill, the president, for having clearly given an indication that, whatever we came out with, he was pretty keen to reappoint the coach. I have no problem with the ASF reappointing the coach. All I do have a problem with is the assertion in this article that Mr Thomson should have been sacked on the basis of what a very distinguished former judge, Mr Stewart, had to say.

What concerns me is that Mr Stewart's report rested heavily—and all the quotations in this article which say that Mr Thomson should be sacked rested heavily—on a lot of conditional words. They continually use words like `the perception' that something had happened, that he `may have' known, that the `implication' was, that there was a `strong inference' that he was doing it, and so on. I have had concerns about the level of response—and particularly this article—regarding what we have found.

I should stress that as far as I am concerned and, I believe, as far as the committee is concerned, this matter has not yet been finalised. There are other matters, particularly those relating, I regret to say, to the Institute of Sport, which are to be examined in the future and to which reference has already been made by some correspondents. I think it was Mr Michael Cockerill in the Sydney Morning Herald who made some reference to the fact that the Australian women's coach is involved as an agent for some young Australian soccer players who have been training, and receiving the benefit of expensive training, I might say, from the Australian Institute of Sport.

This is a matter which obviously is of public concern. It has received considerable publicity. Obviously this is a matter that the soccer inquiry should and, I hope, will properly examine. I stress that the report of the soccer inquiry so far is the first report—not the final report. The media, apparently, does not recognise that other matters of some substance emerged from this inquiry—for example, the pursuit of discrepancies. There was a discrepancy of something like $250,000 between what a Victorian club is alleged to have received as a transfer and what it is reported to have received. That sort of matter has been referred to the Victorian police because it is not a matter properly for examination by the Senate committee.

We are not interested in pursuing fraud and other such things; that is the duty of various instrumentalities. We are concerned about looking at conflicts of interest, particularly those relating to federally funded organisations, and particularly the Australian Institute of Sport and, in the case of women's soccer, the national coach of the women's team. In other words, there has been a response to our report which seems to me to be unreasonable. I hope that further matters will reveal just how sensible, balanced, rational and fair the outcome of this report has been.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's response to the 13th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation is indeed welcome. Honourable senators may recall that recommendation 6.1 of the committee stated that the committee was not convinced that there was not a role for the tribunal to play in dealing with medical complaints. The good news is that the government now favours including complaints involving the interpretation of medical evidence within the tribunal's jurisdiction. I need not remind honourable senators that this chamber itself played an important part in contributing to this widely acclaimed decision. The Senate select committee has just concluded taking evidence of the first 12 months operation of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. That report will be given later this session.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that in the submission to this recent tribunal review the ISC itself stated that a key factor in the government's decision to revise previous policy was the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal's caseload statistics over the first three months of its operation. The caseloads showed that less than 20 per cent of the written inquiries to the tribunal arose from disability claims and only a small proportion of those related to questions of medical evidence. A regulation gazetted on 1 November 1994 deferred the handling of disability complaints involving the assessment of medical evidence by the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal until 1 May 1995.

A difficulty was acknowledged, by all, I believe, where the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal was seeking a determination which affected contractual relationships between trustees and their external parties. This issue was also significant given the environment created by the judicial power in the High Court case Brandy v. Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and others.

Given the need for legislative amendments to bind insurers, and given other necessary amending issues, the exclusion of medical evidence from the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal jurisdiction was extended until 1 November 1995. I believe the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal will have, after this date, all the necessary apparatus and structures to provide for a low cost, fast and efficient resolution of medical issues as an alternative dispute resolution forum to the courts.

This now brings me to the government's response to report No. 14, Superannuation regulations No. II: superannuation industry (supervision) regulations. One of the key features of this report concerns the debate on member choice. Member choice is an increasingly important issue for superannuation members. I believe that in the future most superannuation funds will be offering member choice, not necessarily unlimited choice but some choice. However, I remind the Senate that that choice can be within only a range of investment options determined by trustees.

This will be part of an evolution where members now largely have what I call investment risk, and they certainly have this in accumulation of funds. These members are demanding a greater and greater say in the operation of their superannuation investment. I need to remind the Senate that members do have different needs through life. I believe that these should be addressed by trustees.

I also remind honourable senators that trustees cannot give unfettered choice to members, because it would be an abrogation of their duties as trustees and would also be contrary to the legislation of SIS. Legislators must determine where the boundaries of reasonable choice actually lie. You might recall that the committee recommended in its 14th report that beneficiary investment choice be mandated for standard employer funds with 50 or more members and members generating investment components.

Mandating beneficiary investment choice for such funds would seek to remove a glaring inequity in the superannuation system. As it now stands, members of personal superannuation funds are mostly provided with the opportunity to choose the most appropriate investment strategy for their needs and, importantly, are considered capable of doing so. On the other hand, members of larger standard employer funds have no such choice, and, according to some commentators, are not capable of having a choice and should therefore be protected. The committee has recommended that a `one size fits all' approach to investment is not appropriate and will become untenable in the long term.

I remind the Senate that a lot of women have made significant contributions to superannuation. Mavis Robertson, Linda Nicholls and Elizabeth Bryan are a few of them. Elizabeth Bryan was State Super Corporation General Manager, Investments, and won the Telstra New South Wales Businesswoman of the Year award. She basically says that a member's right of choice is more important than how many may exercise that choice. The other day, Linda Nicholls gave a very good paper on member investment choice, which I seek leave to table.
Leave granted.
