TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last two evenings, I have been talking about the need for the establishment of the marine park at the head of the Great Australian Bight and pointing out to the Senate that an extensive study has been carried out, at the behest of both the Commonwealth and the state, and that, despite the fact that that has been carried out—partly at the behest of the Commonwealth—the result of that study has been kept secret by the minister in the South Australian parliament and has not been released either to the Commonwealth or to members of the public.

PARA.TAB: I pointed out last evening that the minister responsible for declaring marine parks in South Australia is also the minister responsible for fisheries and the Minister for Mines and Energy and, as such, clearly has a conflict of interest when talking about the need for protecting marine areas for the purposes of protecting the breeding areas, principally, of the southern right whale. The minister responsible for fisheries and the Minister for Mines and Energy in South Australia has a conflict of interest with respect to his colleague the minister responsible for conservation. This may result in his reticence to support the marine park, despite the support which comes from the minister responsible for the environment in South Australia.

Disturbingly, the removal of SARDI from the draft management planning process is clear evidence of the increasing influence of the fishing industry in the management of South Australia's aquatic resources, at the expense of the independent long-term government research and management advice. This is evidenced by the establishment of integrated management committees, which now have statutory power to regulate and manage all of the state's aquatic resources, including habitat management, and to define research priorities—in effect, the privatisation of community owned resources.

All of these integrated management committees are overwhelmingly dominated by commercial fishing interests. Only one—the one involving aquaculture—has an environmental representative. SARDI's presence on these committees is not a statutory requirement. Any researcher, either industry or government, can be nominated. The South Australian Fishing Industry Council has recommended that any present SARDI representatives who sit on one of these integrated management committees have no voting rights.

Clearly, we have the South Australian government inhibiting what is—as we understand it, because we have not seen it—a very good, very well written and properly researched report which has gone through the process of input from a wide variety of public interest groups from being seen either by the public or by the Commonwealth. At the same time, the South Australian government is seeking to further inhibit the efforts of those legitimate researchers who work within the South Australian government at the moment to continue with their work on behalf of conservation, with a direction that their work be oriented towards exploitative activities. Many SARDI researchers feel that South Australia will follow the example of Victoria with a complete outsourcing of scientific research related to sustainable fisheries, with all research and research priorities being completely regulated by industry.

The value of the marine resource at Head of Bight in terms of tourism, as I have indicated already, far and away exceeds the importance of that area as a fishing resource. Whale watching is a rapid growth industry. In Western Australia, operators have reported a growth rate of 50 per cent over the last five years. In Queensland, two operators claimed a growth rate of 100 per cent in only two years. In Queensland, boat-based whale watching—this is mainly humpbacks in Harvey Bay—generated a direct income of $3 million in 1993.

At Ningaloo Marine Park in WA whale shark visitors have increased 400 per cent from 500 visitors in 1992 to 2,000 visitors in 1994. Whale shark fees alone generated $500,000 in 1994. If the additional costs for fishing charters, safari tours, diving and accommodation are included, a total of more than $2 million was generated from the eco-tourism activities in the region during the six-week whale shark season. South Australia has already generated $310,000 direct income from cetacean watching enterprises. This is based on only 10 operators.

The total catch of southern rock lobster within the total area of the proposed marine park boundaries was 44 tonnes in 1993-94 at current prices of $35 per kilogram. This represents a direct income of only $1.5 million. Within the proposed sanctuary zone—six per cent of the total marine park area—this translates into only $90,000 in income from rock lobster. It is important to note that the vast majority of the lobster taken in the proposed marine park is caught in the area east of Head of Bight. This area would be seasonally open to lobster fishing—that is, December to April—under the proposed conservation zone proposals. So here we have a direct comparison of the economic benefit of protecting this area as a major marine park—the economic benefit in terms of eco-tourism—compared with its established direct benefit as a fishing area.

Prospectivity for mineral and petroleum development is widely acknowledged to be poor in the marine park area. This has been confirmed by BHP, which has formally and publicly supported the marine park proposal. The Yalata land management program at the Head of Bight reported 10,000 whale watchers in 1994, with an estimated expenditure of $560,000 between Nullarbor Roadhouse and Ceduna. This is an area which at the moment is largely devoid of established tourist facilities. People have to literally go out there and camp to carry out this activity. The return in terms of eco-tourism could be very significantly increased.

Based on rates of increase in eco-tourism experienced elsewhere in Australia, with an expected rapid increase in whale watchers over the next five years, the Great Australian Bight Marine Park has the potential to generate in the order of $10 million to $20 million in direct income to the communities of the western Eyre Peninsula.

In Dominica, 600 people spent $230,000 to watch sperm whales in 1993. Whale Watch Kaikoura, in New Zealand, won the British Airways Tourism for Tomorrow award in the green tourism category in February 1995. The award recognises the high standards, contributions to the local economy and sensitivity to the environment. Whale watching has become a national icon that reinforces New Zealand tourism's clean-green image, which is very lucrative in the nature-based and eco-tourism market. They expect 44,000 whale watchers this year.

The estimated direct value of shore and boat-based dolphin and whale watching, that is, humpback and southern right whale, in Australia in 1993 was approximately $5.2 million, employing 200 people. The industry is considered to be continuing to grow rapidly. These figures are from an Australian Nature Conservation Agency report by Gordon Anderson to the International Whaling Commission in 1994.

So the 17,500 hectare Head of Bight Sanctuary represents approximately 31 per cent of the total sanctuary area recommended and only 10 per cent of the total state waters recommended for protection under the SARDI-prepared draft management plan. The original project funded by the Commonwealth was for a large, multiple-use marine park, not a small, unzoned area proposed by the South Australian government.

The Head of Bight Sanctuary cannot be considered a marine park but rather an aquatic reserve, that is, the small South Australian one. Marine parks are defined nationally and internationally as large areas, zoned for multiple-use activities. They are specifically established to manage a range of non-exploitative and exploitative activities. Importantly, they incorporate the concept of buffer zones. I strongly recommend that senators look at this proposal, and urge the federal government to become more intensively involved to ensure that this area at Head of Bight is properly protected.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take no particular joy in standing here tonight to record in the annals of the Hansard of the parliament of Australia the fact that the former mayor of the city where I live, Wanneroo, is now behind bars. Mr Wayne Bradshaw was yesterday found guilty of official corruption in that he accepted a $20,000 bribe and he was due to be sentenced today. Because of the amount of other work I have been involved in during the day I have not found out just what that sentence is.

PARA.TAB: I knew Mr Bradshaw from my role as a parliamentarian in the City of Wanneroo and I had a certain admiration for the way he got things done. He certainly was a very enthusiastic individual in looking after a city of which he was very proud.

Over the years many rumours, smears and innuendo have been attached to Dr Bradshaw, none of which, I make the point quite clearly, have I sought to use in this place or any other place. There are proper chambers in which to adjudicate these matters.

Indeed, yesterday back home in Perth in the district court, that adjudication did take place by a jury of his peers and Dr Bradshaw was found guilty of that bribe. He was convicted generally on the strength of the evidence of another former councillor from Wanneroo who had been earlier convicted of official corruption, Mr David King, who, like Dr Bradshaw, was a very influential and active member not only of the Wanneroo City Council but also of the Liberal Party of Australia.

I make those remarks and repeat that I have not sought to cast any aspersions, innuendo or rumours against any individuals. I have not spoken on this matter until Dr Bradshaw has been convicted and behind bars.

My local member of parliament, Mr Paul Filing, the member for Moore, has also until this time protected the sub judice rules. He did, however, speak on Mr Bradshaw and his trial on Tuesday night of this week, two days ago—and I expect that he is probably speaking in the other place as I speak here tonight.

That speech is an interesting one which I would commend to all honourable senators. It is on page 756 of the House of Representatives Hansard of Tuesday 29 August 1995. Mr Filing made some mention of Mr Bradshaw's record within the Liberal Party over quite a period of time.

He was also, as the bells rang, about to tell the House of Representatives, the other place, something about another of the local members of parliament, the Hon. Iain MacLean. But the bells intruded, and we will have to wait for another day to hear that.

I expect that, when Mr Filing does again speak, he may make references to another of the local state members of parliament, Mrs Cheryl Edwardes. He may go to the extent which I would like to do of calling for a royal commission into matters that are very loosely and unfortunately referred to as `Wanneroo Inc.'. The reason I say it is unfortunate is that the connotation of `Wanneroo Inc.' casts some doubts on the credibility of the locale and the people in the locale rather than just a very few individuals within it.

There are many more reasons which could be put in this chamber—but I do not operate like that—as to why there ought to be a royal commission or judicial inquiry into the affairs very loosely referred to as `Wanneroo Inc.', but I do not think it will ever happen. I doubt if it will happen. The reason for that is that the other member that I am expecting Mr Filing will refer to, Mrs Cheryl Edwardes, the member for Kingsley, is indeed the Attorney-General in the Western Australian government. I doubt very much that she would order such an inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was recently produced by the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland an inquiry into five Aboriginal councils. Those councils were not named—very peculiar, because if there had been any other council into which an inquiry had been held the council and the identity of the people involved in the inquiry would have been made public. For reasons best known to itself, the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland decided that it would identify those councils by the letters A, B, C, D and E.

PARA.TAB: I am rising to address matters contained in that report in relation to Aboriginal council B. I am going to say here and now that Aboriginal council B is, in fact, the Hopevale Aboriginal Council. There is a reason for my making this step and naming that council. An examination of the report will make part of that apparent.

The report goes into a number of investigations of the finances and activities of the council. For example, the Auditor-General in Queensland in February 1990 told the Minister for Family Services and Aboriginal and Islander Affairs that an audit had disclosed `an unacceptable position in the financial administration of the Council'. In March 1990, a senior consultant to the Department of Family Services and Aboriginal and Islander Affairs reported on the performance of the council. He said that it was riddled with factionalism and that personality clashes prevented some matters being properly dealt with.

A further report by the Auditor-General in February 1991 stated that council minutes were of an unacceptable standard, that invoices were not being reconciled to suppliers' monthly statements of accounts, and that the balance of outstanding debtors was unsatisfactory and amounted to $309,577.

In February 1992, the Auditor-General again wrote to the chairman of the council saying that the council was not maintaining a goods inward book; that third parties were collecting employees' wages without signing for them; that the council minutes failed to address authorisation of travel expenses, the write-off of debts owed to the council and the setting of rental charges and they were not always signed. Amongst other things it indicated there should have been $18,744.45 on hand at the bank and in fact the amount on hand was $2,061,21.

In May 1993, there was another qualified audit report. In February 1995, there was another qualified audit report in which it was found that the various accounts of the council and the trust fund were overdrawn by $128,981. How you can overdraw a trust account is completely beyond me. It is a disastrous state of affairs. That qualified audit report also indicated that there was a significant increase in arrears of debts outstanding to the council, 80 per cent of which were estimated to be uncollectable.

No doubt lawyers for this council will respond to my statements here in parliament today by saying that significant improvements have been made and that the council was recently congratulated by the minister for improving. That does not really mean terribly much, given that this council has an appalling track record of management, both financial and proprietorial. I believe that to say that the council had been congratulated on improving when it still cannot adequately manage its affairs is not satisfactory.

Why do I say this council cannot adequately manage its affairs? The explanation for that is really quite simple. I visited the community recently. Amongst some of the concerns that were raised with me, a number of elders, including one elder by the name of Gordon Charlie, asked me to inquire of the council's solicitors as to whether they could be provided with a copy of a compensation agreement entered into between Cape Flattery Silica Mine and the council.

Part of the council's claim for compensation was based on the claims of traditional owners, one of whom was Mr Gordon Charlie. I received a letter from Messrs Bottoms English, lawyers for the council, on 4 August stating that they were going to obtain instructions from the Hopevale Aboriginal Council concerning the matter. I wrote to them again on 23 August saying, `Three weeks have elapsed since I wrote to you and I have not received another response.' In the eight days that have elapsed since then I still have not received a response.

This would be disturbing even if you did not know that all of the councillors who are on the Hopevale Aboriginal Council are paid as full-time employees of the council. In four weeks the council has been unable to give instructions to its lawyers as to whether or not it can release a copy of the Cape Flattery compensation agreement to a senator who is inquiring on behalf of a constituent who could not get a copy of it from the council because it claimed that the copy that it had was burnt.

This is quite ridiculous. What angers me even more is that it is alleged—and I believe it is quite possibly the case—that the council is failing to properly deal with CDEP moneys that are paid to it. Honourable senators may well know that a council is generally provided with $177 or thereabouts per week in respect of each CDEP participant, and that those participants must receive or have the opportunity of earning an amount at least equal to the newstart allowance or jobsearch allowance.

When I visited the Hopevale community at the beginning of the month there were many people who said to me that they or their children or their husbands were receiving substantially less than the jobsearch allowance, that there were deductions made from their pay without authorisation, that the council had failed to adequately account to them and that they only got the money they believed they were entitled to if they kicked up a fuss. Having kicked up a fuss, they would be paid the appropriate amount for a certain period of time and then further deductions would be made from their wages.

The only reason that the bad administration in this council has persisted is that the Criminal Justice Commission has failed to name this council. I do not understand what is achieved by failing to name this council. We do not advance the situation in which the Aboriginal people of Hopevale find themselves if official inquiries into that council continue to cover up the most appalling state of affairs.

In the report, the Criminal Justice Commission concluded that it was impossible to bring charges against some of the people for the simple reason that the records were so lamentably inadequate as to be non-existent in some cases and to be totally unreliable in other cases. All the while that this goes on, the honest and decent Aboriginal people of Hopevale, which I believe is the vast majority, are on the receiving end of this sort of maladministration.

I have made these statements here tonight because I hope the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, who on other occasions has dealt with my concerns in a fairly satisfactory way, will initiate an immediate inquiry into the use of CDEP funds at the council. It is also time the council recognised that it has a responsibility to its constituents, to its ratepayers.

There are many other things that are wrong at Hopevale. This is just a small selection of the matters. I believe it is about time the people of Hopevale received better administration than they are getting. If we have to go through this process for as many months as it takes, I will continue to do this because I believe that decent people deserve decent government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to raise tonight deals with the Beijing conference for women, which is currently being held. I cannot help but note the irony of a country such as Taiwan not being given status in the United Nations—although I understand, as a result of a circular by Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, that the United Nations is now giving consideration to its membership. But I find it somewhat ironic that the conference for empowering women is being held in Beijing, in the People's Republic of China, under UN auspices, when a country like Taiwan is not being given recognition in the United Nations. Indeed, I know that if there were a choice to live in either Taiwan or the People's Republic of China, I am sure every single Australian would opt for living in Taiwan because it has a greater regard for human rights.

PARA.TAB: I also find it somewhat ironic that the conference is being held in Beijing and that we, as a nation, are going there relatively quietly. I just ponder what would be the situation if this conference were to be held in France, in relation to the nuclear testing that that country is about to conduct. Methinks the government may well be arguing for a boycott. Indeed, one thing that has not been presented at all to the Australian community in the same way as the French nuclear testing has been the question of Chinese nuclear testing, which has been going on, and on and on.

People will argue that we should not boycott China and that really our involvement there will assist reform that country. It is interesting to note that the people who argue that are the same people who argued against involvement with South Africa. Those same people argued for boycotts against South Africa because that would be the only way to break down the regime which did not allow human rights to the vast majority of the population in that country and had denied them the vote. They said that the only way to deal with it would be to have a boycott of that country. So it is interesting to note the different approaches that we, as a country, are taking.

But the real purpose for my comments tonight is to deal with the question of the Beijing conference and what we are doing there. It is interesting to note that Dr Lawrence said that our paper, our presentation, at this conference was largely determined as a result of trying to get responses through what was called the purple postcard campaign.

On 18 May 1995, she said that the 2,250 replies raised more than 5,000 points of concern, whereas, as a result of answers during Senate estimates, we were told in the executive summary on this purple postcards project that the responses covered around 4,500 issues. So Dr Lawrence and her office clearly took a degree of liberty in indicating the response rate.

These purple postcards asking for women's input were largely put around universities, workplaces, unions, international women's day events, live music venues and women's organisations. Circulating them widely within that area, one would assume that a particular response may have been achieved, as opposed to what would be found from sending it out to a lot of women who are at home looking after children or who are in employment in small business areas.

What concerns me is that Beijing was chosen as the venue for this discussion on empowering women by the United Nations and the world community. Beijing would have to be seen as the world capital of repressing women's rights through its brutal population control, which it has made into an art form.

Let us never forget that, during the Nuremberg trials after the Second World War, a crime against humanity was defined as including the forcing of a pregnant woman to submit to the killing of her unborn child. That was a crime against humanity according to the Nuremberg trials. These well-known crimes against humanity are practised every day in the People's Republic of China. But, for some reason, because it is the People's Republic of China, the world community wants to cast a blind eye.

China is a totalitarian, authoritarian, one-party state which ignores universally held civil and political rights and economic, social and cultural rights. In the world human rights guide third survey of 1992, China scored the fifth lowest ranking out of 75 countries. The 1994-95 Freedom House annual survey of freedom included China in the worst violator countries.

A country like that does not deserve the privilege of hosting a conference such as the one that is taking place at the moment. Indeed, negotiations over the text of the conference resolutions have been very much put in China's favour. It proved impossible to secure an unequivocal condemnation of abuses such as forced abortion and sterilisation. I remind the Senate that the Nuremberg trials said that those sort of activities are a crime against humanity. So if you cannot even get that as the starting point when you are talking about women's rights, and if you cannot agree, because the host country will not agree, that those sorts of activities are not a crime against humanity, what on earth is the world community doing in going to that country and giving it a degree of kudos within the world community that somehow it really does believe in women's rights and human rights?

Time is running out. Paragraph 115 in the section on violence against women states that other acts of violence against women include violation of the human rights of women in situations of armed conflict, particularly murder, systematic rape and sexual slavery. Forced pregnancy is noted in brackets. The rest, which is in brackets, is what could not be agreed upon because of the concerns of the People's Republic of China. Acts of violence against women also include terrorism, forced sterilisation and forced abortion, the coercive, forced use of contraceptives, female foeticide, prenatal sex selection and female infanticide.

If the world community cannot agree that these are abuses against the rights of women, I do not know what an abuse of women's rights could actually be. Why we are allowing this conference to be hosted in Beijing, when the host country refuses to acknowledge such basic and fundamental human rights, really does concern me. I simply ask: why is there any disagreement about the inclusion of such wording in the document at this conference? I ask the federal government to reconsider its position in relation to the Beijing conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to discuss a major issue for Australian women. I had hoped I would have an opportunity earlier today, having asked a question of Senator Crowley, to take note of that answer—well, I should not elevate the status of her response to the status of an answer—but I did not. It was her response in answer to a question which I had asked her about how much an average women who works for 25 years—not the 39 years of the average man—at 85 per cent of male earnings would have in superannuation when she retires.

PARA.TAB: This dishonesty that is being perpetrated amongst Australians, and which will be accentuated next week, is nothing short of the sort of lie or story that was told to Australian people when former Prime Minister Hawke said, `No child will live in poverty by the year 2000.' If anybody who is over 18 years of age out there thinks that the superannuation guarantee fund the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is putting forward will support them in their retirement, they are wrong—and, in particular, Australian women will not be supported in their retirement.

This government has had 13 years to get a retirement incomes policy in place. It has fiddled at the edges of superannuation to the point where people have no faith in it because they feel it will change all the time. The government is to spend $12.5 million—I repeat: $12.5 million—on an advertising campaign, funded by the taxpayer, to push the benefits of superannuation. Next week is national superannuation awareness week—well, I reckon it is `superannuation con week'. It is scheduled to coincide with the distribution to every household of a booklet explaining how superannuation works.

A few weeks ago in June we had a booklet circulated to all households about the wonders of the social security system; that cost two-and-a-bit million dollars. Now we have $12 1/2 million being spent on telling them about money growing on trees. The Prime Minister's extravagant $12 1/2 million propaganda campaign within six months of an election is a blatant political stunt designed to overcome public scepticism about the government's enforced savings plan.

The Treasurer, Mr Ralph Willis, says that he has research that shows that 76 per cent of women think that super is good for them, personally. Of course they do. They also think savings, democracy and motherhood are good things. That is not the point. The point is: are women treated equitably and fairly under Labor's superannuation policies? And the answer is no.

The coalition supports the implementation of a national savings policy and a retirement incomes policy which provide incentive and reward to all Australians. What we do not support is the sort of con trick which Mr Keating is perpetrating on the women of Australia. He has gloated that an average wage earner joining the work force now would retire with nearly half a million dollars in superannuation.

As I said, you have to be 25 at the time it is fully in force, so you have to be 18 now and work continually throughout 40 years to even hope to hit the $500,000—and that is only if everything goes to plan, such as interest rates going up at the same rate. But if you are a woman and have worked for 25 years—not the 39 years of a man—at 85 per cent of male earnings, you will not have that in your superannuation. This is an absolute fraud.

In 1990 the government had an opportunity when the coalition put forward a retirement savings policy for women. The government before the 1993 election sort of half copied that and let women continue to put into their superannuation for two years after they left employment. But that is not good enough. There really has not been an adequate attempt on the part of the government to address the issue of women's superannuation. In fact, Eva Cox, convenor of the Economic Women's Think Tank, has said that it is unfair and inequitable; she has cast doubts on the government's plan.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 29 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the public comments by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) during his recent visit to Japan on the treatment of Australian prisoners of war during World War II:
(1) Did the Prime Minister make any reference to the treatment of women forced into prostitution (the so-called comfort women) by the Japanese Army during the war; if not, why not.
(2) Was the Prime Minister given any briefing on the treatment of comfort women during the war and their unresolved claims for compensation; if not, why not.
(3) What is the current state of consideration by the Japanese Government concerning compensation, and/or other means of demonstrating remorse for war time atrocities against comfort women.

(4)(a) What representations, if any, have been made by the Australian Government to Japan over the issue; and (b) can details of the date and type of representations made to the Japanese Government in which comfort women are specifically mentioned be provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (4)(a),(b) The specific issue of comfort women did not arise during the Prime Minister's visit to Japan. The Australian Government has not made direct representations to the Japanese Government on this matter. The Prime Minister commented more broadly during his visit on the importance of Japan coming to grips with the realities of its past and ensuring the history of the war is better known in Japan.

(2) No. The Prime Minister was briefed on compensation and the August 1994 `Peace, Friendship and Exchange Initiative' (refer to response to question 3) in general terms. In accordance with the terms of the 1951 San Francisco Treaty, the Australian Government, along with other Allied powers, considers Japan as having discharged its reparations obligations.
(3) In a January 1995 statement, the Japanese Government outlined its approach to this issue in the following terms:

`On the issue of wartime comfort women, which seriously stained the honour and dignity of many women, the Government expresses profound and sincere remorse and apologies through the "Peace, Friendship and Exchange Initiative". Along with the Initiative by the Government, an appropriate way which would enable a wide participation of the people of Japan to share such feelings is now under consideration by the coalition parties' project team for 50th anniversary issues. The Government will allocate Y500 million in order to facilitate such wide participation, although it cannot directly compensate victims.'

The funding promised in the above statement was approved by the Japanese Parliament as part of the budget for the financial year commencing 1 April 1995. The details of how these funds will be utilised are still under consideration.
For additional information I refer the honourable senator to my response to Senate Question No. 1152, page 120 of Weekly Senate Hansard, 3 May 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Tourism, upon notice, on 30 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the Federal Government apply to the Bureau of International Expositions for the dates 1 August 2000 to 31 January 2001 to be reserved for Australia's International Garden Festival.
(2) Will the Federal Government offer financial assistance to stage the event.

(3) Is the Federal Government aware of the significant benefits for the Australian economy to be derived from staging the first-ever International Garden Festival to be held in the southern hemisphere.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister for Tourism wrote to the President of the Bureau of International Expositions (BIE) on 12 October 1994 and again on 12 May 1995 seeking to reserve the dates of 1 August 2000 to 31 January 2001 for the staging of a BIE endorsed International Garden Festival (IGF) in Australia.

(2) The Minister for Tourism has advised the proponents of the festival that, if a viable private sector funded IGF can be developed, he will take a proposal to Cabinet for the Federal Government to build an Australian pavilion for the festival.
(3) Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: Did any staff employed at the Lodge claim travel allowance with respect to 3-5 July 1994, 16-18 July 1994 or 21 August-2 September 1994; if so: (a) which staff; and (b) on what date and at what time did they: (i) depart from their place of work, (ii) return to headquarters, and (iii) what was their destination.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: No staff employed at the Lodge claimed travel allowance with respect to 3-5 July 1994, 16-18 July 1994 or 21 August-2 September 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 August, 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to an answer given recently to the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee in relation to the Blackhawk manuals:
(1) Why was the contract for the Sikorsky 5 year publication update service for the Blackhawk helicopters not renewed after 1992.

(2) In the additional information supplied: (a) what is meant by `the introduction of the new manuals and their updating will nonetheless be an improvement on current arrangements'; and (b) does the use of the word `nonetheless' in this context mean that it is anticipated that there will still be problems with the new manuals; if so, what are those problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The decision not to renew the contract was based on cost.
(2) The statement simply means that while the previous arrangements were satisfactory, the introduction of the new manuals and their updating represents an improvement.
